1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	We are a leading provider of a weight management system based on a low-calorie, portion-controlled, prepared meal program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages containing a 28-day supply of breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	Most of our customers order on an auto-delivery basis ( Auto-Delivery ), in which we send a month s food supply on an ongoing basis until notified by the customer to stop our shipments.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our Core Auto-Delivery program is regularly priced between $300 and $330 per shipment, or about $11 to $12 per day for a full 28 days of Nutrisystem ready-to-go food.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S4	Our food for the Core program is shelf-stable at room temperature and will last for up to two years, making it relatively inexpensive to ship and store.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S5	We have also expanded our product offerings to include a combination of our ready-to-go food and our fresh-frozen line of menu items.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P0_S6	This new Select program is priced higher than the Core program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our program is based on the following cornerstones that represent who we are to our customers: Results.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	We believe our program enables our customers to lose weight successfully.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Nutrisystem program is based on over 35 years of nutrition research and the science of the low Glycemic Index, and offers over 150 low-calorie, portion-controlled items that are high in fiber, heart healthy and contain good carbohydrates and zero trans fats.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P3_S1	Foods on the lower end of the Glycemic Index are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	We sell our weight management programs primarily through a direct-to-consumer sales and distribution approach using the Internet and telephone.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our customers can order 24 hours a day, seven days a week on our website, www.nutrisystem.com, and the food is shipped directly to the customer s door.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S2	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting of a pre-packaged food program and counseling.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S3	Our customers can either choose our pre-selected favorites food package or customize their monthly food orders for their specific tastes.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S4	There are no center visits, no measuring foods and no counting calories.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S5	Our Core Auto-Delivery program is regularly priced at about $11 to $12 per day for a full 28 days of Nutrisystem food.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S6	We do not charge membership fees.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P4_S7	Additionally, we advertise various promotional offers and pricing throughout the year.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	The direct-to-consumer approach using the Internet provides the privacy that our customers value.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	We provide online and telephone counseling and support to our customers using our trained weight loss coaches, diet counselors and other nutrition and dietary staff resulting in no need to travel for a face-to-face meeting.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Competitive Strengths We believe that our system offers consumers a sensible approach to losing weight without the use of faddish, unhealthy or unrealistic weight loss methods.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	We intend to capitalize on the following competitive strengths to grow: Product Efficacy .
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	We believe our customers are very satisfied with our products and believe they have lost weight while using our program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	Our customer surveys found that customers lost an average of 1.0 to 2.0 pounds per week and tended to stay on the program for 10 to 11 weeks (including the one free week most customers obtain with their initial order).
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S4	We believe these surveys indicate overall satisfaction with our program and a potential willingness to refer our program to others.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S5	We believe that our brand is generally well recognized in the weight management industry.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P6_S6	Our company and our predecessors have been in the weight management industry for more than 35 years, and we estimate that our company and our predecessors have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising over that time period.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	Low Cost, Highly Scalable Model .
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	Unlike traditional commercial weight loss programs, which primarily sell through franchisee and company-owned centers, we generate revenue in our direct channel through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards).
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our method of distribution removes the fixed costs and capital investment associated with diet centers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	We also minimize fixed costs and capital investments in food procurement and fulfillment: we outsource the production of our food products to a number of vendors and we currently outsource 100% of our fulfillment operations to a third party provider.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S3	Our goal is to offer our customers a complete weight management program that is convenient, private and cost-effective.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S4	Our customers place their orders through the Internet or over the phone and have their food delivered directly to their homes.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S5	This affords our customers the convenience and anonymity that other diets which rely on weight-loss centers cannot ensure.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S6	Additionally, we provide our customers with a month of food, including breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert, each day, which removes the confusion of reading nutrition labels, measuring portions or counting calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S7	At a cost of as little as $11 per day, we believe our weight management program offers our customers significant value and is priced below those of our competitors.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P8_S8	In addition, we do not charge a membership fee, whereas many of our competitors do.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our Industry Weight management is a challenge for a significant portion of the U.S., as well as the global population.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	According to the World Health Organization ( WHO ), in 2005 approximately 1.6 billion adults (age 15 and above) globally were overweight and at least 400 million of them were obese.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	WHO projects that by 2015, 2.3 billion people will be overweight and 700 million of these will be obese.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	In the U.S., data from a nationally representative sample surveyed in 2007-2008 found that more than one-third of U.S. adults were obese, with another one-third being overweight.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	Nutrisystem is currently operating primarily in the U.S. and Canada.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	Gallup surveys indicate that approximately 42% of the people in the U.S., or an estimated 96 million were dieting during 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	Of those people, approximately 56 million were attempting to lose weight and 40 million were attempting to maintain their weight.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	Approximately 8% participated in commercial weight loss programs and 56% conducted some form of self-directed diet.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P13_S3	We believe the Nutrisystem program is well positioned to attract both types of dieters.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, overweight or obese individuals are increasingly at risk for diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, certain types of cancer, stroke, arthritis, breathing problems and depression.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	However, there is evidence that weight loss may reduce the risk of developing these diseases, as well as improve the health and quality of life of people who have these conditions.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	In addition to the health risks, there are also cultural implications for those who are overweight or obese.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	U.S. consumers are inundated with imagery in media, fashion and entertainment that depicts the thin body as the ideal body type.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	Despite the high percentage of overweight or obese individuals in the U.S., the popularity of dieting appears to indicate consumers desire to be thin.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	The weight loss industry is very competitive and consists of pharmaceutical products and weight loss programs, as well as a wide variety of diet foods and meal replacement bars and shakes, appetite suppressants and nutritional supplements.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The weight loss market is served by a diverse array of competitors.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	Potential customers seeking to manage their weight can turn to traditional center-based competitors such as Weight Watchers and Jenny Craig, online diet-oriented sites, self-administered products such as the over-the-counter drug Alli and other medically supervised programs.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	We believe that the principal competitive factors in the weight loss market are:
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	the ability to attract and retain customers through promotion and personal referral.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	Based on these factors, we believe that we can compete effectively in the weight management industry.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	We, however, have no control over how successful competitors will be in addressing these factors.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	By providing a well-recognized food-based program using the direct channel, we believe that we have a competitive advantage in our market.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S4	Our Products and Services For more than 35 years, the Nutrisystem name has been recognized as a leader in the weight loss industry.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S5	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting primarily of a pre-packaged food program, online tools and counseling.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P17_S6	Trained counselors are available to answer questions and make recommendations to help each customer achieve and maintain his or her weight loss goal.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	Customers support and encourage each other and share information through hosted Internet chat rooms and bulletin boards.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	These services are complemented with relevant information on diet, nutrition and exercise, which is provided on our community website and emailed to our customers bi-weekly.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	Additionally, online and smart phone weight management tools are available to our customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P18_S3	These tools include the interactive Mindset Makeover guide, a behavior modification program that was co-authored by an international leader in the field of obesity research and is offered to our customers free of charge.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P18_S4	This insightful and motivational guide walks clients through the program and can serve as an interactive tool for our counselors to use to facilitate communication and enhance weight loss success for our clients.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Our Nutrisystem program consists of over 150 low calorie, portion-controlled items that serve as the foundation of a low Glycemic Index diet.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods and foods on the lower end are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Our program is perfectly portioned for weight loss and offers a balance of carbohydrate, protein and fat that meets national dietary guidelines.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	We have also worked to reduce the sodium content of our meal program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S3	Including grocery additions, our plans contain 1800-2200 milligrams of sodium per day, consistent with national guidelines.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S4	In contrast, the average American consumes 2800-4000 milligrams of sodium per day.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P20_S5	We will constantly strive to meet or exceed nutritional guidelines as they are updated.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	We have an agreement with Schwan s Home Service, a provider of fine frozen foods, for the development and distribution of frozen foods under the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	The program, which includes frozen foods ( Nutrisystem Select ), enhances Nutrisystem s tradition of effective weight loss and weight management.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	The full national launch of Nutrisystem Select took place in the first quarter of 2009 but was recently revamped so that most of our weight plans include these fresh-frozen foods.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P21_S3	The program provides customers with premium fresh-frozen foods that complement Nutrisystem s prepared food weight loss programs and still adhere to Nutrisystem s nutritional guidelines.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	When a customer orders Nutrisystem Select, two separate shipments are delivered.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	The first shipment will be sent directly to the customer and will contain Nutrisystem s standard shelf-stable food.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	The second shipment will contain the fresh-frozen foods and will be delivered right to the customer s home.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	The Nutrisystem D Program is a weight loss program specifically designed to produce gradual weight loss in overweight patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Results from a 2009 clinical study conducted at the Temple University School of Medicine and published in the journal of Postgraduate Medicine show that a pre-packaged, portion controlled meal plan in combination with weekly counseling sessions helped overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes lose more weight and experience greater reductions in their A1C levels as compared to those in the control group.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	This weight loss was also associated with reductions in blood pressure, cholesterol and waist circumference.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S3	A follow up study at the University of Pennsylvania and Temple University School of Medicine was launched in the third quarter of 2010 and is expected to be complete by the end of the second quarter of 2011.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S4	Both research studies were funded by Nutrisystem.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P23_S5	We continue to offer our program at Costco through the use of prepaid program cards.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	The Nutrisystem program has also been offered at other large retailers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	Each retailer offered a unique promotional package and pricing through the use of prepaid program cards.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	We have discontinued offering our program at underperforming retailers, but we will continually explore other major retailers where we may potentially offer our program in the future.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P24_S3	In 2008, we also introduced the Flex program ( Nutrisystem Flex ), which is a 28-day program consisting of 20 days of food, our weekends off program, which provides a less restrictive option to meet the needs and lifestyle of an important segment of dieting consumers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P24_S4	Nutrisystem Flex includes a Recipe Book ( Nutrisystem, My Way ) and a Dining Out Guide to help consumers make healthy choices and stay within the program guidelines on their flex days.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages of shelf-stable and frozen food containing 28 breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	In certain instances, depending on the promotional offers available, customers can receive more than the typical 28 days of food.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Most customers order through our Auto-Delivery feature.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	Our program is regularly priced for as little as $11 per day.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P26_S2	By offering a variety of shelf-stable and fresh-frozen foods, we help our customers sustain their weight loss efforts.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P26_S3	On our website, customers can order food 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	The features of our weight loss program address many of the most common limitations of traditional weight loss programs, including high initiation and recurring membership fees, the inconvenience of traveling to weight loss centers for scheduled appointments and lack of privacy.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	In addition, our prepared meals provide our customers with a structured program with limited weighing and measuring of foods, and no need to count calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	The convenience of home delivery, reduced grocery shopping time, and rapid food preparation also aid compliance.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P27_S3	Our food items have accounted for 99% of our revenues for each of the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P27_S4	No other product or service has accounted for more than 1% of consolidated revenue in any of the last three years.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	In January 2008, we expanded operations into Canada and in October 2009, we announced our Nutrisystem J Diet in Japan.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	Approximately 98% of our revenues for each of the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 were generated in the United States.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Marketing Marketing is a core competency that drives sales and builds the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	We have strong expertise in all facets of both offline and online marketing and utilize an integrated marketing process to drive profitable revenue in an efficient, effective way.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	We believe Nutrisystem is one of the leading and most efficient offline direct response advertisers in the industry.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S3	We deploy a hybrid of proven direct response techniques to: 1) build brand equity and awareness; 2) encourage qualified customers to call or visit our website; and 3) deliver profitable sales.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S4	We track response to each advertisement through unique toll-free numbers and URLs and we deploy multi-channel campaigns to target new customers that include television, print, direct mail and telemarketing efforts.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P29_S5	To reactivate lapsed customers and upsell to those already on our program, we utilize a combination of direct mail and telemarketing efforts which complements our other media advertising.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Our online marketing strategy focuses on driving high-volume, cost-effective, qualified leads to our website with an emphasis on increasing both front-end and back-end conversion through constant testing and optimization.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	We are continually exploring new online opportunities as the market evolves, but focus the majority of our efforts on search optimization (paid and natural), affiliate management, portal relationships, large ad networks, strategic partnerships, targeted display media and internal/external email campaigns.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	The consumer and business media outreach programs accentuate Nutrisystem as a leader and innovator in the weight loss category.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	Our public relations strategically complement offline and online marketing to increase top-of-mind awareness for Nutrisystem, as well as to foster positive word-of-mouth, in order to enhance purchase consideration of our product.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P31_S2	The Nutrisystem brand, our marketing and product innovations, as well as celebrities who have lost weight on our program are regularly featured in top-tier media outlets such as: The Today Show, USA TODAY, People Magazine, Access Hollywood, E! News and Forbes.com .
1096376_11_ITEM1_P31_S3	We typically compensate our spokespersons based on their initial weight loss on our program and maintenance of the weight loss over time.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	As a leading ecommerce company and brand, we constantly strive to employ the latest tools and technology in order to drive increased performance of online customer conversion, retention and reactivation.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	We utilize our ecommerce platform to drive a highly-customizable and personalized user experience, as well as to effectively and efficiently manage day-to-day ecommerce business operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P32_S2	In addition, we combine internal resources with external agencies in the development of our website information architecture, user interface and user experience.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P32_S3	In order to optimize the key online business drivers, we continually perform usability testing and are constantly optimizing our website using a variety of sophisticated third party testing tools.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P32_S4	Finally, we measure our online interaction with customers, along with broader website performance, via web analytics platforms and tools.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Sales and Counseling A majority of our direct business sales occur on our website.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	The remaining sales are by telephone, and our call center processes virtually all of them.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	Our weight loss program is also sold through QVC, a television home shopping network, which represented 4% of our revenue in 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P33_S3	As of December 31, 2010 we employed approximately 97 weight loss counselors and 256 sales agents.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P33_S4	Staffing levels for counselors and sales agents are largely a function of the volume of revenue and orders.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Sales agents are responsible for in-bound sales calls and will initiate out-bound sales calls to our leads and other targeted potential customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	Counselors initiate some out-bound sales calls but primarily focus on in-bound calls and email.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	Counselors also handle online web conversations from new visitors and appointments with existing customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P34_S3	Sales agents are paid primarily on commission while counselors receive an hourly wage.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	We seek to hire counselors with backgrounds in psychology, sociology, nutrition, dietetics or other health-related fields and with suitable temperaments to speak with our customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	Counselors are trained in our meal plan, our Internet chat service, email, motivational techniques and customer service problem solving.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S2	Sales agents are well-versed in explaining our program and working with our customers to determine the program that would best fit their needs in helping them reach their weight loss goals.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S3	Customer Service As of December 31, 2010, we employed approximately 112 customer service representatives.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S4	Customer service representatives are trained to handle in-bound calls and emails from customers who have questions or problems with an order after the sale transaction is completed.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S5	Typical customer inquiries relate to the arrival date of their order shipment, reporting of missing or damaged items and credits and exchanges.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P35_S6	For email inquiries, we have a software system that scans the customer s email message for key words and automatically supplies the representative with a form response that is reviewed, edited and sent back to the customer.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	Customer service representatives are paid an hourly wage.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	We operate an integrated order receipt, billing, picking, shipping and delivery tracking system comprised of proprietary and third party components.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	This system integrates the front end, or website customer interface, with order processing and shipping, and allows Internet customers to access shippers order tracking numbers online.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S2	Our computer-assisted picking system allows for virtually paperless order picking in all warehouse facilities.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S3	We operate an integrated network of distribution facilities.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S4	In 2009 and 2010, we embarked on several key initiatives within our supply chain, including the installation of new material handling equipment and a new warehouse management system.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S5	These initiatives resulted in realized cost improvements, enhanced vendor productivity and warehouse efficiencies, and they helped increase key metrics supporting customer satisfaction.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S6	In addition, these initiatives resulted in improved inventory management and allowed for us to reduce our overall warehouse footprint.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S7	We currently utilize two outsourced distribution facilities one located in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania and the other in Sparks, Nevada.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S8	During 2010, 100% of our fulfillment was handled by our outsourced provider.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S9	We have a service agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, which provides for storage, handling and other services, including pricing and minimum space commitments.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P37_S10	The current contract expires on December 17, 2014, but may be terminated sooner upon 180 days written notice.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	We believe that other outside fulfillment providers could be utilized if needed and we continually evaluate the need for secondary fulfillment services.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P38_S1	We continue to partner with our fulfillment provider to reduce the warehouse order turn-around time for processing and shipping orders.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P38_S2	In 2010, approximately 99% of all direct customer initial orders were shipped within two business days of the date the order was received.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P38_S3	In addition, we can ship to approximately 99% of the domestic population within five business days using standard ground transportation.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P38_S4	In 2010, we made capital investments in new material handling equipment and a new warehouse management system to target improvements in productivity, cost, quality and service.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Direct customers are not charged for their orders until the ordered product is shipped.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	We do not charge customers for shipping and handling on Auto-Delivery food orders provided customers take receipt of their second order.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	If a customer cancels before receipt of a second order or postpones his or her second order for more than 30 days, the customer will be charged for shipping and the difference in pricing for an Auto-Delivery order versus a non Auto-Delivery order.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	Product Development All of our foods and supplements are currently outsourced from more than 30 manufacturers or vendors.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	We have entered into supply agreements with many of these food vendors.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S2	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S3	One agreement also provides for certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S4	All of these contracts may be terminated by us upon written notice, generally between 30 and 180 days.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P40_S5	We anticipate meeting all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	In 2010, approximately 18%, 17% and 10%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from three suppliers.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	We have supply arrangements with certain of these vendors that require us to make certain minimum purchases.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	In 2009, these vendors supplied 18%, 19% and 8%, respectively, of total purchases and in 2008 these vendors supplied 15%, 19% and 5%, respectively, of total purchases.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Our product development team uses a number of sources customer feedback, market trends, nutrition science, and breakthroughs in food technology to create new ideas for our program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	New foods are created to enhance the variety of our current offerings or to support the efforts of creating a new program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	Typically, concepts are formulated in the test kitchen to meet our stringent demands for nutrition and stability.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P42_S3	We then contract with food manufacturers who further develop viable new products based on our specifications.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P42_S4	Regardless of a given food item s pathway through development, that food is evaluated for nutrition, compliance with our program, taste (using testing panels), and cost considerations.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	The number of stock keeping units, or SKUs, we introduce each year varies depending on whether we are introducing a new program or simply updating an existing one.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Our Customers We offer weight loss programs designed for women, men, seniors as well as people with type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Based on our customer data, our typical customer is female, approximately 49 years of age and weighs 187 lbs.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	We believe that, on average, our customers want to lose approximately 44 lbs.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	Based on our customer surveys, we believe our typical customers tend to stay on our program for 10 to 11 weeks (including the one free week most customers obtain with their initial order), lose 1.0 to 2.0 pounds per week and have tried other popular diet programs.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P44_S4	We believe that these surveys indicate a willingness to refer our program to others and that our customers value the following Nutrisystem program attributes:
1096376_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	they do not feel hungry while on the program.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our ecommerce and community websites, both of which are based primarily on third party software customized to meet our business needs, are each hosted in a top tier, co-location facility.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	These facilities provide redundant network connections, an uninterruptible power supply, physical and fire security and diesel generated power back up for the equipment upon which our websites rely.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P46_S2	Our servers and our network are monitored 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P46_S3	We use a variety of security techniques to protect our confidential customer data.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	technologies, including secure sockets layer, or SSL.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	Our customer data is protected against unauthorized access by security measures and we engage a variety of industry leading technology providers including VeriSign, CyberSource and SecureWorks to further ensure the security of our credit card transactions and the safety of our customers personal information.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	We own numerous domestic and international trademarks and other proprietary rights that are important to our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	Depending upon the jurisdiction, trademarks are valid as long as they are used in the regular course of trade and/or their registrations are properly maintained.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	We believe the protection of our trademarks, copyrights, patents, domain names, trade dress, and trade secrets is important to our success.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	We aggressively protect our intellectual property rights by relying on a combination of watch services and trademark, copyright, patent, trade dress and trade secret laws, and through the domain name dispute resolution system.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	Employees As of December 31, 2010, we had approximately 573 administrative, sales, counseling and customer service personnel, 23 employees dedicated to fulfillment and 51 employees in marketing.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	None of our employees are represented by a labor union, and we consider relations with our employees to be good.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is strongest in the first quarter and lowest in the fourth calendar quarter.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet and the placement of our advertising based on the price and availability of certain media.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Available Information All periodic and current reports, registration statements, code of conduct and other material that the Company is required to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), including the Company s annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the 1934 Act Reports ), are available free of charge through the Company s investor relations page at www.nutrisystem.com .
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	Such documents are available as soon as reasonably practicable after electronic filing of the material with the SEC.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S2	The Company s Internet website and the information contained therein or connected thereto are not intended to be incorporated into this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S3	The public may also read and copy any materials filed by the Company with the SEC at the SEC s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S4	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P52_S5	The SEC maintains an Internet site, www.sec.gov , which contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	Executive Officers of the Company The Company s executive officers and their respective ages and positions as of December 31, 2010 are as follows:
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Executive Vice President, Operations Joseph M. Redling has served as our President and Chief Operating Officer since September 2007, as our Chief Executive Officer since May 2008 and as member of our Board since April 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	In November 2008, Mr. Redling became Chairman of our Board.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S2	Before joining us, Mr. Redling held a number of executive positions at AOL, Inc., a global web services company, including Chief Marketing Officer, President of AOL Access, President of AOL Paid Services and Customer Management and Chief Executive Officer of AOL International from September 2001 through March 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S3	David D. Clark has served as our Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer since November 2007 and in July 2008, the Board promoted Mr. Clark from the position of Senior Vice President, which he had held since November 2007, to Executive Vice President.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S4	Prior to joining us, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of Claymont Steel Holdings, Inc., a manufacturer of steel plate, from November 2006 through October 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S5	Prior to that, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of SunCom Wireless Holdings, a publicly traded provider of digital wireless communications services, from its founding in 1997 through February 2006 and held the additional position of Executive Vice President from 2000 through February 2006 and Senior Vice President from 1997 through 2000.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S6	Christopher S. Terrill has served as our Executive Vice President, E-Commerce and Chief Marketing Officer since June 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S7	He had served since January 2007 as the Company s Senior Vice President of E-Commerce.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S8	Prior to joining the Company, from 2005 to 2006, Mr. Terrill was Vice President of Product and Marketing at Blockbuster.com, the online division of Blockbuster Inc. From 1999 to 2005, Mr. Terrill held senior level positions at Match.com, where he served as Vice President of New Brands Verticals from 2004 to 2005, and Vice President of Offline Initiatives from 2001 to 2004.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S9	Scott A. Falconer has served as our Executive Vice President, Operations since June 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S10	Prior to that, Mr. Falconer served as our Executive Vice President, Customer Management and Product Development since May 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S11	Prior to joining us, Mr. Falconer held a number of positions at AOL, Inc., a global web services company, including Executive Vice President, AOL Mobile as well as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, AOL Member Services from 2002 through 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM1_P54_S12	Effective March 2, 2011, Mr. Falconer ceased to be an executive officer of the Company.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	consider carefully the following risks and uncertainties when reading this Annual Report on Form 10-K. If any of the events described below actually occurs, the Company s business, financial condition and operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Risks Related to Our Business Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures and our ability to select the right markets and media in which to advertise.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Our marketing expenditures were $145.9 million, $146.4 million and $174.9 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures, including our ability to:
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	convert consumer inquiries into actual orders.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our planned marketing expenditures may not result in increased revenue or generate sufficient levels of brand name and program awareness.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	We may not be able to manage our marketing expenditures on a cost-effective basis whereby our customer acquisition cost may exceed the contribution profit generated from each additional customer.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our sales can be adversely impacted by the health and stability of the general economy.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, such as a recession or prolonged economic slowdown, may reduce the demand for our products and otherwise adversely affect our sales.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	For example, economic forces, including general economic conditions, demographic trends, consumer confidence in the economy, changes in disposable consumer income and/or reductions in discretionary spending, may cause consumers to defer purchases of our program which could adversely affect our revenue, gross margins, and/or our overall financial condition and operating results.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	We rely on third parties to provide us with adequate food supply and certain fulfillment, Internet, networking and call center services, the loss of any of which could cause our revenue, earnings or reputation to suffer.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S4	We rely solely on third party manufacturers to supply all of the food and other products we sell.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P2_S5	In 2010, approximately 18%, 17% and 10%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from three suppliers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	If we are unable to obtain sufficient quantity, quality and variety of food and other products in a timely and low-cost manner from our manufacturers, we will be unable to fulfill our customers orders in a timely manner, which may cause us to lose revenue and market share or incur higher costs, as well as damage the value of the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In 2010, more than 95% of our orders were shipped by one third party, United Parcel Service, or UPS, and 100% of our order fulfillment was handled by another third party, Ozburn-Hessey Logistics, or OHL.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Should UPS or OHL be unable to service our needs for even a short duration, our revenue and business could be harmed.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Additionally, the cost and time associated with replacing UPS or OHL on short notice would add to our costs.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any replacement fulfillment provider would also require startup time, which could cause us to lose sales and market share.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Internet, Networking and Call Center .
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Our business also depends on a number of third parties for Internet access, networking and call center services, and we have limited control over these third parties.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Should our network connections go down, our ability to fulfill orders would be delayed.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Further, if our website or call center becomes unavailable for a noticeable period of time due to Internet or communication failures, our business could be adversely affected, including harm to our brand and loss of sales.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S4	Therefore, we are dependent on maintaining good relationships with these third parties.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P5_S5	The services we require from these parties may be disrupted by a number of factors associated with their businesses, including the following:
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	with respect to our food suppliers, shortages of ingredients or United States Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) and United States Food and Drug Administration ( FDA ) compliance issues.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We may be subject to claims that our personnel are unqualified to provide proper weight loss advice.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Some of our counselors for our weight management program do not have extensive training or certification in nutrition, diet or health fields and have only undergone the training they receive from us.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S3	We may be subject to claims from our customers alleging that our personnel lack the qualifications necessary to provide proper advice regarding weight loss and related topics.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S4	We may also be subject to claims that our personnel have provided inappropriate advice or have inappropriately referred or failed to refer customers to health care providers for matters other than weight loss.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Such claims could result in damage to our reputation and divert management s attention from our business, which would adversely affect our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S6	We may be subject to health-related claims from our customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S7	Our weight loss program does not include medical treatment or medical advice, and we do not engage physicians or nurses to monitor the progress of our customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Many people who are overweight suffer from other physical conditions, and our target consumers could be considered a high-risk population.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S9	A customer who experiences health problems could allege or bring a lawsuit against us on the basis that those problems were caused or worsened by participating in our weight management program.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S10	For example, our predecessor businesses suffered substantial losses due to health-related claims and related publicity.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S11	Currently, we are neither subject to any such allegations nor have we been named in any such litigation.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S12	However, if we were, we would defend ourselves against such claims.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S13	Defending ourselves against such claims, regardless of their merit and ultimate outcome, would likely be lengthy and costly, and adversely affect our results of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P6_S14	Further, our general liability insurance may not cover claims of these types.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The weight management industry is highly competitive.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	If any of our competitors or a new entrant into the market with significant resources pursues a weight management program similar to ours, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Competition is intense in the weight management industry and we must remain competitive in the areas of program efficacy, price, taste, customer service and brand recognition.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Some of our competitors are significantly larger than we are and have substantially greater resources.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S4	Our business could be adversely affected if someone with significant resources decided to imitate our weight management program.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S5	For example, if a major supplier of pre-packaged foods decided to enter this market and made a substantial investment of resources in advertising and training diet counselors, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P7_S6	Any increased competition from new entrants into our industry or any increased success by existing competition could result in reductions in our sales or prices, or both, which could have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We are dependent on certain third party agreements for a percentage of revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We have contractual agreements with certain third party retailers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Under the agreements, these third parties control when and how often our products and services are offered and we are not guaranteed any minimum level of sales or transactions.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Additionally some agreements contain exclusive rights in specified locations to promote our products during the contract term and for specified years thereafter.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S4	If any third party elects not to renew their agreement or reduces the promotion of our products, our operating profits will suffer.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Additionally, in certain instances, we could be prohibited from selling our products through competitors of these third parties for a specified time after the termination of the agreements.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	New weight loss products or services may put us at a competitive disadvantage.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	On an ongoing basis, many existing and potential providers of weight loss solutions, including many pharmaceutical firms with significantly greater financial and operating resources than we have, are developing new products and services.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P9_S2	The creation of a weight loss solution, such as a drug therapy, that is perceived to be safe, effective and easier than a portion-controlled meal plan would put us at a disadvantage in the marketplace and our results of operations could be negatively affected.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P9_S3	If we pursue competitive advertising, we may be subject to litigation from our competitors.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P9_S4	If we pursue competitive advertising, our competitors may pursue litigation regardless of its merit and chances of success.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Competitive advertising may include advertising that directly or indirectly mentions a competitor or a competitor s weight loss program in comparison to our program.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Defending such litigation may be lengthy and costly, strain our resources and divert management s attention from their core responsibilities, which would have a negative impact on our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Our business is subject to online security risks, including security breaches and identity theft.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	To succeed, online commerce and communications must provide a secure transmission of confidential information over public networks.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Currently, a significant number of our customers authorize us to bill their credit cards directly for all fees charged by us.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We rely on third party software products to secure our credit card transactions.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Although we have developed systems and processes that are designed to protect consumer information and prevent fraudulent payment transactions and other security breaches, failure to prevent or mitigate such fraud or breaches may adversely affect our operating results.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	We may experience fluctuations in our operating results which may cause our stock price to be volatile.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P12_S4	In view of the evolving nature of our business and the seasonality inherent in the weight loss industry, our operating results may fluctuate significantly.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	our ability to meet or exceed securities analysts expectations, recommendations by securities analysts, the condition of the financial markets and other factors.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	These fluctuations, as well as general economic and market conditions, may adversely affect the market price of our common stock and cause it to fluctuate significantly.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Future acquisitions and the pursuit of new business opportunities present risks, and we may be unable to achieve the financial and strategic goals of any acquisition or new business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P13_S3	A component of our growth strategy may be to acquire existing businesses or pursue other business opportunities in the market for weight management and fitness products and services.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P13_S4	Even if we succeed in acquiring or building such businesses, we will face a number of risks and uncertainties, including:
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	the risk that the anticipated benefits of any acquisition or of the commencement of any new business may not be realized, in which event we will not be able to achieve any return on our investment in that new business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	If we do not continue to receive referrals from existing customers, our customer acquisition cost may increase.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P14_S2	We rely on word-of-mouth advertising for a portion of our new customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P14_S3	If our brand suffers or the number of customers acquired through referrals drops due to other circumstances, our costs associated with acquiring new customers and generating revenue will increase, which will, in turn, have an adverse affect on our profitability.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We use spokespersons to promote our products.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	If these spokespersons suffer adverse publicity, our revenue could be adversely affected.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Our marketing strategy depends in part on celebrity spokespersons, as well as customer spokespersons, to promote our weight management program.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P15_S3	Any of these spokespersons may become the subject of adverse news reports, negative publicity or otherwise be alienated from a segment of our customer base, whether weight loss related or not.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P15_S4	If so, such events may reduce the effectiveness of his or her endorsement and, in turn, adversely affect our revenue and results of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	If we cannot protect and enforce our trademarks and other intellectual property rights, our brand and our business will suffer.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	We believe that our trademarks and other proprietary rights are important to our success and competitive position.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	The actions we take to establish and protect our trademarks and other proprietary rights may prove to be inadequate to prevent imitation of our products or services or to prevent others from claiming violations of their trademarks and proprietary rights by us.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S3	In addition, others may develop similar trademarks or other intellectual property independently or assert rights in our trademarks and other proprietary rights.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S4	If so, third parties may seek to block or limit sales of our products and services based on allegations that use of some of our marks or other intellectual property constitutes a violation of their intellectual property rights.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S5	If we cannot protect our trademarks and other intellectual property rights, or if our trademarks or other intellectual property rights infringe upon the rights of third parties, the value of our brand may decline, which would adversely affect our results of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S6	We are dependent on our key executive officers for future success.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S7	Our future success depends to a significant degree on the skills, experience and efforts of our key executive officers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S8	The loss of the services of any of these individuals could harm our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S9	We have not obtained life insurance on any key executive officers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S10	If any key executive officers left us or were seriously injured and became unable to work, the business could be harmed.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S11	Provisions in our certificate of incorporation may deter or delay an acquisition of us or prevent a change in control, even if an acquisition or a change of control would be beneficial to our stockholders.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S12	Provisions of our certificate of incorporation (as amended) may have the effect of deterring unsolicited takeovers or delaying or preventing a third party from acquiring control of us, even if our stockholders might otherwise receive a premium for their shares over then current market prices.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P16_S13	In addition, these provisions may limit the ability of stockholders to approve transactions that they may deem to be in their best interests.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our certificate of incorporation (as amended) permits our Board of Directors to issue preferred stock without stockholder approval upon such terms as the Board of Directors may determine.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	The rights of the holders of our common stock will be junior to, and may be adversely affected by, the rights of the holders of any preferred stock that may be issued in the future.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	The issuance of preferred stock could have the effect of making it more difficult for a third party to acquire, or of discouraging a third party from acquiring, a majority of our outstanding common stock.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	The issuance of a substantial number of preferred shares could adversely affect the price of our common stock.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S4	Risks Related to Our Industry Changes in consumer preferences could negatively impact our operating results.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S5	Our program features pre-packaged food selections, which we believe offer convenience and value to our customers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S6	Our continued success depends, to a large degree, upon the continued popularity of our program versus various other weight loss, weight management and fitness regimens, such as low carbohydrate diets, appetite suppressants and diets featured in the published media.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S7	Changes in consumer tastes and preferences away from our pre-packaged food and support and counseling services, and any failure to provide innovative responses to these changes, may have a materially adverse impact on our business, financial condition, operating results, cash flows and prospects.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S8	The weight loss industry is subject to adverse publicity, which could harm our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P17_S9	The weight loss industry receives adverse publicity from time to time, and the occurrence of such publicity could harm us, even if the adverse publicity is not directly related to us.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	businesses were subject to extremely damaging adverse publicity relating to a large number of lawsuits alleging that the Nutrisystem weight loss program in use at that time led to gall bladder disease.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P18_S1	This publicity was a factor that contributed to the bankruptcy of our predecessor businesses in 1993.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	More recently, our predecessor businesses were severely impacted by significant litigation and damaging publicity related to their customers use of fen-phen as an appetite suppressant, which the FDA ordered withdrawn from the market in September 1997.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The significant decline in business resulting from the fen-phen problems caused our predecessor businesses to close all of their company-owned weight loss centers.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Congressional hearings about practices in the weight loss industry have also resulted in adverse publicity and a consequent decline in the revenue of weight loss businesses.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S3	Future research reports or publicity that is perceived as unfavorable or that question certain weight loss programs, products or methods could result in a decline in our revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Because of our dependence on consumer perceptions, adverse publicity associated with illness or other undesirable effects resulting from the consumption of our products or similar products by competitors, whether or not accurate, could also damage customer confidence in our weight loss program and result in a decline in revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Adverse publicity could arise even if the unfavorable effects associated with weight loss products or services resulted from the user s failure to use such products or services appropriately.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our industry is subject to governmental regulation that could increase in severity and hurt results of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Our industry is subject to federal, state and other governmental regulation.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P20_S2	For example, some advertising practices in the weight loss industry have led to investigations from time to time by the Federal Trade Commission, or FTC, and other governmental agencies.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Many companies in the weight loss industry, including our predecessor businesses, have entered into consent decrees with the FTC relating to weight loss claims and other advertising practices.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P20_S4	We continue to be subject to these consent decrees, which restrict how we advertise the successes our customers have achieved in losing weight through the program and require us to include the phrase results not typical together with a statement as to what the typical weight loss a customer can expect to achieve on our program in advertisements.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	In October 2009, the FTC published its revised Guides concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Regulation of advertising practices in the weight loss industry may increase in scope or severity in the future, which could have a material adverse impact on our business.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P22_S1	Other aspects of our industry are also subject to government regulation.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P22_S2	For example, food manufacturers are subject to rigorous inspection and other requirements of the USDA and FDA, and companies operating in foreign markets must comply with those countries requirements for proper labeling, controls on hygiene, food preparation and other matters.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P22_S3	If federal, state, local or foreign regulation of our industry increases for any reason, then we may be required to incur significant expenses, as well as modify our operations to comply with new regulatory requirements, which could harm our operating results.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P22_S4	Additionally, remedies available in any potential administrative or regulatory actions may include requiring us to refund amounts paid by all affected customers or pay other damages, which could be substantial.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The sale of ingested products involves product liability and other risks.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Like other distributors of products that are ingested, we face an inherent risk of exposure to product liability claims if the use of our products results in illness or injury.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P23_S2	The foods that we resell in the U.S. are subject to laws and regulations, including those administered by the USDA and FDA that establish manufacturing practices and quality standards for food products.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Product liability claims could have a material adverse effect on our business as existing insurance coverage may not be adequate.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Distributors of weight loss food products, vitamins, nutritional supplements and minerals, including our predecessor businesses, have been named as defendants in product liability lawsuits from time to time.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	We may also be subject to claims that our products contain contaminants, are improperly labeled, include inadequate instructions as to use or inadequate warnings covering interactions with other substances.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Product liability litigation, even if not meritorious, is very expensive and could also entail adverse publicity for us and reduce our revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	In addition, the products we distribute, or certain components of those products, may be subject to product recalls or other deficiencies.
1096376_11_ITEM1A_P25_S3	Any negative publicity associated with these actions would adversely affect our brand and may result in decreased product sales and, as a result, lower revenues and profits.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	lease two locations in Horsham, Pennsylvania and one in Fort Washington, Pennsylvania.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	These three locations total approximately 258,280 square feet of office space.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	One lease in Horsham expires in the first quarter of 2011 and the second expires in 2018.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S3	The lease for our Fort Washington location expires in 2022.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S4	We have additional fulfillment capacity in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania and Sparks, Nevada through an outsourced provider.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S5	We have no lease obligations to any of our outsourced fulfillment providers; however, we are subject to minimum space commitments which we may reduce over a specified period of time.
1096376_11_ITEM2_P0_S6	Management believes the outsourced fulfillment capacity is adequate to meet our needs for the foreseeable future.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	Commencing on October 9, 2007, several putative class action suits were filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania naming Nutrisystem, Inc. and certain of its officers and directors as defendants and alleging violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S1	The complaints purported to bring claims on behalf of a class of persons who purchased the Company s common stock between February 14, 2007 and October 3, 2007 or October 4, 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S2	The complaints alleged that the defendants issued various materially false and misleading statements relating to the Company s projected performance that had the effect of artificially inflating the market price of its securities.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S3	These actions were consolidated in December 2007 under docket number 07-4215, and a consolidated amended complaint was filed on March 7, 2008 that raised the same claims but alleged a class period of February 14, 2007 through February 19, 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S4	The consolidated amended complaint asked the court to (1) certify a class, (2) award compensatory damages, reasonable costs and expenses and (3) grant such other and further relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S5	The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on May 6, 2008 that was granted by the Court on August 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P0_S6	On September 29, 2009, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal, and on May 19, 2010, upon motion by the plaintiff/appellant, the appeal was dismissed with prejudice without costs to either party.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	Commencing on October 30, 2007, two shareholder derivative suits were filed in the same Court, which were nominally brought on behalf of Nutrisystem, Inc., and named certain of its officers and directors (including four current directors) as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	The complaints alleged violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and asserted claims for breach of fiduciary duty, waste, and unjust enrichment against all defendants and insider selling against certain defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S2	The complaints were based on many of the same allegations as the putative class action suits described above but added contentions regarding the Company s stock buyback program.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S3	The two federal action suits were consolidated under docket number 07-4565, and an amended complaint was filed on March 14, 2008 naming four members of the current Board of Directors and certain current and former officers as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S4	The complaint sought (1) judgment for damages against the individual defendants, (2) declarations that certain defendants were liable for violations of the Exchange Act, (3) an order directing the Company and current director defendants to reform and improve corporate governance, (4) extraordinary equitable and/or injunctive relief, (5) an award of restitution to Nutrisystem from defendants ordering disgorgement of all profits, benefits and other compensation received, (6) an award to the plaintiff for the costs and disbursements of the action and (7) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P1_S5	Defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which the Court granted on October 26, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P2_S0	A shareholder derivative action was also filed in the Common Pleas Court of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, in November 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P2_S1	Like the federal derivative action described above, the state court action was nominally brought on behalf of the Company and named four members of the current Board of Directors as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P2_S2	The complaint sought (1) a determination that the case was a proper derivative action and plaintiff was an appropriate representative, (2) a declaration that each of defendants breached his or her fiduciary duties to Nutrisystem, (3) an award to Nutrisystem of damages sustained by reason of the violations and exemplary damages, (4) an award to the plaintiffs for costs and disbursements and (5) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P3_S0	On April 30, 2010, the Court sent the plaintiff a notice to terminate pursuant to Pennsylvania s Rules of Civil Procedure for inactive cases.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P3_S1	The plaintiff took no action and, on October 1, 2010, the Court closed this case.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P4_S0	On April 27, 2010, counsel for the same shareholder who commenced the Montgomery County, Pennsylvania litigation described above sent a letter relating to the same events that form the bases of the federal putative class action and derivative suits described above.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S0	breaches of fiduciary duties described above.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S1	The Board of Directors has appointed a special committee consisting of three independent directors to investigate this demand.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S2	The committee has engaged independent legal counsel to assist it in this investigation, and after the investigation is completed, the committee will provide its recommendation to the entire Board of Directors, who will make the final decision with respect to the Company s response to the shareholder s demand.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S3	The Company also received in November 2007 correspondence from an attorney purporting to represent another Nutrisystem shareholder.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S4	This correspondence requested that the Company s Board of Directors appoint a special litigation committee to investigate unspecified breaches of fiduciary duty.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P5_S5	The disinterested and independent board members met to discuss this issue and responded to the attorney s correspondence.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P6_S0	The complaint sought (1) judgment against all defendants, (2) equitable and/or injunctive relief as permitted by law, equity and the state statutory provisions, (3) restitution to Nutrisystem from the individual defendants, (4) an award to the plaintiffs of the costs and disbursements of the action and (5) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P7_S0	Following receipt of additional correspondence from the same attorney in February 2008, the Board of Directors was considering its response when the shareholder commenced a derivative lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania in the name of the Company against the entire Board of Directors at that time and certain current and former officers.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P7_S1	The parties reached an agreement to stay this matter pending the disposition of the motion to dismiss the federal securities putative class action complaint described above.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P8_S0	On April 30, 2010, the Court sent the plaintiff a notice to terminate pursuant to Pennsylvania s Rules of Civil Procedure for inactive cases.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P8_S1	The plaintiff took no action and, on October 1, 2010, the Court closed this case.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S0	On March 28, 2008, a former Nutrisystem, Inc. sales representative filed a putative collective action complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, docket no. 08-1508, alleging that the Company unlawfully failed to pay him for overtime work in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S1	The complaint purported to bring claims on behalf of a class of current and former sales representatives who had been compensated by the Company pursuant to a commission-based compensation plan, rather than on an hourly basis.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S2	The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on May 28, 2008, adding a state-law class claim under the Pennsylvania Minimum Wage Act, alleging that the Company s compensation plan also violated state law.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S3	The plaintiff sought (1) that the action be certified as a collective action pursuant to Section 216(b) of the Fair Labor Standards Act, (2) that the action be certified as a class action pursuant to Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, (3) actual damages for unpaid overtime, (4) liquidated damages, (5) attorneys fees and costs and (6) pre- and post-judgment interest.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S4	The Court dismissed the state-law class claim on July 25, 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P9_S5	On September 26, 2008, the Court granted plaintiff s motion to proceed as a collective action and to send class members notice under the Fair Labor Standards Act claim.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S0	On October 14, 2008, plaintiff s counsel mailed notice to potential class members.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S1	Including plaintiff, sixty-eight former and current sales representatives opted-in to this litigation.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S2	On July 24, 2009, the Court heard oral argument on the motions for summary judgment that the parties had previously filed, and on July 31, 2009, the Court entered an Order granting the Company s motion for summary judgment and denying plaintiffs cross-motion for summary judgment.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S3	The plaintiffs filed an appeal of the Court s Order, and several employee rights organizations and the U.S. Department of Labor filed amicus curiae briefs in this matter.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S4	On June 21, 2010, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit held oral argument on plaintiffs appeal and on September 7, 2010 affirmed the District Court s grant of summary judgment for the Company.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S5	On October 4, 2010, the Third Circuit denied plaintiffs petition for rehearing by the original Third Circuit panel and a rehearing en banc.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S6	On October 12, 2010, the Third Circuit delivered its certified judgment to the District Court.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P10_S7	On November 15, 2010, the District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Company against all plaintiffs.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P11_S0	The Company is also involved in other various claims and routine litigation matters.
1096376_11_ITEM3_P11_S1	In the opinion of management, after consultation with legal counsel, the outcome of such matters is not anticipated to have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in future years.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P0_S0	Market Information The Company s common stock has been traded on the NASDAQ Stock Market since June 22, 2005, under the symbol NTRI.

1096376_11_ITEM5_P1_S0	Holders As of March 2, 2011, the Company had approximately 289 record holders of its common stock.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P1_S1	Prior to 2008, we had not declared or paid any dividend since inception.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P1_S2	We have paid a quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share beginning with the second quarter of 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P1_S3	The declaration and payment of dividends in the future will be determined by the Company s Board of Directors in light of conditions then existing, including the Company s earnings, financial condition, capital requirements and other factors.

1096376_11_ITEM5_P3_S0	(1) In August 2006, we announced that our Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to $50 million of our outstanding shares of common stock in open-market transactions on the NASDAQ National Market.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P3_S1	Additionally, in February 2007, a repurchase program of up to $200 million of outstanding shares of common stock was authorized and, in October 2007, an additional $100 million of outstanding shares of common stock was authorized.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P4_S0	The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depend on a variety of factors including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other market conditions.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P4_S1	The stock repurchase programs from 2007 had an expiration date of March 31, 2009, but were extended by our Board of Directors until March 31, 2011.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P4_S2	These programs also may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
1096376_11_ITEM5_P5_S0	(2) The period from October 1, 2010 through December 31, 2010 does not include 38,124 shares surrendered by employees to the Company for payment of the minimum tax withholding obligations upon the vesting of shares of restricted common stock.
