1096376_11_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected consolidated financial data presented below has been derived from the Company s Consolidated Financial Statements for each of the periods indicated.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S0	In June 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Technologies, LLC ( Zero Water ) as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with our current strategic direction.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S1	An equity and impairment loss of $4,000 was recorded during 2009 to write-off the remaining investment.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S2	During 2008, we recorded an equity loss of $2,975 for our share of Zero Water s loss and the amortization expense for the difference between the cost and the underlying equity in net assets of Zero Water at the investment date.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S3	Additionally, we recorded an impairment charge of $6,483 during 2008 to reduce the carrying value of the equity investment to its estimated fair value.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S4	The impairment charge primarily resulted from lower-than-expected operating results and projections of future performance coupled with the current non-strategic business direction of Zero Water and the overall general economic decline which indicated that the full carrying value of the equity investment was not recoverable.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P1_S5	See the discussion contained in Note 7 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P2_S0	In the first quarter of 2010, we committed to a plan to sell the business operations conducted by our subsidiary, Nutrisystem Fresh, Inc. ( NuKitchen ), as it was no longer aligned with the business direction of the Company.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P2_S1	NuKitchen has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P2_S2	During the third quarter of 2010, this business was shut down as we were unsuccessful in locating a buyer.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P2_S3	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P3_S0	The loss on discontinued operations during 2010 was primarily from operations.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P4_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2009, an impairment charge of $4,541 was recorded in connection with the NuKitchen acquisition.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P4_S1	This charge consisted of $2,717 of goodwill and $1,824 of identifiable intangible assets.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P4_S2	See the discussion contained in Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P5_S0	LLC ( Slim and Tone ).
1096376_11_ITEM6_P5_S1	This subsidiary has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P5_S2	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations and are included in loss on discontinued operation, net of income tax in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for all periods presented.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P6_S0	In 2007, we recorded a pre-tax loss on disposal of $1,256, consisting of an impairment of goodwill and intangibles of $1,156 and a pre-tax loss of $100.
1096376_11_ITEM6_P6_S1	See the discussion contained in Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Except for the historical information contained herein, this Report on Form 10-K contains certain forward-looking statements that involve substantial risks and uncertainties.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	Words such as may, should, could, would, expect, plan, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, continue, or similar words are intended to identify forward-looking statements, although not all forward-looking statements contain these words.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P0_S2	Our actual results, performance or achievements could differ materially from the results expressed in, or implied by, these forward-looking statements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P0_S3	Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include those set forth in Risk Factors.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P0_S4	Accordingly, there is no assurance that the results in the forward-looking statements will be achieved.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the financial information included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Background We provide weight management products and services and offer nutritionally balanced weight loss programs based on over 35 years of nutrition research and on the science of the low Glycemic Index.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel, and through QVC, a television shopping network.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2010, the direct channel accounted for 96% of total revenue compared to 4% for QVC.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S4	We incur significant marketing expenditures to support our brand as we continue to advertise across various media channels.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S5	New media channels are tested on a continual basis and we consider our media mix to be diverse.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S6	We market our weight management system through television, print, direct mail, Internet and public relations.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S7	We review and analyze a number of key operating and financial metrics to manage our business, including the number of new customers, revenue per customer, total revenues, marketing per new customer, operating margins and reactivation revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P1_S8	Our mix of revenue can be divided into three categories.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	First, new customer revenue is all revenue within a quarter from customers joining within that quarter.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	New customer revenue is the main driver of revenue growth.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	Second, on-program revenue is all revenue from customers who joined in previous quarters but who are still within their first nine months on the program.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	Third, reactivation revenue is all revenue generated from customers who are more than nine months from their initial purchase.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Over the past several years, our financial performance has been adversely impacted by a number of factors, including the economic downturn and declines in consumers discretionary spending.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	We believe these factors have primarily driven the decline in the number of new customer starts during 2008, 2009 and 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	The decline in new customer starts in previous years has also hampered reactivation revenue during 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	We are continuing to see a challenging environment develop in 2011 as we experienced significantly reduced sales below the comparable 2010 period throughout the month of January.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S4	Our 2011 diet season launch was ineffective in light of intense competitive activity, bargain-focused consumer behavior and weak promotional offerings.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S5	To increase sales effectiveness we re-launched our Rollback pricing strategy, which increased sales traction in the month of February but had a significant negative impact on gross margins.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S6	These factors will have compounding effects through 2011 resulting in decreased revenue and net income.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P3_S7	Additionally, we will incur additional charges during the first quarter of 2011 including severance which we expect to be more than offset by reductions in general and administrative expenses throughout 2011.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our eCommerce, direct-to-consumer business model provides flexibility which allows us to manage marketing spend according to customer demand.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	current instability in general economic conditions.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	Additionally, we have overhauled our eCommerce platform, redesigned our website and initiated a concerted effort to improve lifetime customer economics, length of stay, and overall customer satisfaction.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	Our product offerings have expanded to include fresh-frozen foods, and we entered into the retail channel and the Nutrisystem D program.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S3	Further, we have taken steps to reduce our overall operating costs.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S4	In late December 2010, we announced that we were incorporating our fresh-frozen foods into most of our weight loss plans and offering these plans at the lowest price in our history.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S5	Additionally, we have assembled a Culinary Council of industry leading chefs from around the U.S. to act as an advisory board to guide us in developing the best tasting and most desirable foods and menus going forward.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P5_S6	We believe our customers want great tasting, high quality foods at a low price with the ability to personalize and sustain and believe this new Select program will aid in reaching these goals.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 of the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P6_S3	Management develops, and changes periodically, these estimates and assumptions based on historical experience and on various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P6_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Management considers the following accounting estimates to be the most critical in preparing our consolidated financial statements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	These critical accounting estimates are discussed with our audit committee quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	We review the reserves for customer returns at each reporting period and adjust them to reflect data available at that time.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	To estimate reserves for returns, we consider actual return rates in preceding periods and changes in product offerings or marketing methods that might impact returns going forward.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S4	To the extent the estimate of returns changes, we will adjust the reserve, which will impact the amount of product sales revenue recognized in the period of the adjustment.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S5	The provision for estimated returns for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $24.1 million, $30.2 million and $47.5 million, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P7_S6	The reserve for returns was $1.0 million and $1.9 million at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and has been included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	One of our suppliers provides for rebates based on purchasing levels.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	We accrue this rebate as purchases are made at a rebate percentage determined based upon the estimated total purchases from the vendor.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	The estimated rebate is recorded as a reduction in the carrying value of purchased inventory and is reflected in the consolidated statement of operations when the associated inventory is sold.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S3	A receivable is recorded for the estimate of the rebate earned.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S4	Historically, the actual rebate received from the vendor has closely matched the estimated rebate recorded.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S5	An adjustment is made to the estimate upon determination of the final rebate.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S6	The rebate period is June 1 through May 31 of each year.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S7	For the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, we reduced cost of revenue by $1.9 million, $2.3 million and $4.4 million, respectively, for these rebates.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P8_S8	A receivable of $541,000 and $1.5 million at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, has been recorded in receivables in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	We continually assess the quantities of inventory on hand to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	We estimate the reserve for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on our forecasted demand and/or our ability to sell the products, future production requirements and changes in our customers behavior.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $419,000 and $1.2 million at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and the respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	Deferred tax assets are evaluated for future realization and reduced by a valuation allowance to the extent we believe a portion will not be realized.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	We consider many factors when assessing the likelihood of future realization of our deferred tax assets, including our recent earnings and expectations of future taxable income and other relevant factors.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P10_S3	We estimate the annual effective income tax rate at the beginning of each year and revise the estimate at each reporting period based on a number of factors including operating results, level of tax exempt interest income and sales by state, among other items.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	Results of Operations Revenue and expenses consist of the following components: Revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	Food sales include sales of food, supplements, shipping and handling charges billed to customers and sales credits and adjustments, including product returns.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S3	No revenue is recorded for food products provided at no charge as part of promotions.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S4	Cost of revenue consists primarily of the cost of the products sold, including compensation related to fulfillment, the costs of outside fulfillment, incoming and outgoing shipping costs, charge card fees and packing material.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S5	Cost of products sold includes products provided at no charge as part of promotions and the non-food materials provided with customer orders.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S6	Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S7	Internet advertising expense is recorded based on either the rate of delivery of a guaranteed number of impressions over the advertising contract term or on a cost per customer acquired, depending upon the terms.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S8	Direct-mail advertising costs are capitalized if the primary purpose was to elicit sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the advertising and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S9	The capitalized costs are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S10	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P11_S11	General and administrative expense consists of compensation for administrative, information technology, counselors, customer service and sales personnel, share-based payment arrangements, facility expenses, website development costs, professional service fees and other general corporate expenses.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Equity and impairment loss consists of our share of the earnings or losses of our equity interests.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	In June 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Water, as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with our current strategic direction.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	We held approximately a 27% fully diluted interest in Zero Water and had the ability to significantly influence the operations of Zero Water.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P12_S3	The investment in Zero Water was accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	Interest income, net consists of interest income earned on cash balances and marketable securities, net of interest expense.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	We are subject to corporate level income taxes and record a provision for income taxes based on an estimated effective income tax rate for the year.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	We ceased the operations of two of our subsidiaries, Slim and Tone and NuKitchen.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	Accordingly, the operating results of these discontinued operations have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Overview of the Direct Channel In the years ended 2010, 2009 and 2008, the direct channel represented 96%, 94% and 93%, respectively, of our revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Net sales through the direct channel were $490.8 million in 2010 compared to $495.4 million in 2009 and $639.0 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	The decrease in 2010 is primarily attributable to the decline in reactivation revenue partially offset by an increase in retail revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S3	Revenue is primarily generated through customer starts, reactivation of former customers and the customer ordering behavior, including length of time on our program and the diet program selection.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S4	Critical to increasing customer starts is our ability to deploy marketing dollars while maintaining marketing effectiveness.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P15_S5	Factors influencing our marketing effectiveness include the quality of the advertisements, promotional activity by our competitors, as well as the price and availability of appropriate media.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Overview of Distribution through QVC We distribute our proprietary pre-packaged food through QVC, a television home shopping network.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	In 2010, this channel represented 4% of our revenue as compared to 6% of our revenue in 2009 and 6% in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	On the QVC network, we reach a large audience in a 50-minute infomercial format that enables us to fully convey the benefits of the Nutrisystem diet programs.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	Under the terms of our agreement, QVC viewers purchase Nutrisystem products directly from QVC and are not directed to the Nutrisystem website.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	Retail prices (including shipping and handling) offered on QVC to consumers are similar to prices offered on the website.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S3	We generate a lower gross margin (as a percent of revenue) on sales through QVC relative to the direct channel, but QVC sales require no incremental advertising and marketing expense and, management believes, exposure on QVC raises consumer awareness of the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S4	Net sales through QVC were $18.1 million in 2010, $28.5 million in 2009 and $41.6 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P17_S5	The decrease in QVC sales can be primarily attributed to a decrease in the number of shows and quality air time.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	* 2009 has been reclassified for discontinued operations.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	See Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	Revenue decreased to $509.5 million in 2010 from $524.6 million in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	The revenue decrease resulted primarily from decreased reactivation revenue and a reduction in sales through QVC partially offset by an increase in retail revenue.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	In 2010, direct revenue accounted for 96% of total revenue compared to 4% for QVC.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	In 2009, the comparable percentages were 94% and 6%, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S4	Cost of revenue decreased to $224.8 million in 2010, from $241.2 million in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S5	Gross margin as a percent of revenue increased to 55.9% in 2010 from 54.0% in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S6	The increase in gross margin was primarily attributable to a reduced level of returns, the mix of products with higher gross margins and ongoing cost savings initiatives.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S7	Marketing expense decreased to $145.9 million in 2010 from $146.4 million in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S8	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue increased to 28.6% in 2010 from 27.9% in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S9	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2010 promoted the direct business.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S10	The decrease in marketing is attributable to decreased spending in the production of television advertising ($3.2 million).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S11	This decrease is offset by increased spending in advertising media ($1.5 million) and marketing consulting ($1.4 million).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S12	In total, media spending was $127.6 million in 2010 and $126.1 million in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S13	General and administrative expense decreased to $73.9 million in 2010 from $76.4 million in 2009 and as a percent of revenue decreased to 14.5% in 2010 from 14.6% in 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S14	The decrease in spending is primarily attributable to decreased professional, outside and computer services ($3.2 million) due to our focus on cost containment and charges incurred in 2009 to streamline work processes and right size our organization ($1.9 million).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S15	These decreases were partially offset by higher compensation and benefits and temporary help ($1.9 million) and increased non-cash expense for share-based payment arrangements ($1.5 million).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P19_S16	Depreciation and amortization expense increased to $11.8 million in 2010 from $11.2 million in 2009 due to the relocation of our corporate headquarters and capital expenditures on our website.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	Other (expense) income represents the impact of changes in the Canadian dollar.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	In 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Water because the business was no longer aligned with our current strategic direction.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	An equity and impairment loss of $4.0 million was recorded including the write-off of the remaining investment.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S2	Interest income, net decreased to $5,000 in 2010 from $104,000 in 2009 primarily due to borrowings under our credit facility during 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S3	In 2010, we recorded income tax expense of $19.3 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 36.3%.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S4	In 2009, we recorded $13.1 million of income tax expense for the reporting period.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S5	The effective tax rate in 2009 was 28.5%.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P21_S6	The increase in the effective tax rate was primarily the result of the abandonment of our investment in Zero Water in 2009 which provided an income tax deduction for the entire original $14.3 million tax basis investment in Zero Water and reduced 2009 income tax payments by approximately $5.0 million.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	* 2009 and 2008 have been reclassified for discontinued operations.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	See Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	Revenue decreased to $524.6 million in 2009 from $686.2 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S3	The revenue decrease resulted primarily from a decrease in customer starts due to the weakening economy.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S4	Reactivation revenue in 2009 remained relatively flat compared to 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S5	In 2009, direct revenue accounted for 94% of total revenue compared to 6% for QVC and less than 1% for other channels.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S6	In 2008, the comparable percentages were 93%, 6% and 1%, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S7	Cost of revenue decreased to $241.2 million in 2009, from $325.2 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S8	Gross margin as a percent of revenue increased to 54.0% in 2009 from 52.6% in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S9	The increase in gross margin was primarily attributable to decreased food and freight costs.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S10	Marketing expense decreased to $146.4 million in 2009 from $174.9 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S11	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue increased to 27.9% in 2009 from 25.5% in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S12	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2009 promoted the direct business with an increased concentration on the launch of Nutrisystem D.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S13	The decrease in marketing is attributable to decreased spending for advertising media ($27.5 million), the production of television advertising ($567,000) and professional fees and talent ($542,000).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S14	These decreases offset increased spending in marketing consulting ($587,000).
1096376_11_ITEM7_P22_S15	In total, media spending was $126.1 million in 2009 and $153.6 million in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	General and administrative expense decreased to $76.4 million in 2009 from $86.7 million in 2008 and as a percent of revenue increased to 14.6% in 2009 from 12.6% in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	The decrease in spending is primarily attributable to lower compensation and benefits and temporary help ($8.5 million) and decreased professional, outside and computer services ($1.5 million) due to our focus on cost containment.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P23_S2	Telephone and internet costs also decreased ($1.1 million) due to lower rates.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P23_S3	These decreases were partially offset by charges ($1.9 million) in order to streamline work processes and right size our organization.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P23_S4	Depreciation and amortization expense increased to $11.2 million in 2009 from $8.1 million in 2008 due to increased capital expenditures related to our website.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Other income (expense) primarily represents the favorable impact of changes in the Canadian dollar during 2009 as compared to 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	In 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Water, as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with our current strategic direction.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	An equity and impairment loss of $4.0 million was recorded including the write-off of the remaining investment.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P25_S2	An equity loss of $3.0 million was recorded during 2008 for our share of Zero Water s loss and for the amortization expense for the difference between the cost and the underlying equity in the net assets of Zero Water at the investment date.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P25_S3	Additionally, we recorded an impairment charge of $6.5 million to reduce the carrying value of the equity investment to its estimated fair value during the fourth quarter of 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P25_S4	The impairment charge primarily resulted from lower-than-expected operating results and projections of future performance, coupled with the current non-strategic business direction of Zero Water and the overall general economic decline, which indicated that the full carrying value of the equity investment was not recoverable.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	Interest income, net decreased to $104,000 in 2009 from $454,000 in 2008 primarily due to lower interest rates.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	In 2009, we recorded income tax expense of $13.1 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 28.5%.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	In 2008, we recorded $34.0 million of income tax expense for the reporting period.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S3	The effective tax rate in 2008 was 41.9%.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S4	The decrease is primarily related to our abandonment of our investment in Zero Water.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S5	The abandonment provided an income tax deduction for the entire original $14.3 million tax basis investment in Zero Water and reduced income tax payments by approximately $5.0 million.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P26_S6	The reduction in income tax payments resulted in a similar decrease in income tax expense in 2009, including a reversal of a $3.7 million valuation allowance established in 2008 for deferred tax assets related to prior Zero Water losses and impairment charges not previously considered realizable.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	As of December 31, 2010, our principal commitments consisted of obligations under supply agreements with food vendors, an agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, operating leases and employment contracts.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	Although we have no material commitments for capital expenditures, we anticipate continuing requirements for capital expenditures but at reduced levels from 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	Following is a summary of our contractual obligations.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P27_S3	We have no other commercial commitments.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	The Company has entered into supply agreements with various food vendors.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P28_S2	One agreement also provides for certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P28_S3	Additionally, the Company has entered into an agreement with our outside fulfillment provider which contains minimum space requirements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P28_S4	The Company anticipates it will meet all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	In October 2007, the Company executed a credit agreement with a group of lenders that provides for a $200.0 million unsecured revolving credit facility.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	We borrowed $30.0 million against this facility during 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	The credit agreement provides for interest at either a floating rate, which will be a base rate, or a Eurocurrency rate equal to the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate for the relevant term, plus an applicable margin.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	We are subject to 0.15% per annum unused fee payable quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	In 2010, we entered into two separate $10.0 million notional value floating to fixed interest rate swap agreements ( Swaps ) that mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	Under the Swaps, we receive interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pay a fixed rate of interest of 0.75%, with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	In addition, we have no off-balance sheet financing arrangements.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	The capital and credit markets have become more volatile as a result of the recent global economic conditions, which has caused a general tightening in the credit markets, lower levels of liquidity and increased financing costs.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	Despite these factors, we believe that available capital resources are sufficient to fund our working capital requirements, capital expenditures, income tax obligations, dividends and share repurchases for the foreseeable future.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S2	At December 31, 2010, we had net working capital of $74.0 million, a decrease of $29.3 million from the $103.3 million net working capital balance at December 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S3	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities to fund the stock repurchase program.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S4	Cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2010 were $20.4 million, a decrease of $11.8 million from the balance of $32.2 million at December 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S5	In addition, we had $20.8 million invested in marketable securities at December 31, 2010 as compared to $30.3 million at December 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S6	Our principal sources of liquidity during this period were cash flow from operations and borrowings under our credit facility.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S7	We have a $200.0 million unsecured revolving credit facility with a group of lenders which is committed until October 2, 2012 with an expansion feature, subject to certain conditions, to increase the facility to $300.0 million.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S8	We borrowed $30.0 million against this facility during 2010 to utilize our low cost debt capital to retire equity capital.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S9	No amounts were borrowed during 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S10	In the year ended December 31, 2010, we generated cash flows of $66.9 million from continuing operations, an increase of $10.3 million from 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S11	The increase in cash flow from operations is primarily attributable to higher net income and non-cash working capital changes primarily from reductions in inventory.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S12	In the year ended December 31, 2010, net cash used in investing activities from continuing operations was $10.1 million, primarily due to capital expenditures of $19.6 million for the relocation of our corporate headquarters and web initiatives, partially offset by sales of marketable securities of $10.0 million.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P32_S13	In the year ended December 31, 2010, net cash used in financing activities was $68.6 million, primarily for the repurchase of 3,270,429 shares of our common stock for an aggregate cost of $75.0 million and the payment of dividends of $20.7 million, partially offset by the borrowings under our credit facility of $30.0 million.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	Our Board of Directors has authorized stock repurchase programs under which an additional $38.8 million of our outstanding shares of common stock may be purchased through March 31, 2011.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	The repurchase programs may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S2	The repurchased shares have been retired.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S3	The Board of Directors declared quarterly dividends of $0.175 per share, which were paid on March 22, 2010, May 24, 2010, August 19, 2010 and November 22, 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S4	Subsequent to December 31, 2010, the Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share payable on March 17, 2011 to shareholders of record as of March 7, 2011.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P33_S5	Although the Company intends to continue to pay regular quarterly dividends, the declaration and payment of future dividends are discretionary and will be subject to quarterly determination by the Board of Directors following its review of the Company s financial performance.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is strongest in the first calendar quarter and lowest in the fourth calendar quarter.
1096376_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet and the price and availability of certain media.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	variable-rate debt and fixing the interest rate of certain variable-rate debt through the use of interest rate swaps.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	At December 31, 2010, we had two interest rate swap agreements (the Swaps ), with notional amounts of $10.0 million each, which mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Under the Swaps, we receive interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pay a fixed rate of interest of 0.75% with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P1_S2	At December 31, 2010, we had $30.0 million of debt outstanding at a weighted average interest rate of 1.09%.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P1_S3	A 1 percentage point change in the weighted average rate would affect annual interest by approximately $300,000.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We believe that we are not subject to any material risks arising from changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity prices or other market changes that affect market risk instruments.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Our cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2010 of $20.4 million were maintained in bank and money market accounts.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Additionally, we invested $20.8 million in marketable securities, which are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at fair value in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_11_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As such, a change in interest rates of 1 percentage point would not have a material impact on our operating results and cash flows.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Controls and Procedures The Securities and Exchange Commission defines the term disclosure controls and procedures to mean a company s controls and other procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that it files or submits under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on the evaluation of the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures by our management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer, as of the end of the period covered by this report, our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer have concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures at the end of the period covered by this report were effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is (i) recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Commission s rules and forms, and (ii) accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding disclosure.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over the Company s financial reporting.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of the Company s financial reporting and the preparation of consolidated financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that: (i) pertain to maintaining records that, in a reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect our transactions and dispositions of our assets; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of our financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and that the receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made in accordance with management and board of director authorization; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	There was no change in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Management evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ).
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based upon that evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P5_S0	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm, KPMG LLP, has audited the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Their report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting appears on page 37.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Nutrisystem, Inc.: We have audited Nutrisystem, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Nutrisystem, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P6_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S4	In our opinion, Nutrisystem, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1096376_11_ITEM9A_P7_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders equity and comprehensive income, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010, and our report dated March 7, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P9_S0	BACKGROUND Nature of the Business Nutrisystem, Inc. (the Company or Nutrisystem ), a provider of weight management products and services, offers nutritionally balanced weight loss programs based on over 35 years of nutrition research and on the science of the low glycemic index.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P9_S1	The Company s pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel and through QVC, a television shopping network.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P9_S2	Approximately 98% of revenues for each the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 were generated in the United States.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P10_S0	The Company s consolidated financial statements include 100% of the assets and liabilities of Nutrisystem, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P10_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P11_S0	Cash, Cash Equivalents and Marketable Securities Cash and cash equivalents include only securities having a maturity of three months or less at the time of purchase.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P11_S1	At December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, demand accounts and money market accounts comprised all of the Company s cash and cash equivalents.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P12_S0	Marketable securities consist of investments in a bond fund that holds short-term U.S. government securities with original maturities of greater than three months.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P12_S1	The Company classifies these as available-for-sale securities.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P12_S2	The marketable securities are reported at fair value with the related unrealized gains and losses included in accumulated other comprehensive loss, a component of stockholders equity, net of related tax effects.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P13_S0	The Company evaluates its investments for other-than-temporary impairment by reviewing factors such as the length of time and extent to which fair value has been below cost basis and the Company s ability and intent to hold the investment for a period of time which may be sufficient for anticipated recovery of the market value.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P13_S1	There were no other-than-temporary impairments in 2010 or 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S0	Inventories Inventories consist principally of packaged food held in outside fulfillment locations.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S1	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market, with cost determined using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S2	Quantities of inventory on hand are continually assessed to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S3	The reserve is estimated for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on forecasted demand and/or the Company s ability to sell the products, future production requirements and changes in customers behavior.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S4	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $419 and $1,179 at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P14_S5	Fixed Assets Fixed assets are stated at cost.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P15_S0	Depreciation is provided using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which are generally two to seven years.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P16_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the lesser of the estimated useful life of the asset or the related lease term.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P16_S1	Expenditures for repairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred, while major renewals and improvements are capitalized.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P17_S0	Included in fixed assets is the capitalized cost of internal-use software and website development incurred during the application development stage.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P17_S1	Capitalized costs are amortized using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the asset, which is generally two to five years.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P18_S0	Costs incurred related to planning or maintenance of internal-use software and website development are charged to expense as incurred.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P18_S1	The net book value of capitalized software was $12,845 and $12,332 at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P19_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company continually evaluates whether events or circumstances have occurred that would indicate that the remaining estimated useful lives of long-lived assets may warrant revision or that the remaining balance may not be recoverable.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P19_S1	Long-lived assets are evaluated for indicators of impairment.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P19_S2	When factors indicate that long-lived assets should be evaluated for possible impairment, an estimate of the related undiscounted cash flows over the remaining life of the long-lived assets is used to measure recoverability.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P19_S3	If any impairment is indicated, measurement of the impairment will be based on the difference between the carrying value and fair value of the asset, generally determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows associated with the use of the asset.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P20_S0	As of December 31, 2010, management believes that no reductions to the remaining useful lives or write-downs of long-lived assets are required.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P21_S0	The functional currency of the Company s Canadian subsidiary is the Canadian dollar.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P21_S1	Assets and liabilities are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates as of the financial statement date and revenues and expenses are translated at average exchange rates prevailing during the respective periods.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P21_S2	Translation adjustments are included as a separate component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders equity in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P21_S3	Gains and losses from foreign currency transactions are recognized as other income (expense) in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations and were $32 of expense in 2010, $407 of income in 2009 and $1,155 of expense in 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P22_S0	Derivative Instruments Interest rate swap agreements, a type of financial derivative instrument, are utilized by the Company to reduce interest rate risk on credit facility borrowings.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P22_S1	The Company recognizes the interest rate swaps in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets at fair value.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P22_S2	The Company has designated and accounted for its interest rate swaps as cash flow hedges of variable-rate debt.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P22_S3	The effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative is reported as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders equity in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, net of tax, and reclassified into earnings in the periods during which the hedged transactions affect earnings.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P22_S4	To the extent that the change in value of the derivative does not perfectly offset the change in value of the items being hedged, that ineffective portion is immediately recognized in earnings.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P23_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from product sales is recognized when the earnings process is complete, which is upon transfer of title to the product.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P23_S1	Recognition of revenue upon shipment meets the revenue recognition criteria in that persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the selling price is fixed and determinable and collection is reasonably assured.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S0	The Company sells prepaid program cards to wholesalers and retailers.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S1	Revenue from these cards is recognized after the card is redeemed online at the Company s website by the customer and the product is shipped to the customer.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S2	Deferred revenue consists primarily of unredeemed prepaid program cards and unshipped frozen foods.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S3	Customers may return unopened product within 30 days of purchase in order to receive a refund or credit.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S4	Estimated returns are accrued at the time the sale is recognized and actual returns are tracked monthly.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P24_S5	The Company reviews its history of actual versus estimated returns to ensure reserves are appropriate.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P25_S0	Revenue from product sales includes amounts billed for shipping and handling and is presented net of returns and billed sales tax.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P25_S1	Revenue from shipping and handling charges was $5,763, $5,193 and $5,019 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P25_S2	Shipping-related costs are included in cost of revenue in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P26_S0	Dependence on Suppliers In 2010, approximately 18%, 17% and 10%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from three suppliers.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company has supply arrangements with certain of these vendors that require the Company to make minimum purchases.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P26_S2	In 2009, these vendors supplied approximately 18%, 19% and 8%, respectively, of inventory purchases and in 2008, approximately 15%, 19% and 5%, respectively, of total purchases (see Note 9).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P26_S3	During 2010, the Company outsourced 100% of its fulfillment operations to a third party provider.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P26_S4	During 2009 and 2008, more than 85% of its fulfillment operations was handled by this third party provider.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P27_S0	Vendor Rebates One of the Company s suppliers provides for rebates based on purchasing levels.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P27_S1	The Company accounts for this rebate on an accrual basis as purchases are made at a rebate percent determined based upon the estimated total purchases from the vendor.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P27_S2	The estimated rebate is recorded as a reduction in the carrying value of purchased inventory and is reflected in the consolidated statements of operations when the associated inventory is sold.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P27_S3	A receivable is recorded for the estimate of the rebate earned.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P27_S4	A receivable of $541 and $1,478 at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, has been recorded in receivables in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P28_S0	Historically, the actual rebate received from the vendor has closely matched the estimated rebate recorded.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P28_S1	An adjustment is made to the estimate upon determination of the final rebate.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P29_S0	Marketing Expense Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P29_S1	Media expense was $127,597, $126,117 and $153,577 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P30_S0	Direct-mail advertising costs are capitalized if the primary purpose was to elicit sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the direct mailing and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P30_S1	The capitalized costs are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P30_S2	Typically, this period falls within 40 days of the initial direct mailing.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P30_S3	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred or the first time the advertising takes place.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P30_S4	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, $7,152 and $3,529, respectively, of costs have been prepaid for future advertisements and promotions.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P31_S0	Lease Related Expenses Certain of the Company s lease contracts contain rent holidays, various escalation clauses, or landlord/tenant incentives.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P31_S1	The Company records rental costs, including costs related to fixed rent escalation clauses and rent holidays, on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P32_S0	Lease allowances utilized for space improvement are recorded as leasehold improvement assets and amortized over the shorter of the economic useful life of the asset or the lease term.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P32_S1	Tenant lease incentive allowances received are recorded as deferred rent and amortized as reductions to rent expense over the lease term.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P32_S2	Included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets is $3,991 of a tenant improvement allowance at December 31, 2010, of which $345 is included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities and $3,646 in non-current liabilities.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P33_S0	Income Taxes Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and the respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P33_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P33_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in the consolidated statements of operations in the period that includes the enactment date.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P34_S0	In assessing the ability to realize deferred tax assets, the Company considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P34_S1	A tax benefit from an uncertain tax position may be recognized only if it is more likely than not that the position is sustainable, based on its technical merits.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P34_S2	The tax benefit of a qualifying position is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized upon settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P34_S3	The liability for unrecognized tax benefits is classified as noncurrent unless the liability is expected to be settled in cash within 12 months of the reporting date.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P34_S4	The Company records accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of interest expense.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P35_S0	The Company is managed and operated as one business.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P35_S1	The entire business is managed by a single management team that reports to the chief executive officer.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P35_S2	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P36_S0	The Company uses the two-class method to calculate earnings per share ( EPS ) as the unvested shares issued under the Company s equity incentive plans are participating shares with nonforfeitable rights to dividends.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P36_S1	Under the two-class method, earnings per common share are computed by dividing the sum of distributed earnings to common shareholders and undistributed earnings allocated to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P36_S2	In applying the two-class method, undistributed earnings are allocated to both common shares and participating securities based on the number of weighted average shares outstanding during the period.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P36_S3	The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted EPS:
1096376_11_ITEM15_P37_S0	In 2010, 2009 and 2008, common stock equivalents representing 167,158, 527,891 and 604,545 shares of common stock, respectively, were excluded from weighted average shares outstanding for diluted income per common share purposes because the effect would be anti-dilutive.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P38_S0	The cost of all share-based awards to employees, including grants of employee stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units, is recognized in the financial statements based on the fair value of the awards at grant date.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P38_S1	The fair value of stock option awards is determined using the Black-Scholes valuation model on the date of grant.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P38_S2	The fair value of restricted stock and restricted stock unit awards is equal to the market price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P38_S3	The fair value of share-based awards is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, net of estimated forfeitures.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P38_S4	The Company relies primarily upon historical experience to estimate expected forfeitures and recognizes compensation expense on a straight-line basis from the date of grant.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P39_S0	The Company issues new shares upon exercise of stock options or vesting of restricted stock or restricted stock units.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P39_S1	Cash Flow Information The Company made payments for income taxes of $16,660, $11,449 and $36,784 in 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P39_S2	Interest payments in 2010, 2009 and 2008 were $283, $304 and $352, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P39_S3	During 2010, the Company had non-cash capital additions of $3,991 through a tenant improvement allowance and $1,664 of unpaid invoices in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P40_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and operating expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P40_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
