1096376_11_ITEM15_P42_S0	At December 31, 2009, cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities of continuing operations consisted of the following:
1096376_11_ITEM15_P43_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS A three-tier fair value hierarchy has been established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) to prioritize the inputs used in measuring fair value.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P44_S0	Level 1 Valuations based on quoted prices for identical assets and liabilities in active markets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P44_S1	Level 2 Valuations based on observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active, or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P44_S2	Level 3 Valuations based on unobservable inputs reflecting the Company s own assumptions, consistent with reasonably available assumptions made by other market participants.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P45_S0	The fair values of the Company s cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities are based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P45_S1	The fair values of the Company s derivative instruments are determined using pricing models that take into account contract terms and certain observable current market information such as LIBOR interest rates.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P45_S2	The following table summarizes the Company s financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value at December 31, 2010:
1096376_11_ITEM15_P46_S0	FIXED ASSETS Fixed assets consist of the following: The increase in fixed assets is primarily due to the relocation of our corporate headquarters during 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P46_S1	Additionally, the Company wrote-off fully depreciated assets of approximately $8,100.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P46_S2	Depreciation and amortization expense was $11,773, $11,177 and $8,093 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P47_S0	GOODWILL AND IDENTIFIABLE INTANGIBLE ASSETS On July 1, 2008, the Company acquired certain assets of Power Chow, LLC (d/b/a NuKitchen) ( NuKitchen ), a provider of freshly prepared meals designed to promote weight management and healthy living.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P47_S1	The total purchase price of $5,717 was allocated to identifiable intangible assets ($3,000) and goodwill ($2,717).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P47_S2	As further discussed in Note 12, NuKitchen has been treated as a discontinued operation and the $5,717 purchase price has been included in net cash used in investing activities of discontinued operations in the accompanying consolidated statements of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P48_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2009, a goodwill impairment charge of $2,717 was recorded as a result of the Company conducting its annual impairment test of goodwill.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P48_S1	Additionally, the Company recorded an impairment charge of $1,824 for identifiable intangible assets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P49_S0	The Company used a combination of income and market based approaches to estimate the fair value.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P49_S1	The impairment was initially recorded to depreciation and amortization in the accompanying consolidated statement of operations but has since been classified in discontinued operations (see Note 12).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P49_S2	The impairment charge primarily resulted from management s determination that the resources needed to grow a premium product in a down economy were unsustainable after conducting market tests during the fourth quarter of 2009, particularly with respect to the higher-end consumer segment.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S0	EQUITY INVESTMENT On October 11, 2007, the Company purchased an approximately 27% fully diluted equity interest in Zero Technologies, LLC ( Zero Water ), at a purchase price of $10.60 per Series A unit for an aggregate purchase price of $14,258, which included acquisition costs of $259.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S1	This investment was accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2008, the Company recorded an impairment charge of $6,483 to reduce the carrying value of the equity investment to its then estimated fair value of $4,000.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S3	The impairment charge primarily resulted from lower-than-expected operating results and projections of future performance coupled with the current non-strategic business direction of Zero Water and the overall general economic decline which indicated that the full carrying value of the equity investment was not recoverable.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S4	The charge was recorded as equity and impairment loss in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S5	Also, an equity loss of $2,975 was recorded in 2008 for the Company s share of Zero Water s loss and amortization expense for the difference between the cost and the underlying equity in net assets of Zero Water at the investment date.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S6	In June 2009, the Company abandoned its interest in Zero Water as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with the Company s current strategic direction.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P50_S7	An equity and impairment loss of $4,000 was recorded to write-off the remaining investment.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P51_S0	CREDIT FACILITY AND INTEREST RATE SWAPS On October 2, 2007, the Company executed a credit agreement with a group of lenders that provides for a $200,000 unsecured revolving credit facility with an expansion feature, subject to certain conditions, to increase the facility to $300,000 (the Credit Facility ).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P51_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the Company had $30,000 in borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility at a weighted average interest rate of 1.09%.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P51_S2	No amounts were borrowed during 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P51_S3	During 2008, the Company drew down and repaid the Credit Facility in the amount of $35,000.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P52_S0	The Credit Facility provides for interest at either a floating rate, which will be a base rate, or a Eurocurrency rate equal to the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate ( LIBOR ) for the relevant term, plus an applicable margin.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P52_S1	The base rate will be the higher of the lender s base rate or one-half of one percent above the Federal Funds Rate.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P52_S2	The Credit Facility is also subject to 0.15% per annum unused fee payable quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P52_S3	During 2010, 2009 and 2008, the Company incurred $87, $0 and $49 in interest, respectively, and $294, $304 and $303 in an unused line fee, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P52_S4	Interest payments and unused line fees are classified as interest income, net in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S0	The Credit Facility contains financial and other covenants, including a maximum leverage ratio and minimum interest coverage ratio, and includes limitations on, among other things, liens, certain acquisitions, consolidations and sales of assets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S1	The Company may declare and pay cash dividends up to specified amounts if certain ratios are maintained and no events of default have occurred.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S2	As of December 31, 2010, the Company was in compliance with all covenants contained in the Credit Facility.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S3	At December 31, 2010, the Company had $285 of unamortized debt issuance costs associated with the Credit Facility that are being amortized over the remaining term of the Credit Facility.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S4	The amount of unused Credit Facility at December 31, 2010 was $170,000.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P53_S5	The Credit Facility can be drawn upon through October 2, 2012, at which time all amounts must be repaid.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P54_S0	The Company uses interest rate swaps, a type of derivative financial instrument, to manage interest costs and minimize the effects of interest rate fluctuations on cash flows associated with its variable-rate debt.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P54_S1	The Company does not use interest rate derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P55_S0	While interest rate swaps are subject to fluctuations in value, these fluctuations are generally offset by the value of the underlying exposures being hedged.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S0	The Company minimizes the risk of credit loss by entering into these agreements with financial institutions that have high credit ratings.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S1	In November 2010, the Company entered into two separate $10,000 notional value floating to fixed interest rate swap agreements ( Swaps ) that mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S2	Under the Swaps, the Company receives interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pays a fixed rate of interest of 0.75%, with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S3	The objective of the hedges is to eliminate the variability of cash flows in interest payments for $20,000 of floating rate debt.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S4	The Swaps estimated fair value was $(44) as of December 31, 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P56_S5	The corresponding change in fair value is included in other comprehensive income.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P57_S0	There was no cash flow hedge ineffectiveness recorded during 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P58_S0	The Company leases its corporate headquarters and certain equipment.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P58_S1	These leases generally have initial terms of one to 12 years and have renewal options for additional periods.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P58_S2	Certain of the leases also contain escalation clauses based upon increases in costs related to the properties.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P58_S3	Lease obligations, with initial or remaining terms of one or more years, consist of the following at December 31, 2010: Total rent expense for 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $3,540, $3,269 and $2,732, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P59_S0	Litigation Commencing on October 9, 2007, several putative class action suits were filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania naming Nutrisystem, Inc. and certain of its officers and directors as defendants and alleging violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P59_S1	The complaints purported to bring claims on behalf of a class of persons who purchased the Company s common stock between February 14, 2007 and October 3, 2007 or October 4, 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P60_S0	defendants issued various materially false and misleading statements relating to the Company s projected performance that had the effect of artificially inflating the market price of its securities.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P60_S1	These actions were consolidated in December 2007 under docket number 07-4215, and a consolidated amended complaint was filed on March 7, 2008 that raised the same claims but alleged a class period of February 14, 2007 through February 19, 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P60_S2	The consolidated amended complaint asked the court to (1) certify a class, (2) award compensatory damages, reasonable costs and expenses and (3) grant such other and further relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P60_S3	The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on May 6, 2008 that was granted by the Court on August 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P60_S4	On September 29, 2009, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal, and on May 19, 2010, upon motion by the plaintiff/appellant, the appeal was dismissed with prejudice without costs to either party.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S0	Commencing on October 30, 2007, two shareholder derivative suits were filed in the same Court, which were nominally brought on behalf of Nutrisystem, Inc., and named certain of its officers and directors (including four current directors) as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S1	The complaints alleged violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and asserted claims for breach of fiduciary duty, waste, and unjust enrichment against all defendants and insider selling against certain defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S2	The complaints were based on many of the same allegations as the putative class action suits described above but added contentions regarding the Company s stock buyback program.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S3	The two federal action suits were consolidated under docket number 07-4565, and an amended complaint was filed on March 14, 2008 naming four members of the current Board of Directors and certain current and former officers as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S4	The complaint sought (1) judgment for damages against the individual defendants, (2) declarations that certain defendants were liable for violations of the Exchange Act, (3) an order directing the Company and current director defendants to reform and improve corporate governance, (4) extraordinary equitable and/or injunctive relief, (5) an award of restitution to Nutrisystem from defendants ordering disgorgement of all profits, benefits and other compensation received, (6) an award to the plaintiff for the costs and disbursements of the action and (7) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P61_S5	Defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which the Court granted on October 26, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P62_S0	A shareholder derivative action was also filed in the Common Pleas Court of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, in November 2007.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P62_S1	Like the federal derivative action described above, the state court action was nominally brought on behalf of the Company and named four members of the current Board of Directors as defendants.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P62_S2	The complaint sought (1) a determination that the case was a proper derivative action and plaintiff was an appropriate representative, (2) a declaration that each of defendants breached his or her fiduciary duties to Nutrisystem, (3) an award to Nutrisystem of damages sustained by reason of the violations and exemplary damages, (4) an award to the plaintiffs for costs and disbursements and (5) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P63_S0	On April 30, 2010, the Court sent the plaintiff a notice to terminate pursuant to Pennsylvania s Rules of Civil Procedure for inactive cases.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P63_S1	The plaintiff took no action and, on October 1, 2010, the Court closed this case.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P64_S0	On April 27, 2010, counsel for the same shareholder who commenced the Montgomery County, Pennsylvania litigation described above sent a letter relating to the same events that form the bases of the federal putative class action and derivative suits described above.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P64_S1	Specifically, the shareholder has demanded, pursuant to Delaware Chancery Court Rule 23.1, that the Board of Directors (1) undertake (or cause to be undertaken) an independent internal investigation into violations of Delaware law committed by Company management during the time periods described above and (2) commence a civil action against each member of management to recover for the benefit of the Company the amount of damages sustained by the Company as a result of their breaches of fiduciary duties described above.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P64_S2	The Board of Directors has appointed a special committee consisting of three independent directors to investigate this demand.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P64_S3	The committee has engaged independent legal counsel to assist it in this investigation, and after the investigation is completed, the committee will provide its recommendation to the entire Board of Directors, who will make the final decision with respect to the Company s response to the shareholder s demand.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P64_S4	The Company also received in November 2007 correspondence from an attorney purporting to represent another Nutrisystem shareholder.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P65_S0	litigation committee to investigate unspecified breaches of fiduciary duty.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P65_S1	The disinterested and independent board members met to discuss this issue and responded to the attorney s correspondence.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P66_S0	The complaint sought (1) judgment against all defendants, (2) equitable and/or injunctive relief as permitted by law, equity and the state statutory provisions, (3) restitution to Nutrisystem from the individual defendants, (4) an award to the plaintiffs of the costs and disbursements of the action and (5) such other relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P67_S0	Following receipt of additional correspondence from the same attorney in February 2008, the Board of Directors was considering its response when the shareholder commenced a derivative lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania in the name of the Company against the entire Board of Directors at that time and certain current and former officers.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P67_S1	The parties reached an agreement to stay this matter pending the disposition of the motion to dismiss the federal securities putative class action complaint described above.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P68_S0	On April 30, 2010, the Court sent the plaintiff a notice to terminate pursuant to Pennsylvania s Rules of Civil Procedure for inactive cases.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P68_S1	The plaintiff took no action and, on October 1, 2010, the Court closed this case.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S0	On March 28, 2008, a former Nutrisystem, Inc. sales representative filed a putative collective action complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, docket no. 08-1508, alleging that the Company unlawfully failed to pay him for overtime work in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S1	The complaint purported to bring claims on behalf of a class of current and former sales representatives who had been compensated by the Company pursuant to a commission-based compensation plan, rather than on an hourly basis.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S2	The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on May 28, 2008, adding a state-law class claim under the Pennsylvania Minimum Wage Act, alleging that the Company s compensation plan also violated state law.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S3	The plaintiff sought (1) that the action be certified as a collective action pursuant to Section 216(b) of the Fair Labor Standards Act, (2) that the action be certified as a class action pursuant to Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, (3) actual damages for unpaid overtime, (4) liquidated damages, (5) attorneys fees and costs and (6) pre- and post-judgment interest.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S4	The Court dismissed the state-law class claim on July 25, 2008.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P69_S5	On September 26, 2008, the Court granted plaintiff s motion to proceed as a collective action and to send class members notice under the Fair Labor Standards Act claim.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S0	On October 14, 2008, plaintiff s counsel mailed notice to potential class members.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S1	Including plaintiff, sixty-eight former and current sales representatives opted-in to this litigation.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S2	On July 24, 2009, the Court heard oral argument on the motions for summary judgment that the parties had previously filed, and on July 31, 2009, the Court entered an Order granting the Company s motion for summary judgment and denying plaintiffs cross-motion for summary judgment.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S3	The plaintiffs filed an appeal of the Court s Order, and several employee rights organizations and the U.S. Department of Labor filed amicus curiae briefs in this matter.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S4	On June 21, 2010, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit held oral argument on plaintiffs appeal and on September 7, 2010 affirmed the District Court s grant of summary judgment for the Company.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S5	On October 4, 2010, the Third Circuit denied plaintiffs petition for rehearing by the original Third Circuit panel and a rehearing en banc.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S6	On October 12, 2010, the Third Circuit delivered its certified judgment to the District Court.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P70_S7	On November 15, 2010, the District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Company against all plaintiffs.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P71_S0	The Company is also involved in other various claims and routine litigation matters.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P71_S1	In the opinion of management, after consultation with legal counsel, the outcome of such matters is not anticipated to have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in future years.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P72_S0	The Company has entered into supply agreements with various food vendors.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P72_S1	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing and annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P72_S2	One agreement also provides rebates if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P73_S0	During 2010, a new pricing and food purchase agreement with a food supplier was executed which requires advance payments to the supplier.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P73_S1	Advances through December 31, 2010 were $15,240.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P73_S2	The Company anticipates it will meet all annual purchase obligations.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P74_S24	The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depends on a variety of factors including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other market conditions.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P76_S0	Preferred Stock The Company has authorized 5,000,000 shares of preferred stock issuable in series upon resolution of the Board of Directors.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P76_S1	Unless otherwise required by law, the Board of Directors can, without stockholder approval, issue preferred stock in the future with voting and conversion rights that could adversely affect the voting power of the common stock.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P77_S0	The issuance of preferred stock may have the effect of delaying, averting or preventing a change in control of the Company.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P79_S0	A reconciliation of the statutory federal income tax rate to the Company s effective tax rate is as follows: The Company recognized an decrease/(increase) in taxes payable of $418, ($450) and $2,581 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, from the exercise of certain stock options and restricted stock and payment of certain dividends and recorded these amounts as decreases and increases to APIC in the accompanying consolidated statements of stockholders equity.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P80_S0	The significant items comprising the Company s deferred income tax assets and liabilities are as follows: At December 31, 2010, the net deferred tax asset of $2,655 is comprised of $1,854 included in current assets and $801 included in other assets in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P80_S1	At December 31, 2009, the net deferred tax asset of $7,337 is comprised of $2,756 included in current assets and $4,581 included in other assets in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P80_S2	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, the Company had net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $13,716 and $10,163, respectively, for state tax purposes.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P80_S3	The increase is primarily due to the closing of NuKitchen.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P81_S0	For state tax purposes, there is a limitation on the amount of net operating loss carryforwards that can be utilized in a given year to offset state taxable income.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P81_S1	Net operating losses will begin to expire in 2020.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P81_S2	Based on the projected level of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the net deferred tax assets.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S0	In 2008, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of $3,749 related to its impairment of its investment in Zero Water since the character of the deduction could be a capital item and there was no history of generating capital gains.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S1	In 2009, the Company abandoned its investment in Zero Water (see Note 7) which provided the Company with a current year income tax deduction for its entire original $14,258 tax basis investment in Zero Water.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S2	This reduced 2009 federal income tax payments by approximately $4,990.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S3	This reduction in ordinary income tax payments resulted in a similar decrease in income tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2009 including a reversal of a $3,749 valuation allowance established in 2008 for deferred tax assets related to prior Zero Water losses and impairment charges.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S4	These Zero Water losses and impairment charges were considered realizable during the year ended December 31, 2009 due to the terms of the abandonment which changed the tax loss from capital to ordinary which the Company believes is more likely than not to realize.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S5	The total amount of gross unrecognized tax benefits as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 was $2,478 and $1,375, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S6	The total amount of unrecognized tax benefits that, if recognized, would affect the effective income tax rate is approximately $1,611 and $893, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S7	The Company records accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of interest expense.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S8	During 2010, 2009 and 2008, the Company recognized $99, $70 and $61, respectively, in interest and penalties.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S9	The Company s federal income tax returns for 2007 through 2010 are open and are subject to examination by the Internal Revenue Service.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S10	State tax jurisdictions that remain open to examination range from 2000 through 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P82_S11	The Company does not believe that that there will be any material changes to unrecognized tax positions over the next 12 months.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P84_S0	DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS In the fourth quarter of 2007, the Company committed to a plan to sell its subsidiary, Slim and Tone, and this subsidiary has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P84_S1	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P84_S2	The plan to sell was not completed and operations ceased as of December 31, 2009.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P84_S3	Slim and Tone had revenues of $65 and $277 and pre-tax losses of $390 and $276 for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P85_S0	In the first quarter of 2010, the Company committed to a plan to sell the business operations conducted by NuKitchen, as it was no longer aligned with the business direction of the Company.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P85_S1	The Company was unsuccessful in locating a buyer for the NuKitchen business and, therefore, it closed the business during the three months ended September 30, 2010.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P85_S2	NuKitchen has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P85_S3	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P86_S0	NuKitchen had revenues of $1,707, $3,113 and $1,560 and pre-tax losses of $808, $6,091 (including impairment charge) and $1,205 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S0	Equity Incentive Plans The Company has three equity incentive plans: the 1999 Equity Incentive Plan, the 2000 Equity Incentive Plan and the 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan (collectively, the Equity Incentive Plans ).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S1	Under these plans, a variety of equity instruments can be granted to key employees including incentive and nonqualified stock options to purchase shares of the Company s common stock, restricted stock or shares of common stock.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S2	The 1999 Equity Incentive Plan, the 2000 Equity Incentive Plan and the 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan authorize up to 1,000,000, 5,600,000 and 2,700,000 shares of common stock, respectively, for issuance.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S3	At December 31, 2010, options to purchase 936,811 shares were available for grant under these plans.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S4	Under each of the plans, the Board of Directors determines the term of each award, but no award can be exercisable more than 10 years from the date the award is granted.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S5	To date, all of the awards issued under the Equity Incentive Plans expire 10 years from the grant date.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S6	The Board also determines the vesting provisions and the exercise price per share, which is the fair market value at date of grant.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P87_S7	Awards issued to employees generally vest over terms ranging from three to five years.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P92_S0	Additionally, the Company grants restricted stock units.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P92_S2	The performance-based units will be settled in stock upon the Company s achievement of specific performance goals over a specified performance period and vest over three years.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P92_S3	The level of achievement of such goals may cause the actual amount of units that ultimately vest to range from 0% to 200% of the original units granted.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S0	The Company maintains a qualified tax deferred defined contribution retirement plan (the Plan ).
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S1	Under the provisions of the Plan, substantially all employees meeting minimum age and service requirements are entitled to contribute on a before and after-tax basis a certain percentage of their compensation.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S2	The Company matched 100% of employees first 3% contribution and 50% of the employees next 2% contribution.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S3	Effective June 1, 2009, the Company elected to suspend its matching contribution.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S4	Effective April 1, 2010, the Company reinstated their matching contribution of 100% of employees first 3% contribution and 50% of the employees next 2% contribution.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S5	Employees vest immediately in their contributions and the Company s contribution.
1096376_11_ITEM15_P96_S6	The Company s contributions in 2010, 2009 and 2008 were $528, $452 and $1,055, respectively.

1096376_11_ITEM15_P158_S0	Exhibit 32.1 Statement of Chief Executive Officer Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the undersigned, Joseph M. 1096376_11_ITEM15_P160_S0	Exhibit 32.2 Statement of Chief Financial Officer Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the undersigned, David D. Clark, the Chief Financial Officer of Nutrisystem, Inc. (the Company ), hereby certifies that based on the undersigned s knowledge:
1096376_11_ITEM15_P161_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	Overview Nutrisystem, Inc. (together with its consolidated subsidiaries, Nutrisystem, the Company, we, us, or our ) is a leading provider of a weight management system based on a low-calorie, portion-controlled, prepared meal program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages containing a 28-day supply of breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	Most of our customers order on an auto-delivery basis ( Auto-Delivery ), in which we send a month s food supply on an ongoing basis until notified by the customer to stop our shipments.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our food for the Core program is shelf-stable at room temperature and will last for up to two years, making it relatively inexpensive to ship and store.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S4	We have also expanded our product offerings to include a combination of our ready-to-go food and our fresh-frozen line of menu items.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P0_S5	This Select program is priced higher than the Core program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our program is based on the following cornerstones that represent who we are to our customers: Results.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	We believe our program enables our customers to lose weight successfully.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Nutrisystem program is based on 40 years of nutrition research and the science of the low Glycemic Index, and offers over 130 portion-controlled items that include relatively higher amounts of fiber, contain good carbohydrates and zero trans fats.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	Foods on the lower end of the Glycemic Index are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P3_S2	We also offer transition and maintenance plans, which include support tools and desired meal occasions that customers wish to continue to receive from Nutrisystem.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P3_S3	These plans are designed to help our customers keep the weight off.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	We sell our weight management program primarily through a direct-to-consumer sales and distribution approach using the Internet and telephone.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our customers can order 24 hours a day, seven days a week on our website, www.nutrisystem.com , and the food is shipped directly to the customer s door.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S2	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting of a pre-packaged food program and counseling.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S3	Our customers can either choose our pre-selected favorites food package or customize their monthly food orders for their specific tastes.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our program does not require customers to visit centers, measure foods or count calories.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P4_S5	The entrees are individually packaged and food preparation time is minimal.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	We do not charge membership fees.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	Additionally, we advertise various promotional offers and pricing throughout the year.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	The direct-to-consumer approach using the Internet and telephone provides the privacy that our customers value.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	We provide online and telephone counseling and support to our customers using our trained weight loss coaches, diet counselors and other nutrition and dietary staff, and thus, our customers do not need to travel for a face-to-face meeting.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S2	Competitive Strengths We believe our program offers consumers a sensible approach to losing weight without the use of faddish, unhealthy or unrealistic weight loss methods.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S3	We intend to capitalize on the following competitive strengths to grow: Product Efficacy .
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S4	We believe most of our customers are very satisfied with our products and believe they have lost weight while using our program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S5	Our customer surveys found that customers lost an average of 1.0 to 2.0 pounds per week and tended to stay on the program for 11 to 12 weeks.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P6_S6	We believe these surveys indicate overall satisfaction with our program and a potential willingness to refer our program to others.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	We have also sponsored clinical trials at leading academic centers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	The first two trials to report results were in patients with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P7_S2	Statistically significant and clinically meaningful weight loss and improvements in glycemic control were observed in both trials, in addition to improvements in secondary endpoints such as waist circumference, total plasma cholesterol and blood pressure.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P7_S3	The second trial also examined medication use and found that the health benefits were achieved while medication use was decreased in approximately 30% of the subjects on our Nutrisystem D Program, which has been specifically designed to produce gradual weight loss in overweight patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	We believe that our brand is well recognized in the weight management industry.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our company and our predecessors have been in the weight management industry for 40 years, and we estimate that our company and our predecessors have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising over that time period.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	Low Cost, Highly Scalable Model .
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	Unlike traditional commercial weight loss programs, which primarily sell through franchisee and company-owned centers, we generate revenue in our direct channel through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards).
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our method of distribution removes the fixed costs and capital investment associated with diet centers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S2	We also minimize fixed costs and capital investments in food procurement and fulfillment: we outsource the production of our food products to a number of vendors and we currently outsource 100% of our fulfillment operations to a third party provider.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S3	Our goal is to offer our customers a complete weight management program that is convenient, private and cost-effective.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S4	Our customers place their orders through the Internet or over the telephone and have their food delivered directly to their homes.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S5	This affords our customers the convenience and anonymity that other diets which rely on weight-loss centers cannot ensure.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S6	Additionally, we provide our customers with a month of food, including daily breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert, which removes the confusion of reading nutrition labels, measuring portions or counting calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S7	We believe our weight management program offers our customers significant value and is priced below those of our competitors.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P10_S8	In addition, we do not charge a membership fee, whereas many of our competitors do.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our Industry Weight management is a challenge for a significant portion of the U.S., as well as the global population.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	The 2009-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Study estimated that over 78 million U.S. adults were obese in 2009-2010 and the World Health Organization projects that by 2015, 2.3 billion people will be overweight and 700 million of these will be obese.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, overweight and obese individuals are increasingly at risk for diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, certain types of cancer, stroke, arthritis, sleep apnea and depression.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	However, there is evidence that weight loss may reduce the risk of developing these conditions, as well as improve the health and quality of life of people who have these conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P12_S3	Our clinical trial results and analyses of real world customer results confirm that people who stay on the Nutrisystem program for at least three months have a very high probability of achieving clinically meaningful weight loss.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	In addition to the health risks, there are also cultural implications for those who are overweight or obese.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	U.S. consumers are inundated with imagery in media, fashion and entertainment that depicts the thin body as the ideal body type.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	Studies suggest that there is rampant discrimination against the obese.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	Despite the high percentage of overweight and obese individuals in the U.S., the popularity of dieting appears to indicate consumers desire to be thin.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	The weight loss market is served by a diverse array of competitors.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	Potential customers seeking to manage their weight can turn to traditional center-based competitors, online diet-oriented sites, self-directed dieting and self-administered products such as the over-the-counter drugs and other medically supervised programs.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	We believe that the principal competitive factors in the weight loss market are:
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	the ability to attract and retain customers through promotion and personal referral.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	Based on these factors, we believe that we can compete effectively in the weight management industry.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	We, however, have no control over how successful competitors will be in addressing these factors.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S3	By providing a well-recognized food-based program using the direct channel, we believe that we have a competitive advantage in our market.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S4	Our Products and Services For 40 years, the Nutrisystem name has been recognized as a leader in the weight loss industry.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S5	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting primarily of a pre-packaged food program, online tools and counseling.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P17_S6	Trained counselors are available to answer questions and make recommendations to help each customer achieve and maintain his or her weight loss goal.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	Customers support and encourage each other and share information through hosted Internet chat rooms and bulletin boards.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P18_S1	These services are complemented with relevant information on diet, nutrition and exercise, which is provided on our community website and emailed to our customers bi-weekly.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P18_S2	Additionally, online and smart phone weight management tools are available to our customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P18_S3	These tools include the interactive Mindset Makeover guide, a behavior modification program that was co-authored by an international leader in the field of obesity research and is offered to our customers free of charge.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P18_S4	This insightful and motivational guide walks clients through the program and can serve as an interactive tool for our counselors to use to facilitate communication and enhance weight loss success for our clients.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	Our Nutrisystem program consists of over 130 portion-controlled items that serve as the foundation of a low Glycemic Index diet.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods and foods on the lower end of the index are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S1	Our program is portioned for weight loss and offers a balance of carbohydrate, protein and fat that meets national dietary guidelines.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S2	We have also worked to reduce the sodium content of our meal program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S3	Including grocery additions, our plans contain 1800-2200 milligrams of sodium per day, consistent with national guidelines, and tailored versions of the plans are available that deliver as low as 1500 mg/day.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S4	In contrast, the average American consumes 2800-4000 milligrams of sodium per day.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S5	We constantly strive to meet or exceed nutritional guidelines as they are updated.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S6	In December 2011, we launched SUCCESS, our most comprehensive program to date.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S7	It is designed to help take the weight off and keep it off through frequent, portion-controlled, balanced nutrition and low Glycemic Index eating.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P20_S8	The SUCCESS program offers our largest ever assortment of signature fresh-frozen meals including new artisanal Chef s Table dinner entrees, developed by Nutrisystem s Celebrity Chef Culinary Council using revolutionary advanced steamer technology; new chocolate, vanilla, strawberry and coffee advanced protein shakes; the introduction of a personalized My Daily 3 physical activity program; and increased personalization and flexibility through transition and maintenance plans that help consumers manage their weight on their own.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P21_S0	Nutrisystem Select includes fresh-frozen foods and enhances Nutrisystem s tradition of effective weight loss and weight management.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	Most of our weight plans offer these fresh-frozen foods.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P21_S2	The program provides customers with premium fresh-frozen foods that complement Nutrisystem s prepared food weight loss programs and still adheres to Nutrisystem s nutritional guidelines.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P22_S0	When a customer orders Nutrisystem Select, two separate shipments are delivered.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P22_S1	The first shipment will be sent directly to the customer and will contain Nutrisystem s standard shelf-stable food.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P22_S2	The second shipment will contain the fresh-frozen foods and will also be delivered directly to the customer s home.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S0	The Nutrisystem D Program is a weight loss program specifically designed to produce gradual weight loss in overweight patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S1	Results from a 2009 clinical study conducted at the Temple University School of Medicine and published in the journal Postgraduate Medicine show that the Nutrisystem D Program in combination with weekly counseling sessions helped overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes lose more weight and experience greater reductions in their A1C levels (a key measure of blood glucose control) as compared to those in the control group.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S2	This weight loss was also associated with reductions in blood pressure, cholesterol and waist circumference.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S3	A follow up study at the University of Pennsylvania and Temple University School of Medicine was completed in July 2011 and initial findings were presented at the Obesity Society s annual conference in October 2011, confirming and extending the key findings of the first diabetes trial.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S4	A third trial in type 2 diabetes is ongoing.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S5	Multiple trials involving the other Nutrisystem programs are recently completed or ongoing.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S6	In addition, several abstracts analyzing real world results from customers were accepted to medical conferences in 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P23_S7	We continue to offer our program at Costco through the use of prepaid program cards and gift cards.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P24_S0	The Nutrisystem program has also been offered at other large retailers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P24_S1	Each retailer is offered a unique promotional package and pricing through the use of prepaid program cards.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P24_S2	We have discontinued offering our program at underperforming retailers, but we continually explore other major retailers where we may potentially offer our program in the future.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P25_S0	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages of shelf-stable and fresh-frozen food containing 28 days of breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P25_S1	In certain instances, depending on the promotional offers available, customers can receive more than the typical 28 days of food.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S0	Most customers order through our Auto-Delivery feature.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S1	By offering a variety of shelf-stable and fresh-frozen foods, we help our customers sustain their weight loss efforts.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S2	On our website, customers can order food 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S3	The transition and maintenance plans included in the SUCCESS launch, along with the previously developed Flex program, allow customers the means to gradually increase their responsibility for grocery shopping and food preparation while adhering to the principles of the Nutrisystem approach.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S4	These lower cost programs help extend the supportive relationship and allow time to reinforce the dietary changes that produced the initial weight loss.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P26_S5	These plans include recipes and portion-control tools in addition to a reduced number of Nutrisystem entrees delivered each month.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S0	The features of our weight loss program address many of the most common limitations of traditional weight loss programs, including high initiation and recurring membership fees, the inconvenience of traveling to weight loss centers for scheduled appointments and lack of privacy.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S1	In addition, our prepared meals provide our customers with a structured program with limited weighing and measuring of foods, and no need to count calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S2	We believe that the convenience of home delivery, reduced grocery shopping time, and rapid food preparation also aid customer compliance with our weight loss program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S3	Our food items have accounted for 99% of our revenues for each of the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S4	No other product or service has accounted for more than 1% of consolidated revenue in any of the last three years.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P27_S5	Approximately 99% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2011 were generated in the United States as compared to approximately 98% of our revenues for both of the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S0	Marketing Marketing is a core competency that drives sales and builds the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S1	We have strong expertise in all facets of both offline and online marketing and utilize an integrated marketing process designed to drive profitable revenue in an efficient, effective way.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S2	We believe Nutrisystem is one of the leading and most efficient offline direct response advertisers in the industry.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S3	We deploy a hybrid of proven direct response techniques to: 1) build brand equity and awareness; 2) encourage qualified customers to call or visit our website; and 3) deliver profitable sales.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S4	We track response to each advertisement through unique toll-free numbers and URLs and we deploy multi-channel campaigns to target new customers that include television, print, direct mail and telemarketing efforts.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P28_S5	To reactivate lapsed customers and upsell to those already on our program, we utilize a combination of direct mail and telemarketing efforts which complements our other media advertising.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our online marketing strategy focuses on driving high-volume, cost-effective, qualified leads to our website with an emphasis on increasing both front-end and back-end conversion through constant testing and optimization.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P29_S1	We are continually exploring new online opportunities as the market evolves, but focus the majority of our efforts on search optimization (paid and natural), affiliate management, portal relationships, large ad networks, strategic partnerships, targeted display media and internal/external email campaigns.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P30_S0	The consumer and business media outreach programs accentuate Nutrisystem as a leader and innovator in the weight loss category.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P30_S1	Our public relations strategically complement offline and online marketing to increase top-of-mind awareness for Nutrisystem, as well as to foster positive word-of-mouth, in order to enhance purchase consideration of our product.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P30_S2	News, Entertainment Tonight and Forbes.com .
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S0	We typically compensate our celebrity spokespersons based on their initial weight loss on our program and maintenance of the weight loss over time.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S1	We are continuing to strive to drive much stronger public relations and social media participation and engagement through blogs, forums, Facebook and Twitter .
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S2	As a leading ecommerce company and brand, we constantly strive to employ the latest tools and technology in order to drive increased performance of online customer conversion, retention and reactivation.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S3	We utilize our ecommerce platform to drive a highly-customizable and personalized user experience, as well as to effectively and efficiently manage day-to-day ecommerce business operations.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S4	In addition, we combine internal resources with external agencies in the development of our website information architecture, user interface and user experience.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S5	In order to optimize the key online business drivers, we continually perform usability testing and are constantly optimizing our website using a variety of sophisticated third party testing tools.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P31_S6	Finally, we measure our online interaction with customers, along with broader website performance, via web analytics platforms and tools.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P32_S0	Sales and Counseling A majority of our direct business sales occur on our website.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P32_S1	The remaining sales are by telephone, and our call center processes all of them.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our weight loss program is also sold through QVC, a television home shopping network, which represented 4% of our revenue in 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P32_S3	As of December 31, 2011 we employed approximately 73 weight loss counselors and 199 sales agents.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P32_S4	Staffing levels for counselors and sales agents are largely a function of the volume of revenue and orders.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S0	Additionally, certain sales agents assist in retaining customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S1	Counselors initiate some out-bound sales calls but primarily focus on in-bound calls and email.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S2	Counselors also handle online web conversations from new visitors and appointments with existing customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S3	Sales agents are paid primarily on commission while counselors receive an hourly wage.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S4	We seek to hire counselors with backgrounds in psychology, sociology, nutrition, dietetics or other health-related fields and with suitable temperaments to speak with our customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S5	Counselors are trained in our program, our Internet chat service, email, motivational techniques and customer service problem solving.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S6	Sales agents are well-versed in explaining our program and working with our customers to determine the program that would best fit their needs in helping them reach their weight loss goals.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S7	Customer Service As of December 31, 2011, we employed approximately 90 customer service representatives.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S8	Customer service representatives are trained to handle in-bound calls and emails from customers who have questions or problems with an order after the sale transaction is completed.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S9	Typical customer inquiries relate to the arrival date of the customer s order shipment, reporting of missing or damaged items and credits and exchanges.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P33_S10	For email inquiries, we have a software system that scans the customer s email message for key words and automatically supplies the representative with a form response that is reviewed, edited and sent back to the customer.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P34_S0	Customer service representatives are paid an hourly wage.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S0	Fulfillment An integrated order receipt, billing, picking, shipping and delivery tracking system comprised of proprietary and third party components is utilized for our orders.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S1	This system integrates the front end, or website customer interface, with order processing and shipping, and allows Internet customers to access shippers order tracking numbers online.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S2	Our computer-assisted picking system allows for virtually paperless order picking in all warehouse facilities.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S3	We utilize an integrated network of distribution facilities through an existing arrangement with our outside fulfillment provider.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S4	In recent years, we have embarked on several key initiatives within our supply chain, including the installation of new material handling equipment and a new warehouse management system.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S5	These initiatives resulted in realized cost improvements, enhanced vendor productivity and warehouse efficiencies, and they helped increase key metrics supporting customer satisfaction.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S6	In addition, these initiatives resulted in improved inventory management and allowed us to reduce our overall warehouse footprint.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S7	We currently utilize four outsourced distribution facilities located in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania, Allentown, Pennsylvania and two in Sparks, Nevada.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S8	Additionally, we had an agreement, which expired in November 2011, with a provider of fine frozen foods, for the development and distribution of frozen foods under the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S9	We have found other frozen food supply options to replace this supplier.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S10	During 2011, 100% of our fulfillment was handled by two outsourced providers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S11	As of December 31, 2011, all fulfillment was being handled by one outsourced provider.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S12	We have a service agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, which provides for storage, handling of fresh-frozen and ready-to-go foods and other services, including pricing and minimum space commitments.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P35_S13	The current contract expires on December 17, 2014, but may be terminated sooner upon 180 days written notice.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P36_S0	We believe that other outside fulfillment providers could be utilized if needed and we continually evaluate the need for secondary fulfillment services.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P36_S1	We continue to partner with our fulfillment provider to reduce the warehouse order turn-around time for processing and shipping orders.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P36_S2	In 2011, approximately 99% of all direct customer initial orders were shipped within two business days of the date the order was received.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P36_S3	In addition, we can ship to approximately 99% of the domestic population within five business days using standard ground transportation.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P36_S4	In 2011, we made capital investments in new material handling equipment to target improvements in productivity, cost, quality and service.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P37_S0	Direct customers are not charged for their orders until the ordered product is shipped.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P37_S1	We do not charge customers for shipping and handling on Auto-Delivery food orders provided customers take receipt of their second order.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P37_S2	If a customer cancels before receipt of a second order, the customer will be charged for shipping and the difference in pricing for an Auto-Delivery order versus a non Auto-Delivery order.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S0	All of our foods and supplements are currently outsourced from more than 30 manufacturers or vendors.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S1	We have entered into supply agreements with some of these food vendors.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S2	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S3	One agreement also provides for certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S4	All of these contracts may be terminated by us upon written notice, generally between 30 and 180 days.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S5	We anticipate meeting all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S6	In 2011, approximately 16% and 15%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S7	We have a supply arrangement with one of these vendors that requires us to make certain minimum purchases.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S8	In 2010, these vendors supplied 17% and 18%, respectively, of total purchases and in 2009 these vendors supplied 19% and 18%, respectively, of total purchases.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S9	Additionally, we were dependent on one frozen food supplier for less than 20% of our food costs in 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S10	The amount provided from this supplier in 2010 was negligible.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P38_S11	We had a supply agreement with this supplier that expired in November 2011 and we have found other frozen food supply options to replace this supplier.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our product development team uses a number of sources customer feedback, market trends, nutrition science, and breakthroughs in food technology to create new ideas for our program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P39_S1	New foods are created to enhance the variety of our current offerings or to support the efforts of creating a new program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P39_S2	Typically, concepts are formulated in the test kitchen to meet our stringent demands for nutrition and stability.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P39_S3	We then contract with food manufacturers who further develop viable new products based on our specifications.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P39_S4	Regardless of a given food item s pathway through development, that food is evaluated for nutrition, compliance with our program, taste (using testing panels), and cost considerations.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P40_S0	The number of stock keeping units, or SKUs, we introduce each year varies depending on whether we are introducing a new program or simply updating an existing one.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our Customers We offer weight loss programs designed for women, men, seniors as well as people with type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P41_S1	Based on our customer data, our typical customer is female, approximately 50 years of age and weighs approximately 187 pounds.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P41_S2	We believe that, on average, our customers want to lose approximately 43 pounds over a period of time.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P41_S3	Based on our customer surveys, we believe our typical customers tend to stay on our program for 11 to 12 weeks, lose 1.0 to 2.0 pounds per week and have tried other popular diet programs.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P41_S4	We believe that these surveys indicate a willingness to refer our program to others and that our customers value the following Nutrisystem program attributes:
1096376_12_ITEM1_P42_S0	they do not feel hungry while on the program.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our ecommerce and community websites, both of which are based primarily on third party software customized to meet our business needs, are each hosted in a top tier, co-location facility.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S1	These facilities provide redundant network connections, physical and fire security and diesel generated power back up for the equipment upon which our websites rely and are intended to provide an uninterruptible power supply.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S2	Our servers and our network are monitored 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S3	We use a variety of security techniques to protect our confidential customer data.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S4	When our customers place an order or access their account information, we secure that transaction by using some of the best available encryption technologies, including secure sockets layer, or SSL.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S5	Our customer data is protected against unauthorized access by security measures and we engage a variety of industry leading technology providers including VeriSign, CyberSource and SecureWorks to further ensure the security of our credit card transactions and the safety of our customers personal information.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P43_S6	We own numerous domestic and international trademarks and other proprietary rights that are important to our business.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P44_S0	Depending upon the jurisdiction, trademarks are valid as long as they are used in the regular course of trade and/or their registrations are properly maintained.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P45_S0	We believe the protection of our trademarks, copyrights, patents, domain names, trade dress, and trade secrets is important to our success.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P45_S1	We aggressively protect our intellectual property rights by relying on a combination of watch services and trademark, copyright, patent, trade dress and trade secret laws, and through the domain name dispute resolution system.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P46_S0	Employees As of December 31, 2011, we had approximately 455 administrative, sales, counseling and customer service personnel, 19 employees dedicated to fulfillment and 37 employees in marketing.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P46_S1	None of our employees are represented by a labor union, and we consider relations with our employees to be good.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P47_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is strongest in the first quarter and lowest in the fourth calendar quarter.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P48_S0	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven primarily by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet at certain times of the year and the placement of our advertising is based on the price and availability of certain media at such times.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S0	Available Information All periodic and current reports, registration statements, code of conduct and other material that the Company is required to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), including the Company s annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the 1934 Act Reports ), are available free of charge through the Company s investor relations page at www.nutrisystem.com .
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S1	Such documents are available as soon as reasonably practicable after electronic filing of the material with the SEC.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S2	The Company s Internet website and the information contained therein or connected thereto are not intended to be incorporated into this Annual Report.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S3	The public may also read and copy any materials filed by the Company with the SEC at the SEC s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S4	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P49_S5	The SEC maintains an Internet site, www.sec.gov , which contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file such information electronically with the SEC.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P50_S0	Executive Officers of the Company The Company s executive officers and their respective ages and positions as of December 31, 2011 are as follows:
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S0	Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer Joseph M. Redling has served as our President and Chief Operating Officer since September 2007, as our Chief Executive Officer since May 2008 and as member of our Board since April 2008.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S1	In November 2008, Mr. Redling became Chairman of our Board.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S2	Before joining us, Mr. Redling held a number of executive positions at AOL, Inc., a global web services company, including Chief Marketing Officer, President of AOL Access, President of AOL Paid Services and Customer Management and Chief Executive Officer of AOL International from September 2001 through March 2007.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S3	David D. Clark has served as our Chief Financial Officer since November 2007 and in July 2008, the Board promoted Mr. Clark from the position of Senior Vice President, which he had held since November 2007, to Executive Vice President.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S4	Prior to joining us, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of Claymont Steel Holdings, Inc., a manufacturer of steel plate, from November 2006 through October 2007.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S5	Prior to that, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of SunCom Wireless Holdings, a publicly traded provider of digital wireless communications services, from its founding in 1997 through February 2006 and held the additional position of Executive Vice President from 2000 through February 2006 and Senior Vice President from 1997 through 2000.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S6	Michael R. Amburgey has served as our Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer since October 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S7	Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Amburgey had been Head of Marketing at Healthways, Inc. during September 2011, and he served as Senior Vice President Consumer Marketing at Schneider Electric from May 2011 to August 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S8	Concurrently, Mr. Amburgey was Partner at Chief Outsiders, a strategic consulting firm that provides chief marketing services, from December 2010 to October 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM1_P51_S9	Previously, Mr. Amburgey was Chief Marketing Officer at Oreck Corporation from September 2008 to October 2010 and served as Vice President of Marketing and Direct Response Sales at Oreck Corporation from September 2007 to September 2008.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	and operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	You should understand that it is not possible to predict or identify all such risks and uncertainties.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Consequently, you should not consider the following to be a complete discussion of all potential risks or uncertainties.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Risks Related to Our Business Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures and our ability to select effective markets and media in which to advertise.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our marketing expenditures were $110.9 million, $145.9 million and $146.4 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures, including our ability to:
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	convert consumer inquiries into actual orders.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our planned marketing expenditures may not result in increased revenue or generate sufficient levels of brand name and program awareness.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	We may not be able to manage our marketing expenditures on a cost-effective basis whereby our customer acquisition costs may exceed the contribution profit generated from each additional customer.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Our sales may be adversely impacted by the health and stability of the general economy.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, such as a recession or prolonged economic slowdown, may reduce the demand for our products and otherwise adversely affect our sales.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S5	For example, economic forces, including general economic conditions, demographic trends, consumer confidence in the economy, changes in disposable consumer income and/or reductions in discretionary spending, may cause consumers to defer purchases of our program which could adversely affect our revenue, gross margins, and/or our overall financial condition and operating results.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S6	We rely on third parties to provide us with adequate food supply and certain fulfillment, Internet, networking and call center services, the loss of any of which could cause our revenue, earnings or reputation to suffer.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S7	We rely solely on third party manufacturers to supply all of the food and other products we sell.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P2_S8	In 2011, approximately 16% and 15%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	If we are unable to obtain sufficient quantity, quality and variety of food and other products in a timely and low-cost manner from our manufacturers, we will be unable to fulfill our customers orders in a timely manner, which may cause us to lose revenue and market share or incur higher costs, as well as damage the value of the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In 2011, more than 90% of our orders were shipped by one third party provider and 100% of our order fulfillment was handled by our third party providers.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Should these providers be unable to service our needs for even a short duration, our revenue and business could be harmed.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Additionally, the cost and time associated with replacing these providers on short notice would add to our costs.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Any replacement fulfillment provider would also require startup time, which could cause us to lose sales and market share.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Internet, Networking and Call Center .
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Our business also depends on a number of third parties for Internet access, networking and call center services, and we have limited control over these third parties.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Should our network connections go down, our ability to fulfill orders would be delayed.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Further, if our website or call center become unavailable for a noticeable period of time due to Internet or communication failures, our business could be adversely affected, including harm to our brand and loss of sales.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S4	Therefore, we are dependent on maintaining good relationships with these third parties.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P5_S5	The services we require from these parties may be disrupted by a number of factors associated with their businesses, including the following:
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	with respect to our food suppliers, shortages of ingredients or United States Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) or United States Food and Drug Administration ( FDA ) compliance issues.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We may be subject to claims that our personnel are unqualified to provide proper weight loss advice.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Some of our counselors for our weight management program do not have extensive training or certification in nutrition, diet or health fields and have only undergone the training they receive from us.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	We may be subject to claims from our customers alleging that our personnel lack the qualifications necessary to provide proper advice regarding weight loss and related topics.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	We may also be subject to claims that our personnel have provided inappropriate advice or have inappropriately referred or failed to refer customers to health care providers for matters other than weight loss.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Such claims could result in lawsuits, damage to our reputation and divert management s attention from our business, which would adversely affect our business.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S6	We may be subject to health or advertising related claims from our customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S7	Our weight loss program does not include medical treatment or medical advice, and we do not engage physicians or nurses to monitor the progress of our customers.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Many people who are overweight suffer from other physical conditions, and our target consumers could be considered a high-risk population.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S9	A customer who experiences health problems could allege or bring a lawsuit against us on the basis that those problems were caused or worsened by participating in our weight management program.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S10	For example, our predecessor businesses suffered substantial losses due to health-related claims and related publicity.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S11	Further, customers who allege that they were deceived by any statements that we made in advertising or labeling could bring a lawsuit against us under consumer protection laws.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S12	Currently, we are neither subject to any such allegations nor have we been named in any such litigation.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S13	If we were subject to any such claims, while we would defend ourselves against such claims, we may ultimately be unsuccessful in our defense.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S14	Also, defending ourselves against such claims, regardless of their merit and ultimate outcome, would likely be lengthy and costly, and adversely affect our results of operations.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P6_S15	Further, our general liability insurance may not cover claims of these types.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The weight management industry is highly competitive.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	If any of our competitors or a new entrant into the market with significant resources pursues a weight management program similar to ours, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Competition is intense in the weight management industry and we must remain competitive in the areas of program efficacy, price, taste, customer service and brand recognition.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Our competitors include companies selling pharmaceutical products and weight loss programs, as well as a wide variety of diet foods and meal replacement bars and shakes, appetite suppressants and nutritional supplements.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S4	Some of our competitors are significantly larger than we are and have substantially greater resources.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S5	Our business could be adversely affected if someone with significant resources decided to imitate our weight management program.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S6	For example, if a major supplier of pre-packaged foods decided to enter this market and made a substantial investment of resources in advertising and training diet counselors, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P7_S7	Any increased competition from new entrants into our industry or any increased success by existing competition could result in reductions in our sales or prices, or both, which could have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We are dependent on certain third party agreements for a percentage of revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We have contractual agreements with certain third party retailers.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Under the agreements, these third parties control when and how often our products and services are offered and we are not guaranteed any minimum level of sales or transactions.
1096376_12_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Additionally, some agreements contain exclusive rights in specified locations to promote our products during the contract term and for a specified period thereafter.
