1096376_12_ITEM5_P2_S0	Recent Sales of Unregistered Securities On October 14, 2011, we issued 117,188 shares of common stock to Black Doll, Inc. in consideration for marketing services.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P2_S1	In granting the shares, we relied upon the exemption from registration set forth in Section 4(2) of the Securities Act of 1933.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P3_S0	The following table provides information relating to our purchases of our common stock during the quarter ended December 31, 2011:
1096376_12_ITEM5_P4_S0	(1) On July 28, 2011, we announced that our Board of Directors had authorized the repurchase of up to $150.0 million of our outstanding shares of common stock in open-market transactions on the NASDAQ Stock Market or through privately negotiated transactions, including block transactions.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P4_S1	The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depend on a variety of factors including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other market conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P4_S2	The stock repurchase program has an expiration date of June 30, 2013 but may be limited or terminated at any time by our Board of Directors without prior notice.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P5_S0	(2) For the period from October 1, 2011 through December 31, 2011, employees surrendered 5,930 shares of common stock to the Company for payment of the minimum tax withholding obligations upon the vesting of shares of restricted common stock.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P6_S0	STOCK PRICE PERFORMANCE GRAPH The following graph shows a comparison of cumulative total return since December 29, 2006, for our common stock, the Russell 2000 Index and the Dow Jones Consumer Services Index (a published industry index), each of which assumes an initial value of $100 and reinvestment of dividends.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P7_S0	Our common stock traded on the NASDAQ National Market until May 24, 2001.
1096376_12_ITEM5_P7_S1	It then traded on the OTC Bulletin Board under the ticker symbol THIN.OB., the American Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol NSI and now trades on the NASDAQ Stock Market under the ticker symbol NTRI.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P0_S0	to and should be read in conjunction with Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements included as Items 7 and 8, respectively, in this Annual Report.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	In June 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Technologies, LLC ( Zero Water ) as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with our current strategic direction.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S1	An equity and impairment loss of $4,000 was recorded during 2009 to write-off the remaining investment.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S2	During 2008, we recorded an equity loss of $2,975 for our share of Zero Water s loss and the amortization expense for the difference between the cost and the underlying equity in net assets of Zero Water at the investment date.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S3	Additionally, we recorded an impairment charge of $6,483 during 2008 to reduce the carrying value of the equity investment to its estimated fair value.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S4	The impairment charge primarily resulted from lower-than-expected operating results and projections of future performance coupled with the current non-strategic business direction of Zero Water and the overall general economic decline which indicated that the full carrying value of the equity investment was not recoverable.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P1_S5	See the discussion contained in Note 7 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P2_S0	In the first quarter of 2010, we committed to a plan to sell the business operations conducted by our subsidiary, Nutrisystem Fresh, Inc. ( NuKitchen ), as it was no longer aligned with the business direction of the Company.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P2_S1	NuKitchen has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P2_S2	During the third quarter of 2010, this business was shut down as we were unsuccessful in locating a buyer.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P2_S3	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P3_S0	The loss on discontinued operations during 2010 was primarily from operations.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P4_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2009, an impairment charge of $4,541 was recorded in connection with the NuKitchen acquisition.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P4_S1	This charge consisted of $2,717 of goodwill and $1,824 of identifiable intangible assets.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P4_S2	See the discussion contained in Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P5_S0	LLC ( Slim and Tone ).
1096376_12_ITEM6_P5_S1	This subsidiary has been treated as a discontinued operation.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P5_S2	Accordingly, the operating results of this discontinued operation have been presented separately from continuing operations and are included in loss on discontinued operation, net of income tax in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for all periods presented.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P6_S0	In 2007, we recorded a pre-tax loss on disposal of $1,256, consisting of an impairment of goodwill and intangibles of $1,156 and a pre-tax loss of $100.
1096376_12_ITEM6_P6_S1	See the discussion contained in Note 12 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the financial information included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	Background We provide weight management products and services and offer nutritionally balanced weight loss programs designed for women, men, and seniors, as well as the Nutrisystem D program, specifically designed to help people with type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight and manage their diabetes.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	The Nutrisystem programs are based on 40 years of nutrition research and on the science of the low Glycemic Index.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel, and through QVC, a television shopping network.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	Approximately 80% of our order volumes are processed through the Internet.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	For 2011, 2010 and 2009, the direct channel accounted for 95%, 96% and 94%, respectively, of total revenue compared to 4%, 4% and 6%, respectively, for QVC.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	During 2011, 1% of total revenue came from other channels.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	We incur significant marketing expenditures to support our brand as we continue to advertise across various media channels.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S6	New media channels are tested on a continual basis and we consider our media mix to be diverse.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S7	We market our weight management system through television, print, direct mail, Internet and public relations.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S8	We review and analyze a number of key operating and financial metrics to manage our business, including the number of new customers, revenue per customer, total revenues, marketing per new customer, operating margins and reactivation revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P2_S9	Our mix of revenue can be divided into three categories.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	First, new customer revenue is all revenue within a quarter from customers joining within that quarter.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	New customer revenue is the main driver of revenue growth.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	Second, on-program revenue is all revenue from customers who joined in previous quarters but who are still within their first nine months on the program.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	Third, reactivation revenue is all revenue generated from customers who are more than nine months from their initial purchase.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our eCommerce, direct-to-consumer business model provides flexibility which allows us to manage marketing spend according to customer demand.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe this flexibility is especially valuable due to the current instability in general economic conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	Additionally, we initiated a concerted effort to improve lifetime customer economics, length of stay, and overall customer satisfaction and are continuously redesigning our eCommerce platform and website.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P4_S3	Our product offerings have expanded to include fresh-frozen foods, and we entered into the retail channel and introduced the Nutrisystem D program during the last several years.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P4_S4	Further, we have taken steps to reduce our overall operating costs.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Over the past several years, our financial performance has been adversely impacted by a number of factors, including the economic downturn and declines in consumers discretionary spending.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	We believe these factors have primarily driven the decline in the number of new customer starts which in turn began to hamper reactivation revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	We continued to see a challenging environment in 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Our plan for 2011, a year that we expected to be challenging from a revenue standpoint, was to optimize our business model to maximize profitability and cash flow, strengthen our balance sheet, return cash to stockholders, and invest in growth initiatives for 2012 and beyond.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	We experienced significantly reduced sales below the comparable 2010 period throughout the month of January.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S3	Our 2011 diet season launch was ineffective in light of intense competitive activity, bargain-focused consumer behavior and weak promotional offerings.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S4	To increase sales effectiveness, we re-launched our Rollback pricing strategy, which increased sales traction in the months of February and March but had a negative impact on gross margins offset by increased marketing efficiency.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P6_S5	Similarly, the remaining months of 2011 were also hampered by continued bargain-focused consumer behavior and economic concerns.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	We continued to react with discounted sales promotions thus reducing average selling prices and gross margins partially offset by increased marketing efficiency.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	Additionally, we incurred severance and other related charges of $2.7 million during the first quarter of 2011, which were more than offset by reductions in general and administrative expenses throughout the remainder of 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	In December 2011, we launched SUCCESS, our most comprehensive program to date and teamed with new celebrities for new national ad campaigns.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	The SUCCESS program is designed to help take the weight off and keep it off through frequent, portion-controlled, balanced nutrition and low Glycemic Index eating.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	It offers our largest ever assortment of signature fresh-frozen meals including new artisanal Chef s Table dinner entrees, developed by Nutrisystem s Celebrity Chef Culinary Council using revolutionary advanced steamer technology; new chocolate, vanilla, strawberry and coffee advanced protein shakes; the introduction of a personalized My Daily 3 physical activity program; and increased personalization and flexibility through transition and maintenance plans that help consumers manage their weight on their own.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P8_S3	SUCCESS replaced our Nutrisystem Advanced program resulting in additional costs during the fourth quarter of 2011 primarily for marketing, packaging and increased reserves for excess and obsolete inventory and returns.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 of the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P9_S2	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P9_S3	Management develops, and changes periodically, these estimates and assumptions based on historical experience and on various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P9_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Management considers the following accounting estimates to be the most critical in preparing our consolidated financial statements.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	These critical accounting estimates are discussed with our audit committee quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	We review the reserves for customer returns at each reporting period and adjust them to reflect data available at that time.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S3	To estimate reserves for returns, we consider actual return rates in preceding periods and changes in product offerings or marketing methods that might impact returns going forward.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S4	To the extent the estimate of returns changes, we will adjust the reserve, which will impact the amount of product sales revenue recognized in the period of the adjustment.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S5	The provision for estimated returns for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $12.9 million, $24.1 million and $30.2 million, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S6	The decrease in the provision during 2011 was due to the decrease in revenue and a decrease in the return rate due to system improvements which offset the additional reserve for the new program launch.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P10_S7	The reserve for returns incurred but not received and processed was $726,000 and $1.0 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, and has been included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	We continually assess the quantities of inventory on hand to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	We estimate the reserve for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on our forecasted demand and/or our ability to sell the products, introduction of new products, future production requirements and changes in our customers behavior.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $769,000 and $419,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P11_S3	The increase in the reserve was due to the new program launch in December 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	Deferred tax assets are evaluated for future realization and reduced by a valuation allowance to the extent we believe a portion will not be realized.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	We consider many factors when assessing the likelihood of future realization of our deferred tax assets, including our recent earnings and expectations of future taxable income and other relevant factors.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	We estimate the annual effective income tax rate at the beginning of each year and revise the estimate at each reporting period based on a number of factors including operating results, level of tax exempt interest income and sales by state, among other items.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	Results of Operations Revenue and expenses consist of the following components: Revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	Food sales include sales of food, supplements, shipping and handling charges billed to customers and sales credits and adjustments, including product returns.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	No revenue is recorded for food products provided at no charge as part of promotions.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S4	Cost of revenue consists primarily of the cost of the products sold, including compensation related to fulfillment, the costs of outside fulfillment, incoming and outgoing shipping costs, charge card fees and packing material.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S5	Cost of products sold includes products provided at no charge as part of promotions and the non-food materials provided with customer orders.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S6	Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses, including share-based payment arrangements, for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S7	Internet advertising expense is recorded based on either the rate of delivery of a guaranteed number of impressions over the advertising contract term or on a cost per customer acquired, depending upon the terms.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S8	Direct-mail advertising costs are capitalized if the primary purpose was to elicit sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the advertising and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S9	The capitalized costs are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S10	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred or the first time the advertising takes place.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P14_S11	General and administrative expense consists of compensation for administrative, information technology, counselors, customer service and sales personnel, share-based payment arrangements for related employees, facility expenses, website development costs, professional service fees and other general corporate expenses.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	Equity and impairment loss consisted of our share of the earnings or losses of our equity interests.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	In June 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Water, as it was determined that the business was no longer aligned with our strategic direction.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P15_S2	We held approximately a 27% fully diluted interest in Zero Water.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	The investment in Zero Water was accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	Interest (expense) income, net consists of interest expense on our outstanding indebtedness net of interest income earned on cash balances and marketable securities.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	We are subject to corporate level income taxes and record a provision for income taxes based on an estimated effective income tax rate for the year.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	We ceased the operations of two of our subsidiaries, Slim and Tone and NuKitchen.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	Accordingly, the operating results of these discontinued operations have been presented separately from continuing operations for all periods presented.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	Overview of the Direct Channel In the years ended 2011, 2010 and 2009, the direct channel represented 95%, 96% and 94%, respectively, of our revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	Revenues through the direct channel were $382.8 million in 2011 compared to $490.8 million in 2010 and $495.4 million in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P19_S2	Revenue is primarily generated through customer starts, reactivation of former customers and the customer ordering behavior, including length of time on our program and the diet program selection.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P19_S3	The decrease in 2011 is primarily attributable to lower average selling prices, discounted promotional offerings and declines in new customers, on-program revenue and reactivation revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Critical to increasing customer starts is our ability to deploy marketing dollars while maintaining marketing effectiveness.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	Factors influencing our marketing effectiveness include the quality of the advertisements, promotional activity by our competitors, as well as the price and availability of appropriate media.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	Year Ended December 31, 2011 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2010 Revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S1	Revenue decreased to $401.4 million in 2011 from $509.5 million in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S2	The revenue decline occurred across all of our sales channels primarily due to lower average selling prices and fewer customer starts and on-program customers as a result of bargain-focused consumer behavior and discounted promotional offerings.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S3	In 2011, direct revenue accounted for 95% of total revenue compared to 4% for QVC and 1% for other channels.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S4	In 2010, direct revenue accounted for 96% of total revenue compared to 4% for QVC.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S5	Cost of revenue decreased to $198.4 million in 2011 from $224.8 million in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S6	Gross margin as a percent of revenue decreased to 50.6% in 2011 from 55.9% in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P21_S7	The decrease in gross margin was primarily attributable to our promotional pricing and to an increase in the sales of our fresh-frozen food programs, which have a higher cost per sales dollar.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	Marketing expense decreased to $110.9 million in 2011 from $145.9 million in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue decreased to 27.6% in 2011 from 28.6% in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	During the beginning of the first quarter of 2011, we experienced significant pressures on response and conversion rates across all sales channels causing a decrease in new customers and directly impacting our marketing efficiency.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	As a result, we reduced the spending for advertising media but increased our promotional incentives to increase demand and leverage marketing efficiency.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2011 promoted the direct business.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	The decrease in marketing is attributable to decreased spending in media ($38.8 million) partially offset by increased spending for the production of television advertising ($3.7 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S2	In total, media spending was $88.8 million in 2011 and $127.6 million in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S3	General and administrative expense decreased to $60.8 million in 2011 from $73.9 million in 2010 and as a percent of revenue increased to 15.2% in 2011 from 14.5% in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S4	The decrease was is primarily attributable to lower compensation, benefits and temporary help ($7.8 million), decreased professional and outside computer services ($2.1 million), lower facilities expense ($1.3 million) and decreased non-cash expense for share-based payment arrangements ($1.9 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S5	We implemented a series of measures, including reductions in headcount and outside professional services during the first quarter of 2011 that resulted in reductions in our general and administrative expenses.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S6	Depreciation and amortization expense increased to $12.1 million in 2011 from $11.8 million in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S7	Interest expense, net, was $468,000 in 2011 compared to interest income, net, of $5,000 in the comparable period of 2010 due to increased average borrowings outstanding during 2011 under our credit facility.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S8	In 2011, we recorded income tax expense of $6.4 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 34.3% as compared to $19.3 million of income tax expense in 2010 with an effective tax rate of 36.3%.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P24_S9	The change in the effective tax rate was due to the impact of limitations on executive compensation deductions and food donations in comparison to pre-tax income, as well as reductions in tax reserves due to the lapse of the statute of limitations during the fourth quarter of 2011 and tax credits and other miscellaneous adjustments occurring throughout the year.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	Revenue decreased to $509.5 million in 2010 from $524.6 million in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	The revenue decrease resulted primarily from decreased reactivation revenue and a reduction in sales through QVC partially offset by an increase in retail revenue.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S2	In 2010, direct revenue accounted for 96% of total revenue compared to 4% for QVC.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S3	In 2009, direct revenue accounted for 94% of total revenue compared to 6% for QVC.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S4	Cost of revenue decreased to $224.8 million in 2010, from $241.2 million in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S5	Gross margin as a percent of revenue increased to 55.9% in 2010 from 54.0% in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S6	The increase in gross margin was primarily attributable to a reduced level of returns, the mix of products with higher gross margins and ongoing cost savings initiatives.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S7	Marketing expense decreased to $145.9 million in 2010 from $146.4 million in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S8	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue increased to 28.6% in 2010 from 27.9% in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S9	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2010 promoted the direct business.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S10	The decrease in marketing is attributable to decreased spending in the production of television advertising ($3.2 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S11	This decrease is partially offset by increased spending in advertising media ($1.5 million) and marketing consulting ($1.4 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S12	In total, media spending was $127.6 million in 2010 and $126.1 million in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S13	General and administrative expense decreased to $73.9 million in 2010 from $76.4 million in 2009 and as a percent of revenue decreased to 14.5% in 2010 from 14.6% in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S14	The decrease in spending is primarily attributable to decreased professional, outside and computer services ($3.2 million) due to our focus on cost containment and charges incurred in 2009 to streamline work processes and right size our organization ($1.9 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P25_S15	These decreases were partially offset by higher compensation and benefits and temporary help ($1.9 million) and increased non-cash expense for share-based payment arrangements ($1.5 million).
1096376_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Depreciation and amortization expense increased to $11.8 million in 2010 from $11.2 million in 2009 due to the relocation of our corporate headquarters and capital expenditures on our website.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	Other (expense) income represents the impact of changes in the Canadian dollar.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	In 2009, we abandoned our interest in Zero Water because the business was no longer aligned with our strategic direction.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S2	An equity and impairment loss of $4.0 million was recorded including the write-off of the remaining investment.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S3	Interest income, net decreased to $5,000 in 2010 from $104,000 in 2009 primarily due to borrowings under our credit facility during 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S4	In 2010, we recorded income tax expense of $19.3 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 36.3% as compared to $13.1 million of income tax expense in 2009 at an effective tax rate of 28.5%.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P27_S5	The increase in the effective tax rate was primarily the result of the abandonment of our investment in Zero Water in 2009 which provided an income tax deduction for the entire original $14.3 million tax basis investment in Zero Water and reduced 2009 income tax payments by approximately $5.0 million.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	As of December 31, 2011, our principal commitments consisted of obligations under supply agreements with food vendors, an agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, operating leases and employment contracts.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	Although we have no material commitments for capital expenditures, we anticipate continuing requirements for capital expenditures.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S2	Following is a summary of our contractual obligations.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S3	We have no other commercial commitments.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S4	We have entered into supply agreements with various food vendors.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S5	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S6	One agreement also provides for certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S7	Additionally, we have entered into an agreement with our outside fulfillment provider which contains minimum space requirements.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P28_S8	We anticipate that we will meet all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	In December 2011, the Company executed an amended and restated credit agreement with a group of lenders that provides for a $100.0 million unsecured revolving credit facility through December 5, 2016.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P29_S1	Our previous $200.0 million facility was set to expire in October 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P29_S2	We borrowed $30.0 million against this facility during 2011 which was used to repay amounts outstanding under the old facility.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	The credit agreement provides for interest at either a floating rate, which will be a base rate, or a Eurocurrency rate equal to the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate for the relevant term, plus an applicable margin.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	We are subject to an unused fee payable quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	In 2010, we entered into two separate $10.0 million notional value floating to fixed interest rate swap agreements ( Swaps ) that mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	Under the Swaps, we receive interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pay a fixed rate of interest of 0.75%, with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P32_S2	In January 2012, we entered into a third $10.0 million notional value interest rate swap for the amended and restated credit agreement.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P32_S3	In addition, we have no off-balance sheet financing arrangements.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	The capital and credit markets have become more volatile as a result of the recent global economic conditions, which has caused a general tightening in the credit markets, lower levels of liquidity and increased financing costs.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P33_S1	Despite these factors, we believe that available capital resources are sufficient to fund our working capital requirements, capital expenditures, income tax obligations, dividends and share repurchases for the foreseeable future.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	As our previous credit agreement was set to expire in 2012, we entered into a $100 million amended and restated credit agreement that extended the commitment period and replaced our previous agreement.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P34_S1	At December 31, 2011, we had working capital of $76.2 million, an increase of $2.2 million from the $74.0 million working capital balance at December 31, 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P34_S2	Cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2011 were $47.6 million, an increase of $27.2 million from the balance of $20.4 million at December 31, 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P34_S3	In addition, we had $10.0 million invested in marketable securities at December 31, 2011 as compared to $20.8 million at December 31, 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P34_S4	Our principal sources of liquidity during this period were cash flows from operations.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	We have a $100.0 million unsecured revolving credit facility with a group of lenders which is committed until December 5, 2016 with an expansion feature, subject to certain conditions, to increase the facility to $180.0 million.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P35_S1	In 2011, we generated cash flow of $47.3 million from operating activities, a decrease of $19.3 million from 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P35_S2	The decrease in cash flow from operations is primarily attributable to lower net income for 2011 and net changes in operating assets and liabilities primarily driven by inventory balances and the use of supplier advances.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	In 2011, net cash provided by investing activities was $2.9 million primarily from the $20.9 million sale of marketable securities reduced by purchases of marketable securities of $10.1 million and capital additions of $8.0 million.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	We are continuing to invest in our ecommerce and web platform to incorporate new product initiatives.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	In 2011, net cash used in financing activities was $23.0 million, a decrease of $45.6 million from 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P37_S1	During 2011, we did not repurchase any of our shares of common stock as compared to $75.0 million spent to purchase shares in 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P37_S2	On July 28, 2011, we announced that our Board of Directors had authorized the repurchase of up to $150.0 million of our outstanding shares of common stock in open-market transactions on the NASDAQ Stock Market or through privately negotiated transactions, including block transactions.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P37_S3	The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depend on a variety of factors including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other market conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P37_S4	The stock repurchase program has an expiration date of June 30, 2013 but may be limited or terminated at any time without prior notice.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	Our Board of Directors declared quarterly dividends of $0.175 per share, which were paid on March 17, 2011, May 19, 2011, August 18, 2011 and November 25, 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	Subsequent to December 31, 2011, our Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share payable on March 26, 2012 to stockholders of record as of March 15, 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P38_S2	Although we intend to continue to pay regular quarterly dividends, the declaration and payment of future dividends are discretionary and will be subject to quarterly determination by our Board of Directors following its review of our financial performance.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is strongest in the first calendar quarter and lowest in the fourth calendar quarter.
1096376_12_ITEM7_P39_S1	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet and the price and availability of certain media.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We have interest-rate risk exposure for changes in interest rates relating to our outstanding borrowings.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We manage our exposure to changing interest rates through the use of a combination of variable-rate debt and fixing the interest rate of certain variable-rate debt through the use of interest rate swaps.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S2	At December 31, 2011, we had two interest rate swap agreements (the Swaps ), with notional amounts of $10.0 million each, which mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Under the Swaps, we receive interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pay a fixed rate of interest of 0.75% with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S4	In January 2012, we entered into a third $10.0 million notional value interest rate swap for the amended and restated credit agreement.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S5	At December 31, 2011, we had $30.0 million of debt outstanding at a weighted average interest rate of 1.26%.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P0_S6	A 1 percentage point change in the weighted average rate would affect annual interest by approximately $300,000.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We believe that we are not subject to any material risks arising from changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity prices or other market changes that affect market risk instruments.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2011 of $47.6 million were maintained in bank and money market accounts.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Additionally, we invested $10.0 million in marketable securities, which are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at fair value in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_12_ITEM7A_P2_S2	As such, a change in interest rates of 1 percentage point would not have a material impact on our operating results and cash flows.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	defines the term disclosure controls and procedures to mean a company s controls and other procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that it files or submits under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on the evaluation of the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures by our management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer, as of the end of the period covered by this report, our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer have concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures at the end of the period covered by this report were effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is (i) recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Commission s rules and forms, and (ii) accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding disclosure.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over the Company s financial reporting.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of the Company s financial reporting and the preparation of consolidated financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that: (i) pertain to maintaining records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of the Company s financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and that the receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made in accordance with management and board of director authorization; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on its financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P3_S0	There was no change in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Management evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ).
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based upon that evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P5_S0	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm, KPMG LLP, has audited the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Their report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting appears on page 40.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Nutrisystem, Inc.: We have audited Nutrisystem, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Nutrisystem, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P6_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S4	In our opinion, Nutrisystem, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1096376_12_ITEM9A_P7_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders equity and comprehensive income, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011, and our report dated March 12, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P3_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Nutrisystem, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company) as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders equity and comprehensive income, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P3_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P3_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P3_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P3_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P4_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P4_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P4_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P4_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P8_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P9_S0	BACKGROUND Nature of the Business Nutrisystem, Inc. (the Company or Nutrisystem ), a provider of weight management products and services, offers nutritionally balanced weight loss programs designed for women, men, and seniors, as well as the Nutrisystem D program, specifically designed to help people with type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight and manage their diabetes.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P9_S1	The Nutrisystem programs are based on 40 years of nutrition research and on the science of the low glycemic index.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P10_S0	The Company s pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel, and through QVC, a television shopping network.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P10_S1	Approximately 99%, 98% and 98% of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, were generated in the United States.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P11_S0	The Company s consolidated financial statements include 100% of the assets and liabilities of Nutrisystem, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P11_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P12_S0	Cash Equivalents and Marketable Securities Cash equivalents include only securities having a maturity of three months or less at the time of purchase.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P12_S1	At December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, demand accounts and money market accounts comprised all of the Company s cash and cash equivalents.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P12_S2	Marketable securities at December 31, 2011 consist of investments in an income fund that principally holds short-term municipal securities of the U.S. and at December 31, 2010 consisted of investments in a bond fund that held short-term U.S. government securities with original maturities of greater than three months.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P12_S3	The Company classifies these as available-for-sale securities.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P12_S4	The marketable securities are reported at fair value with the related unrealized gains and losses included in accumulated other comprehensive loss, a component of stockholders equity, net of related tax effects.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P13_S0	The Company evaluates its investments for other-than-temporary impairment by reviewing factors such as the length of time and extent to which fair value has been below cost basis and the Company s ability and intent to hold the investment for a period of time which may be sufficient for anticipated recovery of the market value.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P13_S1	There were no other-than-temporary impairments in 2011 or 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P14_S0	Inventories Inventories consist principally of packaged food held in outside fulfillment locations.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P14_S1	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market, with cost determined using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P14_S2	Quantities of inventory on hand are continually assessed to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P14_S3	The reserve is estimated for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on forecasted demand and/or the Company s ability to sell the products, introduction of new products, future production requirements and changes in customers behavior.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P14_S4	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $769 and $419 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P15_S0	Fixed Assets Fixed assets are stated at cost.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P16_S0	Depreciation is provided using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which are generally two to seven years.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P17_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the lesser of the estimated useful life of the asset or the related lease term.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P17_S1	Expenditures for repairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred, while major renewals and improvements are capitalized.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P18_S0	Included in fixed assets is the capitalized cost of internal-use software and website development incurred during the application development stage.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P18_S1	Capitalized costs are amortized using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the asset, which is generally two to five years.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P19_S0	Costs incurred related to planning or maintenance of internal-use software and website development are charged to expense as incurred.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P19_S1	The net book value of capitalized software was $10,285 and $12,845 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P20_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company continually evaluates whether events or circumstances have occurred that would indicate that the remaining estimated useful lives of long-lived assets may warrant revision or that the remaining balance may not be recoverable.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P20_S1	Long-lived assets are evaluated for indicators of impairment.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P20_S2	When factors indicate that long-lived assets should be evaluated for possible impairment, an estimate of the related undiscounted cash flows over the remaining life of the long-lived assets is used to measure recoverability.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P20_S3	If any impairment is indicated, measurement of the impairment will be based on the difference between the carrying value and fair value of the asset, generally determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows associated with the use of the asset.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P21_S0	As of December 31, 2011, management believes that no reductions to the remaining useful lives or write-downs of long-lived assets are required.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P22_S0	The functional currency of the Company s Canadian subsidiary, which has been legally dissolved, was the Canadian dollar.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P22_S1	Assets and liabilities were translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates as of the financial statement date and revenues and expenses were translated at average exchange rates prevailing during the respective periods.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P22_S2	Translation adjustments were included as a separate component of accumulated other comprehensive loss in stockholders equity in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P22_S3	Gains and losses from foreign currency transactions were recognized as other (expense) income in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations and were $0 in 2011, $32 of expense in 2010 and $407 of income in 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P23_S0	Derivative Instruments Interest rate swap agreements, a type of financial derivative instrument, are utilized by the Company to reduce interest rate risk on credit facility borrowings.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P23_S1	The Company recognizes the interest rate swaps in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets at fair value.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P23_S2	The Company has designated and accounted for its interest rate swaps as cash flow hedges of variable-rate debt.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P23_S3	The effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative is reported as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders equity in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, net of tax, and reclassified into earnings in the periods during which the hedged transactions affect earnings.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P23_S4	To the extent that the change in value of the derivative does not perfectly offset the change in value of the items being hedged, that ineffective portion is immediately recognized in earnings.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P24_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from product sales is recognized when the earnings process is complete, which is upon transfer of title to the product.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P25_S0	evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the selling price is fixed and determinable and collection is reasonably assured.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P25_S1	The Company also sells prepaid program cards to wholesalers and retailers.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P25_S2	Revenue from these cards is recognized after the card is redeemed online at the Company s website by the customer and the product is shipped to the customer.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P25_S3	Deferred revenue consists primarily of unredeemed prepaid program cards and unshipped frozen foods.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S0	When a customer orders the Nutrisystem Select program, two separate shipments are delivered.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S1	The first shipment contains Nutrisystem s standard shelf-stable food.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S2	The second shipment contains the fresh-frozen foods and is generally delivered within two weeks of a customer s order.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S3	Both shipments qualify as separate units of accounting and the fair value is based on the estimated selling price of both units.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S4	Customers may return unopened product within 30 days of purchase in order to receive a refund or credit.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S5	Fresh-frozen products are non-returnable and non-refundable unless the order is canceled within seven days of delivery.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S6	Estimated returns are accrued at the time the sale is recognized and actual returns are tracked monthly.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S7	The Company reviews its history of actual versus estimated returns to ensure reserves are appropriate.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S8	Revenue from product sales includes amounts billed for shipping and handling and is presented net of returns and billed sales tax.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S9	Revenue from shipping and handling charges was $2,867, $5,763 and $5,193 in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P26_S10	Shipping-related costs are included in cost of revenue in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S0	Dependence on Suppliers In 2011, approximately 16% and 15%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S1	The Company has a supply arrangement with one of these vendors that requires the Company to make minimum purchases.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S2	In 2010, these vendors supplied approximately 17% and 18%, respectively, of inventory purchases and in 2009, approximately 19% and 18%, respectively, of total purchases (see Note 9).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S3	Additionally, the Company was dependent on one frozen food supplier for less than 20% of its food costs in 2011.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S4	The amount provided from this supplier in 2010 was negligible.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P27_S5	The Company had a supply agreement with this supplier that expired in November 2011 and the Company has found other frozen food supply options to replace this supplier.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P28_S0	During 2011 and 2010, the Company outsourced 100% of its fulfillment operations to third party providers.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P28_S1	During 2009, more than 85% of its fulfillment operations were handled by third party providers.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S0	Vendor Rebates One of the Company s suppliers provides for rebates based on purchasing levels.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S1	The Company accounts for this rebate on an accrual basis as purchases are made at a rebate percent determined based upon the estimated total purchases from the vendor.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S2	The estimated rebate is recorded as a reduction in the carrying value of purchased inventory and is reflected in the consolidated statements of operations when the associated inventory is sold.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S3	A receivable is recorded for the estimate of the rebate earned.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S4	The rebate period is June 1 through May 31 of each year.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company reduced cost of revenue by $1,401, $1,912 and $2,316, respectively, for these rebates.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P29_S6	A receivable of $686 and $541 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, has been recorded in receivables in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P30_S0	Historically, the actual rebate received from the vendor has closely matched the estimated rebate recorded.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P30_S1	An adjustment is made to the estimate upon determination of the final rebate.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P31_S0	Marketing Expense Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses, including share-based payment arrangements, for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P31_S1	Media expense was $88,828, $127,597 and $126,117 in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P32_S0	costs are capitalized if the primary purpose was to elicit sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the direct mailing and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P32_S1	The capitalized costs are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P32_S2	Typically, this period falls within 40 days of the initial direct mailing.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P32_S3	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred or the first time the advertising takes place.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P32_S4	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, $4,800 and $7,152, respectively, of costs have been prepaid for future advertisements and promotions.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P33_S0	Lease Related Expenses Certain of the Company s lease contracts contain rent holidays, various escalation clauses, or landlord/tenant incentives.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P33_S1	The Company records rental costs, including costs related to fixed rent escalation clauses and rent holidays, on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P34_S0	Lease allowances utilized for space improvement are recorded as leasehold improvement assets and amortized over the shorter of the economic useful life of the asset or the lease term.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P34_S1	Tenant lease incentive allowances received are recorded as deferred rent and amortized as reductions to rent expense over the lease term.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P34_S2	Included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets is $3,646 of a tenant improvement allowance at December 31, 2011, of which $345 is included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities and $3,301 in non-current liabilities.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P34_S3	At December 31, 2010, the tenant improvement allowance was $3,991, of which $345 is included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities and $3,646 in non-current liabilities.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P35_S0	Income Taxes Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and the respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P35_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P35_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in the consolidated statements of operations in the period that includes the enactment date.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P36_S0	In assessing the ability to realize deferred tax assets, the Company considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P36_S1	A tax benefit from an uncertain tax position may be recognized only if it is more likely than not that the position is sustainable, based on its technical merits.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P36_S2	The tax benefit of a qualifying position is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized upon settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P36_S3	The liability for unrecognized tax benefits is classified as noncurrent unless the liability is expected to be settled in cash within 12 months of the reporting date.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P36_S4	The Company records accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of interest expense.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P37_S0	The Company is managed and operated as one business.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P37_S1	The entire business is managed by a single management team that reports to the chief executive officer.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P37_S2	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P38_S0	Earnings Per Share The Company uses the two-class method to calculate earnings per share ( EPS ) as the unvested restricted stock issued under the Company s equity incentive plans are participating shares with nonforfeitable rights to dividends.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P39_S0	Under the two-class method, earnings per common share are computed by dividing the sum of distributed earnings to common stockholders and undistributed earnings allocated to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P39_S1	In applying the two-class method, undistributed earnings are allocated to both common shares and participating securities based on the number of weighted average shares outstanding during the period.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P39_S2	The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted EPS: In 2011, 2010 and 2009, common stock equivalents representing 656,871, 167,158 and 527,891 shares of common stock, respectively, were excluded from weighted average shares outstanding for diluted income per common share purposes because the effect would be anti-dilutive.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P40_S0	The cost of all share-based awards to employees and non-employees, including grants of stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units, is recognized in the financial statements based on the fair value of the awards at grant date.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P41_S0	The fair value of stock option awards is determined using the Black-Scholes valuation model on the date of grant.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P41_S1	The fair value of restricted stock and restricted stock unit awards is equal to the market price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P41_S2	The fair value of share-based awards is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, net of estimated forfeitures.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P41_S3	The Company relies primarily upon historical experience to estimate expected forfeitures and recognizes compensation expense on a straight-line basis from the date of grant.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P42_S0	The Company issues new shares upon exercise of stock options or vesting of restricted stock or restricted stock units.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P43_S0	Cash Flow Information The Company made payments for income taxes of $6,049, $16,660 and $11,449 in 2011, 2010, and 2009, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P43_S1	Interest payments in 2011, 2010 and 2009 were $655, $283 and $304, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P43_S2	During 2011, the Company had non-cash capital additions of $1,198 of unpaid invoices in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P43_S3	During 2010, the Company had non-cash capital additions of $3,991 through a tenant improvement allowance and $1,664 of unpaid invoices in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P44_S0	No. 2011-05 Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Presentation of Comprehensive Income ( ASU No. 2011-05 ) amends existing guidance by allowing only two options for presenting the components of net income and other comprehensive income: (1) in a single continuous financial statement, statement of comprehensive income or (2) in two separate but consecutive financial statements, consisting of an income statement followed by a separate statement of other comprehensive income.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P44_S1	ASU No. 2011-05 requires retrospective application, and it is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011, with early adoption permitted.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P44_S2	The Company believes the adoption of this update will change the order in which certain financial statements are presented and provide additional detail on those financial statements when applicable, but will not have any other impact on its consolidated financial position or results of operations.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P45_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and operating expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P45_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P46_S0	Certain immaterial reclassifications have been made to prior year amounts to conform to the current year presentation.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P49_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS A three-tier fair value hierarchy has been established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) to prioritize the inputs used in measuring fair value.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P50_S0	Level 1 Valuations based on quoted prices for identical assets and liabilities in active markets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P50_S1	Level 2 Valuations based on observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active, or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P50_S2	Level 3 Valuations based on unobservable inputs reflecting the Company s own assumptions, consistent with reasonably available assumptions made by other market participants.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P51_S0	The fair values of the Company s cash equivalents and marketable securities are based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P51_S1	The fair values of the Company s derivative instruments are determined using pricing models that take into account contract terms and certain observable current market information such as London Inter-Bank Offered Rate ( LIBOR ) interest rates.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P51_S2	The following table summarizes the Company s financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value at December 31, 2011:
1096376_12_ITEM15_P51_S3	The following table summarizes the Company s financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value at December 31, 2010:

1096376_12_ITEM15_P53_S0	GOODWILL AND IDENTIFIABLE INTANGIBLE ASSETS On July 1, 2008, the Company acquired certain assets of Power Chow, LLC (d/b/a NuKitchen) ( NuKitchen ), a provider of freshly prepared meals designed to promote weight management and healthy living.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P53_S1	The total purchase price of $5,717 was allocated to identifiable intangible assets ($3,000) and goodwill ($2,717).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P53_S2	As further discussed in Note 12, NuKitchen has been treated as a discontinued operation in 2010 and 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P54_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2009, a goodwill impairment charge of $2,717 was recorded as a result of the Company conducting its annual impairment test of goodwill.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P54_S1	Additionally, the Company recorded an impairment charge of $1,824 for identifiable intangible assets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P55_S0	The Company used a combination of income and market based approaches to estimate the fair value.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P55_S1	The impairment is classified in discontinued operations (see Note 12).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P55_S2	The impairment charge primarily resulted from management s determination that the resources needed to grow a premium product in a down economy were unsustainable after conducting market tests during the fourth quarter of 2009, particularly with respect to the higher-end consumer segment.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P56_S0	EQUITY INVESTMENT On October 11, 2007, the Company purchased an approximately 27% fully diluted equity interest in Zero Technologies, LLC ( Zero Water ), at a purchase price of $14,258.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P56_S1	This investment was accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P56_S2	In June 2009, the Company abandoned its interest in Zero Water as management determined that the business was no longer aligned with the Company s strategic direction.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P56_S3	An equity and impairment loss of $4,000 was recorded to write-off the remaining investment.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P57_S0	CREDIT FACILITY AND INTEREST RATE SWAPS On December 5, 2011, the Company executed an amended and restated credit agreement with a group of lenders that provides for a $100,000 unsecured revolving credit facility with an expansion feature, subject to certain conditions, to increase the facility to $180,000 (the Credit Facility ).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P57_S1	The Credit Facility replaced the $200,000 facility that was expiring in October 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P57_S2	The Company borrowed $30,000 million against the Credit Facility during 2011 which was used to repay amounts outstanding under the old facility.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P57_S3	As of December 31, 2011, the Company had $30,000 in borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility at a weighted average interest rate of 1.26%.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P58_S0	The Credit Facility provides for interest at either a floating rate, which will be a base rate, or a Eurocurrency rate equal to LIBOR for the relevant term, plus an applicable margin.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P59_S0	base rate or one-half of one percent above the Federal Funds Rate.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P59_S1	The Credit Facility is also subject to an unused fee payable quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P59_S2	The unused fee is subject to adjustment based on the Company s consolidated leverage ratio and ranges from 0.25-0.45% per year.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P59_S3	During 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company incurred $417, $87 and $0 in interest, respectively, and $279, $294 and $304 in an unused line fee, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P59_S4	Interest payments and unused line fees are classified within interest (expense) income, net in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S0	The Credit Facility contains financial and other covenants, including a maximum leverage ratio, a minimum fixed charge ratio and a minimum consolidated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, and includes limitations on, among other things, liens, capital expenditures, certain acquisitions, consolidations and sales of assets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S1	As of December 31, 2011, the Company was in compliance with all covenants contained in the Credit Facility.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S2	At December 31, 2011, the Company had $1,097 of unamortized debt issuance costs associated with the Credit Facility, of which $991 were incurred in December 2011 for amending the Credit Facility.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S3	These costs are being amortized over the remaining term of the Credit Facility.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S4	The amount of unused Credit Facility at December 31, 2011 was $70,000.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P60_S5	The Credit Facility can be drawn upon through December 5, 2016, at which time all amounts must be repaid.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P61_S0	The Company uses interest rate swaps, a type of derivative financial instrument, to manage interest costs and minimize the effects of interest rate fluctuations on cash flows associated with its variable-rate debt.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P61_S1	The Company does not use interest rate derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P62_S0	While interest rate swaps are subject to fluctuations in value, these fluctuations are generally offset by the value of the underlying exposures being hedged.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S0	The Company minimizes the risk of credit loss by entering into these agreements with financial institutions that have high credit ratings.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S1	In November 2010, the Company entered into two separate $10,000 notional value floating to fixed interest rate swap agreements ( Swaps ) that mature on August 3, 2012 and September 28, 2012, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S2	Under the Swaps, the Company receives interest equivalent to the three-month LIBOR and pays a fixed rate of interest of 0.75%, with settlements occurring quarterly.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S3	The objective of the hedges is to eliminate the variability of cash flows in interest payments for $20,000 of floating rate debt.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S4	The Swaps estimated fair value was a liability of $22 and $44 as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P63_S5	The corresponding change in fair value is included in accumulated other comprehensive loss in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P64_S0	There were no amounts of cash flow hedge ineffectiveness recorded during 2011 or 2010.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P64_S1	The Company expects a liability of $22 to be reclassified into earnings within the next 12 months as both Swaps mature in 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P65_S0	In January 2012, we entered into a third $10,000 notional value interest rate swap for the amended and restated credit agreement.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company leases its corporate headquarters and certain equipment.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P66_S1	These leases generally have initial terms of one to 12 years and have renewal options for additional periods.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P66_S2	Certain of the leases also contain escalation clauses based upon increases in costs related to the properties.
