1096376_12_ITEM15_P68_S0	Total rent expense for 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $3,136, $3,540 and $3,269, respectively.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S0	Litigation Commencing on October 9, 2007, several putative class action suits were filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania naming Nutrisystem, Inc. and certain of its officers and directors as defendants and alleging violations of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S1	The complaints purported to bring claims on behalf of a class of persons who purchased the Company s common stock between February 14, 2007 and October 3, 2007 or October 4, 2007.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S2	The complaints alleged that the defendants issued various materially false and misleading statements relating to the Company s projected performance that had the effect of artificially inflating the market price of its securities.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S3	These actions were consolidated in December 2007 under docket number 07-4215, and a consolidated amended complaint was filed on March 7, 2008 that raised the same claims but alleged a class period of February 14, 2007 through February 19, 2008.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S4	The consolidated amended complaint asked the court to (1) certify a class, (2) award compensatory damages, reasonable costs and expenses and (3) grant such other and further relief as the court deemed just and proper.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S5	The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on May 6, 2008 that was granted by the Court on August 31, 2009.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P69_S6	On September 29, 2009, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal, and on May 19, 2010, upon motion by the plaintiff/appellant, the appeal was dismissed with prejudice without costs to either party.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S0	On April 27, 2010, counsel for a stockholder sent a letter relating to the same events that formed the bases of the federal putative class action described above.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S1	Specifically, the stockholder has demanded, pursuant to Delaware Chancery Court Rule 23.1, that the Board of Directors (1) undertake (or cause to be undertaken) an independent internal investigation into violations of Delaware law committed by Company management during the time periods described above and (2) commence a civil action against each member of management to recover for the benefit of the Company the amount of damages sustained by the Company as a result of their breaches of fiduciary duties described above.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S2	The Board of Directors appointed a special committee consisting of three independent directors to investigate this demand.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S3	The special committee engaged independent legal counsel to assist it in this investigation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S4	In April 2011, the special committee, with the assistance of independent legal counsel, completed its investigation and delivered to the Board of Directors the special committee s recommendation that the Company refuse the demands made in the stockholder s letter.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S5	At its April 2011 meeting, the Board of Directors, after deliberation and discussion, unanimously determined to accept the special committee s recommendation as in the best interests of the Company and its stockholders.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S6	Promptly thereafter, the special committee s counsel delivered to the stockholder s counsel a letter informing counsel of the Board of Directors actions and the Company s decision to refuse the stockholder s demands.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S7	In May 2011, the stockholder s counsel sent a letter to the Company s counsel demanding to inspect and make copies of certain specified books, records, minutes and other documents of the Company for the purposes set forth in such letter.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S8	Without waiving any of its rights to challenge the propriety of such purposes under Delaware law, in early June 2011, the Company delivered to the stockholder s counsel copies of certain minutes of the Board of Directors and the special committee according to the terms of a confidentiality agreement that the Company and the stockholder had executed.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P70_S9	The Company has not received any further correspondence or communications from the stockholder or his counsel since that time.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P71_S0	On August 5, 2011, a lawsuit was filed by a stockholder in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania naming Nutrisystem, Inc., certain of its officers and directors, and one of its former officers as defendants and alleging breaches by defendants of their fiduciary duties of candor, good faith and loyalty, unjust enrichment, and aiding and abetting from 2010 to the present in connection with the award of excessive and unwarranted 2010 executive compensation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P71_S1	Plaintiff specifically claims the action to be a failed say-on-pay shareholder derivative action stemming from the advisory, non-binding vote of the Company s stockholders at its May 12, 2011 annual meeting in which the Company s stockholders did not approve the Company s 2010 executive compensation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P72_S0	certain false and misleading statements contained in Nutrisystem s Proxy Statement; (2) the defendants breached their fiduciary duties in connection with the Board of Directors compensation practices; (3) the defendants breached their fiduciary duties in connection with the Company s failure to respond to the negative say-on-pay vote; and (4) as a result of the foregoing the defendants were unjustly enriched at the expense of the Company.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P72_S1	Accordingly, the complaint asks the court to (1) award judgment against the defendants and in favor of the Company for an unspecified amount of damages sustained by the Company as a result of defendants violation of state law, (2) grant extraordinary equitable and/or injunctive relief as necessary or permitted by law, equity and the statutory provisions cited in the complaint, including disgorgement, attachment, impoundment, imposition of a constructive trust on or otherwise restricting the disposition/exercise of improvidently awarded executive compensation based upon false financial reporting and/or the proceeds of defendants trading activities or their other assets so as to ensure that plaintiff on behalf of the Company has an effective remedy; (3) order the implementation and administration of internal controls and systems at the Company designed to prohibit and prevent excessive and/or unwarranted executive compensation payments to the Company s chief executive, chief financial, and other senior executive officers; (4) award to plaintiff the costs and disbursements of the action, including reasonable attorneys fees, and accountants and expert fees, costs and expenses; and (5) grant such other and further relief as the court deems just and proper.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S0	On October 21, 2011 the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Rules 12(b)(6) and 23.1 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted and for failure to adequately plead demand futility.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S1	On November 21, 2011 plaintiff filed his brief in opposition to the defendants motion to dismiss the complaint and alleged that the directors issued false and misleading statements in the Company s proxy statement by stating that the Company adhered to a pay-for-performance policy when in fact it did not.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S2	In its opposition brief, plaintiff abandoned the count contained in its complaint that the defendants breached their fiduciary duties in connection with the Company s failure to respond to the negative say-on-pay vote.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S3	On December 5, 2011 defendants filed their reply brief in support of their motion to dismiss the complaint.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S4	The court has scheduled a preliminary pretrial conference for March 8, 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P73_S5	The Company believes that the claims are without merit and intends to defend the litigation vigorously.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P74_S0	On September 1, 2011, a lawsuit was filed by another stockholder in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania naming Nutrisystem, Inc., certain of its officers and directors, and one of its former officers as defendants and alleging breaches by defendants of their fiduciary duties of candor, good faith and loyalty, unjust enrichment, and aiding and abetting from 2010 to the present in connection with the award of excessive and unwarranted 2010 executive compensation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P74_S1	This action stems from the same failed say-on-pay advisory, non-binding vote of the Company s stockholders at its May 12, 2011 annual meeting in which the Company s stockholders did not approve the Company s 2010 executive compensation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P74_S2	The complaint is listed under docket number 2011-24985 and specifically alleges that (1) the defendants breached their fiduciary duties in connection with the issuance of certain materially false and misleading statements and omissions of fact in Nutrisystem s Proxy Statement; (2) the defendants breached their fiduciary duties in connection with the Company s excessive 2010 executive compensation and the failure to rescind such compensation in response to the negative say-on-pay vote; and (3) as a result of the foregoing the executive defendants were unjustly enriched at the expense of the Company.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P74_S3	Accordingly, the complaint asks the court to (1) determine that the action is a proper derivative action maintainable under the law and that demand is excused; (2) award judgment against the defendants and in favor of the Company for an unspecified amount of damages sustained by the Company as a result of defendants breaches of fiduciary duties; (3) grant injunctive and other equitable relief as necessary or permitted by law, equity and the statutory provisions cited in the complaint, including disgorgement, attachment, impoundment, imposition of a constructive trust on or otherwise restricting the disposition/exercise of disloyally awarded 2010 executive compensation; (4) direct the Company to take all necessary actions to reform and improve its corporate governance and internal procedures to comply with all applicable laws and to protect the Company and its stockholders from a repeat of the damaging events described in the Complaint; (5) award to plaintiff the costs and disbursements of the action, including reasonable allowance of fees and costs for plaintiff s attorneys, experts and accountants; and (6) grant such other and further relief as the court deems just and proper.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P75_S0	of Civil Procedure 1028(a)(1) and (a)(4) under Pennsylvania s internal affairs doctrine; (2) failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted under Pennsylvania Rule of Civil Procedure 1028(a)(4); and (3) lack of capacity to sue under Pennsylvania Rule of Civil Procedure 1028(a)(5) because the plaintiff did not make a demand on the Company s directors and failed to adequately allege that such demand was excused.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S0	On November 21, 2011, defendants filed a praecipe for argument in which they requested oral argument.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S1	On December 23, 2011, plaintiff filed his opposition to the defendants preliminary objections and alleged that the directors issued false and misleading statements in the Company s proxy statement by stating that the Company adhered to a pay-for-performance policy when in fact it did not.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S2	On January 23, 2012, defendants filed their reply brief in support of their preliminary objections to the complaint.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S3	Oral argument was heard by the court on February 8, 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S4	On February 13, 2012, the court denied the defendants preliminary objections.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S5	The defendants answer to the complaint is now required to be filed by March 13, 2012.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S6	The Company believes that the claims are without merit and intends to defend the litigation vigorously.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S7	The Company is also involved in other various claims and routine litigation matters.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P76_S8	In the opinion of management, after consultation with legal counsel, the outcomes of such matters are not anticipated to have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in future years.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P77_S0	The Company has entered into supply agreements with various food vendors.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P77_S2	One agreement also provides rebates if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P81_S0	On July 28, 2011, the Company announced that its Board of Directors had authorized a new stock repurchase program of up to $150,000 of the Company s outstanding shares of common stock in open-market transactions on the NASDAQ National Market or through privately negotiated transactions, including block transactions.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P81_S1	The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depend on a variety of factors including price, corporate and regulatory requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other market conditions.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P81_S2	This stock repurchase program has an expiration date of June 30, 2013 but may be limited or terminated at any time by the Board of Directors without prior notice.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P86_S2	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, the Company had net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $12,832 and $13,716, respectively, for state tax purposes.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P86_S3	The decrease is due to the utilization of net operating losses.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P86_S4	For state tax purposes, there is a limitation on the amount of net operating loss carryforwards that can be utilized in a given year to offset state taxable income.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P86_S5	Net operating losses will begin to expire in 2024.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P86_S6	Based on the projected level of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the net deferred tax assets.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P87_S0	In 2008, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of $3,749 related to its impairment of its investment in Zero Water since the character of the deduction could be a capital item and there was no history of generating capital gains.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P87_S1	In 2009, the Company abandoned its investment in Zero Water (see Note 7) which provided the Company with a current year income tax deduction for its entire original $14,258 tax basis investment in Zero Water.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P87_S2	This reduced 2009 federal income tax payments by approximately $4,990.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P88_S0	ended December 31, 2009 including a reversal of a $3,749 valuation allowance established in 2008 for deferred tax assets related to prior Zero Water losses and impairment charges.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P88_S1	These Zero Water losses and impairment charges were considered realizable during the year ended December 31, 2009 due to the terms of the abandonment which changed the tax loss from capital to ordinary which the Company believes is more likely than not to realize.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P88_S2	The total amount of gross unrecognized tax benefits as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 was $1,919 and $2,478, respectively.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P92_S0	Equity Incentive Plans The Company had three equity incentive plans: the 1999 Equity Incentive Plan, the 2000 Equity Incentive Plan and the 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan (collectively, the Equity Incentive Plans ).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P92_S1	The 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan is currently the only plan under which new awards may be granted.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P92_S2	Under that plan, a variety of equity instruments can be granted to key employees including incentive and nonqualified stock options to purchase shares of the Company s common stock, restricted stock, restricted stock units or shares of common stock.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S0	authorize up to 1,000,000, 5,600,000 and 2,700,000 shares of common stock, respectively, for issuance.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S1	At December 31, 2011, the 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan had 500,039 shares available for grant.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S2	Under each of the plans, the Board of Directors determines the term of each award, but no award can be exercisable more than 10 years from the date the award is granted.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S3	To date, all of the awards issued under the Equity Incentive Plans expire 10 years from the grant date.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S4	The Board also determines the vesting provisions and the exercise price per share, which is the fair market value at date of grant.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P93_S5	Awards issued to employees generally vest over terms ranging from three to five years.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P95_S6	The level of achievement of such goals may cause the actual amount of units that ultimately vest to range from 0% to 200% of the original units granted which is reflected as performance factor adjustment in the table below.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S0	The Company maintains a qualified tax deferred defined contribution retirement plan (the Plan ).
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S1	Under the provisions of the Plan, substantially all employees meeting minimum age and service requirements are entitled to contribute on a before and after-tax basis a certain percentage of their compensation.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S2	The Company matched 100% of employees first 3% contribution and 50% of the employees next 2% contribution.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S3	Effective June 1, 2009, the Company elected to suspend its matching contribution.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S4	Effective April 1, 2010, the Company reinstated its matching contribution of 100% of employees first 3% contribution and 50% of the employees next 2% contribution.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S5	Employees vest immediately in their contributions and the Company s contribution.
1096376_12_ITEM15_P99_S6	The Company s contributions in 2011, 2010 and 2009 were $692, $528 and $452, respectively.

1096376_12_ITEM15_P142_S0	Exhibit 32.1 Statement of Chief Executive Officer Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the undersigned, Joseph M. 1096376_12_ITEM15_P144_S0	Exhibit 32.2 Statement of Chief Financial Officer Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code Pursuant to Section 1350 of Title 18 of the United States Code as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the undersigned, David D. Clark, the Chief Financial Officer of Nutrisystem, Inc. (the Company ), hereby certifies that based on the undersigned s knowledge:
1096376_12_ITEM15_P145_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Nutrisystem, Inc. (together with its consolidated subsidiaries, Nutrisystem, the Company, we, us, or our ) is a leading provider of a weight management system based on a low-calorie, portion-controlled, prepared meal program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages containing a 28-day supply of breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	Most of our customers order on an auto-delivery basis ( Auto-Delivery ), in which we send a month s food supply on an ongoing basis until notified by the customer to stop our shipments.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S3	We offer personalized plans where customers can hand pick their entire menu or go with our pre-selected favorites pack.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S4	Our Basic Plan contains the pre-selected favorites pack while our Core Plan allows customers the ability to customize their menu and provides access to trained counselors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S5	All foods for the Basic and Core programs are shelf-stable at room temperature and will last for up to two years, making the packages relatively inexpensive to ship and store.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P0_S6	Our Select program includes a fully customizable combination of the ready-to-go food as well as our frozen line of menu items and access to trained counselors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our program is based on the following cornerstones that represent who we are to our customers: Results.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	We believe our program enables our customers to lose weight successfully.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Nutrisystem program is based on 40 years of nutrition research and the science of the low Glycemic Index, and offers over 150 portion-controlled items that include relatively higher amounts of fiber, contain good carbohydrates and zero trans fats.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P3_S1	Foods on the lower end of the Glycemic Index are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P3_S2	We also offer transition and maintenance plans, which include support tools and desired meal occasions that customers wish to continue to receive from Nutrisystem.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P3_S3	These plans are designed to help our customers keep the weight off.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	We sell our weight management program primarily through a direct-to-consumer sales and distribution approach using the Internet and telephone.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our customers can order 24 hours a day, seven days a week on our website, www.nutrisystem.com , and the food is shipped directly to the customer s door.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S2	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting of a pre-packaged food program and counseling.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S3	Our customers can either choose our pre-selected favorites food package or customize their monthly food orders for their specific tastes.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our program does not require customers to visit centers, measure foods or count calories.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P4_S5	The entrees are individually packaged and food preparation time is minimal.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	We do not charge membership fees.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	Additionally, we advertise various promotional offers and pricing throughout the year.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	The direct-to-consumer approach using the Internet and telephone provides the privacy that our customers value.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	We provide online and telephone counseling and support to our customers using our trained weight loss coaches, diet counselors and other nutrition and dietary staff, and thus, our customers do not need to travel for a face-to-face meeting.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	Competitive Strengths We believe our program offers consumers a sensible approach to losing weight without the use of faddish, unhealthy or unrealistic weight loss methods.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P6_S3	We intend to capitalize on the following competitive strengths to grow: Product Efficacy .
1096376_13_ITEM1_P6_S4	We believe most of our customers are very satisfied with our products and believe they have lost weight while using our program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	2.0 pounds per week and tended to stay on the program for 11 to 12 weeks.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P7_S1	We believe these surveys indicate overall satisfaction with our program and a potential willingness to refer our program to others.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P7_S2	We have also sponsored clinical trials at leading academic centers in patients with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P7_S3	Statistically significant and clinically meaningful weight loss and improvements in glycemic control were observed, in addition to improvements in secondary endpoints such as waist circumference, total plasma cholesterol and blood pressure.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	We believe that our brand is well recognized in the weight management industry.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our company and our predecessors have been in the weight management industry for 40 years, and we estimate that our company and our predecessors have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising over that time period.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	Low Cost, Highly Scalable Model .
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	Unlike traditional commercial weight loss programs, which primarily sell through franchisee and company-owned centers, we generate revenue in our direct channel through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards).
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our method of distribution removes the fixed costs and capital investment associated with diet centers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	We also minimize fixed costs and capital investments in food procurement and fulfillment: we outsource the production of our food products to a number of vendors and we outsource 100% of our fulfillment operations to a third party provider.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S3	Our goal is to offer our customers a complete weight management program that is convenient, private and cost-effective.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S4	Our customers place their orders through the Internet or over the telephone and have their food delivered directly to their homes.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S5	This affords our customers the convenience and anonymity that other diets, which rely on weight-loss centers, cannot ensure.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S6	Additionally, we provide our customers with a month of food, including daily breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert, which removes the confusion of reading nutrition labels, measuring portions or counting calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S7	We believe our weight management program offers our customers significant value and is priced below those of our competitors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P10_S8	In addition, we do not charge a membership fee, whereas many of our competitors do.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our Industry Weight management is a challenge for a significant portion of the U.S., as well as the global population.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	The 2009-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Study estimated that over 78 million U.S. adults were obese in 2009-2010 and the World Health Organization projects that by 2015, 2.3 billion people will be overweight and 700 million of these will be obese.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	Obesity is increasingly prevalent in children and studies have shown for the first time significant emergence of diseases such as type 2 diabetes in adolescents and young adults.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, overweight and obese individuals are increasingly at risk for diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, certain types of cancer, stroke, arthritis, sleep apnea and depression.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P13_S2	However, there is evidence that weight loss may reduce the risk of developing these conditions, as well as improve the health and quality of life of people who have these conditions.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P13_S3	Our clinical trial results and analyses of real world customer results confirm that people who stay on the Nutrisystem program for at least three months have a very high probability of achieving clinically meaningful weight loss.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	In addition to the health risks, there are also cultural implications for those who are overweight or obese.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P14_S1	U.S. consumers are inundated with imagery in media, fashion and entertainment that depicts the thin body as the ideal body type.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	Studies suggest that there is rampant discrimination against the obese.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	Despite the high percentage of overweight and obese individuals in the U.S., the popularity of dieting appears to indicate consumers desire to be thin.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Competition The weight loss industry is very competitive and consists of pharmaceutical products and weight loss programs, as well as a wide variety of diet foods and meal replacement bars and shakes, appetite suppressants and nutritional supplements.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P16_S1	The weight loss market is served by a diverse array of competitors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P16_S2	Potential customers seeking to manage their weight can turn to traditional center-based competitors, online diet-oriented sites, self-directed dieting and self-administered products such as prescription drugs, over-the-counter drugs and other medically supervised programs.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P16_S3	Our identified peers and competitors include, but are not limited to, eDiets.com, Jenny Craig, Medifast, Inc. and Weight Watchers International, Inc.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P16_S4	We believe that the principal competitive factors in the weight loss market are:
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	the ability to attract and retain customers through promotion and personal referral.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	Based on these factors, we believe that we can compete effectively in the weight management industry.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S2	We, however, have no control over how successful competitors will be in addressing these factors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S3	By providing a well-recognized food-based program using the direct channel, we believe that we have a competitive advantage in our market.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S4	Our Products and Services For 40 years, the Nutrisystem name has been recognized as a leader in the weight loss industry.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S5	We provide a comprehensive weight management program, consisting primarily of a pre-packaged food program, online tools and counseling.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P17_S6	Trained counselors are available to answer questions and make recommendations to help each customer achieve and maintain his or her weight loss goal.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	Customers support and encourage each other and share information through hosted Internet chat rooms and bulletin boards.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	These services are complemented with relevant information on diet, nutrition and physical activity, which is provided on our community website and emailed to our customers bi-weekly.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P18_S2	Additionally, online and smart phone weight management tools are available to our customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P18_S3	These tools include the interactive Mindset Makeover guide, a behavior modification program that was co-authored by an international leader in the field of obesity research and is offered to our customers free of charge.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P18_S4	This insightful and motivational guide walks customers through the program and can serve as an interactive tool for our counselors to use to facilitate communication and enhance weight loss success for our customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	Our Nutrisystem program consists of over 150 portion-controlled items that serve as the foundation of a low Glycemic Index diet.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Glycemic Index is a measure of the quality of carbohydrates in foods and foods on the lower end of the index are generally considered good carbohydrates.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	Our program is portioned for weight loss and offers a balance of carbohydrate, protein and fat that meets national dietary guidelines.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S2	We have also worked to reduce the sodium content of our meal program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S3	Including grocery additions to supplement our meals, our plans contain 1800-2200 milligrams of sodium per day, consistent with national guidelines, and tailored versions of the plans are available that deliver as low as 1500 mg/day.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S4	In contrast, the average American consumes 2800-4000 milligrams of sodium per day.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S5	We constantly strive to meet or exceed nutritional guidelines as they are updated.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P20_S6	In December 2011, we launched SUCCESS, our most comprehensive program to date.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	The SUCCESS program offers our largest ever assortment of signature frozen meals including artisanal Chef s Table dinner entrees; chocolate, vanilla, strawberry and coffee advanced protein shakes; the introduction of a personalized My Daily 3 physical activity program; and increased personalization and flexibility through transition and maintenance plans that help customers manage their weight on their own.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P21_S1	Our Nutrisystem Select program incorporates both our ready-to-go and frozen foods to enhance Nutrisystem s tradition of effective weight loss and weight management.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P21_S2	Most of our weight plans offer these frozen foods.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P21_S3	The program provides customers with premium frozen foods that complement Nutrisystem s prepared food weight loss programs and still adheres to Nutrisystem s nutritional guidelines.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	When a customer orders Nutrisystem Select, two separate shipments are delivered directly to the customer s home.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P22_S1	The first shipment will contain Nutrisystem s standard ready-to-go food and the second shipment will contain the frozen foods.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	The Nutrisystem D Program is a weight loss program specifically designed to produce gradual weight loss in overweight patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	Results from a 2009 clinical study conducted at the Temple University School of Medicine and published in the journal Postgraduate Medicine show that the Nutrisystem D Program, in combination with weekly counseling sessions, helped overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes lose more weight and experience greater reductions in their A1C levels (a key measure of blood glucose control) as compared to those in the control group.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S2	This weight loss was also associated with reductions in blood pressure, cholesterol and waist circumference.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S3	A follow up study at the University of Pennsylvania and Temple University School of Medicine was completed in July 2011 and initial findings were presented at the Obesity Society s annual conference in October 2011, confirming and extending the key findings of the first diabetes trial.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S4	In addition, the subjects randomized to Nutrisystem D achieved a significant reduction in the requirement for diabetes medications relative to the control group.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S5	A third trial in type 2 diabetes employed continuous glucose monitoring to determine the effect of Nutrisystem D versus a self-selected diet on blood glucose levels and variability in the first two weeks of use.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S6	The study, conducted at the University of Pennsylvania, found that Nutrisystem D resulted in lower mean blood glucose and decreased variability in blood glucose.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P23_S7	The decreased variability was due to a decrease in the incidence of high blood glucose, with no significant increase in low blood glucose.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	Multiple trials involving the other Nutrisystem programs are recently completed or ongoing.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P24_S1	One of these, conducted at Florida State University, looked at weight loss, changes in body composition and changes in cardiovascular health in postmenopausal women randomized to receive the Nutrisystem D Program alone, low intensity resistance exercise alone, or the combination, for 12 weeks.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P24_S2	Key findings were presented at the 2012 annual conference of the American College of Sport Medicine.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	The Nutrisystem D Program, alone or with exercise, resulted in weight loss, smaller waist circumference, decreased body fat, improved arterial elasticity and improved cardiac perfusion.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	Several of these trials have received third party funding, with Nutrisystem s financial contribution limited to the provision of program food.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	In May 2012, we introduced a new in-store retail line, Nutrisystem Everyday , comprised of nutritionally balanced bars, smoothies and bakery and breakfast items targeted to consumers who aspire to eat healthier.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	During 2013, we will be refining the products and distribution channels for the retail line.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	Also, we continue to offer our program at Costco through the use of prepaid program cards and gift cards.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	The Nutrisystem program has also been offered at other large retailers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P27_S1	We are continually exploring other major retailers where we may potentially offer our program in the future.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	Typically, our customers purchase monthly food packages of ready-to-go and frozen food containing 28 days of breakfasts, lunches, dinners and desserts, which they supplement with dairy, fruit, salad, vegetables and low-glycemic carbohydrate items.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P28_S1	In certain instances, depending on the promotional offers available, customers can receive more than the typical 28 days of food.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	Most customers order through our Auto-Delivery feature.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P29_S1	By offering a variety of ready-to-go and frozen foods, we help our customers sustain their weight loss efforts.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P29_S2	On our website, customers can order food 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	These lower cost programs help extend the supportive relationship and allow time to reinforce the dietary changes that produced the initial weight loss.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	These plans include recipes and portion-control tools in addition to a reduced number of Nutrisystem entrees delivered each month.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	The features of our weight loss program address many of the most common limitations of traditional weight loss programs, including high initiation and recurring membership fees, the inconvenience of traveling to weight loss centers for scheduled appointments and lack of privacy.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	In addition, our prepared meals provide our customers with a structured program with limited weighing and measuring of foods and no need to count calories, carbohydrates or points.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P31_S2	We believe that the convenience of home delivery, reduced grocery shopping time and rapid food preparation also aid customer compliance with our weight loss program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our food items have accounted for 99% of our revenues for each of the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P32_S1	No other product or service has accounted for more than 1% of our revenue in any of the last three years.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P32_S2	In 2012, 100% of our revenues were generated in the United States.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P32_S3	Approximately 99% and 98% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, were generated in the United States.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	Marketing Marketing is a core competency that drives sales and builds the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S1	We have strong expertise in all facets of both offline and online marketing and utilize an integrated marketing process designed to drive profitable revenue in an efficient, effective way.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S2	We believe Nutrisystem is one of the leading and most efficient offline direct response advertisers in the industry.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S3	We deploy a hybrid of proven direct response techniques to: 1) build brand equity and awareness; 2) encourage qualified customers to call or visit our website; and 3) deliver profitable sales.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S4	We track response to each advertisement through unique toll-free numbers and URLs and we deploy multi-channel campaigns to target potential new customers that include television, print, direct mail and telemarketing efforts.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P33_S5	To reactivate lapsed customers and upsell to those already on our program, we utilize a combination of direct mail and telemarketing efforts which complements our other media advertising.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our online marketing strategy focuses on driving high-volume, cost-effective, qualified leads to our website with an emphasis on increasing both front-end and back-end conversion through constant testing and optimization.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P34_S1	We are continually exploring new online opportunities as the market evolves, but focus the majority of our efforts on search optimization (paid and natural), affiliate management, portal relationships, large ad networks, strategic partnerships, targeted display media and internal/external email campaigns.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	The consumer and business media outreach programs accentuate Nutrisystem as a leader and innovator in the weight loss category.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P35_S1	Our public relations strategically complement offline and online marketing to increase top-of-mind awareness for Nutrisystem, as well as to foster positive word-of-mouth, in order to enhance purchase consideration of our product.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P35_S2	News, Entertainment Tonight and Forbes.com .
1096376_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	We typically compensate our celebrity third-party marketing vendors based on the initial weight loss of the particular spokesperson on our program and maintenance of the weight loss over time.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P36_S1	In addition to traditional public relations, we seek to leverage social media platforms such as Facebook , Twitter , Pinterest, YouTube , blogs and our own active online community to engage potential customers; acquire new customers and leads; listen and learn from our customers, as well as those who do not become a customer; and motivate those on-program to greater success.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P36_S2	Overall, we seek to create true believers who will provide social proof to others of the effectiveness of our program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	Ecommerce As a leading ecommerce company and brand, we constantly strive to employ the latest tools and technology in order to drive increased performance of online customer conversion, retention and reactivation.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P37_S1	We utilize our ecommerce platform to drive a highly-customizable and personalized user experience, as well as to effectively and efficiently manage day-to-day ecommerce business operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P37_S2	In addition, we combine internal resources with external agencies in the development of our website information architecture, user interface and user experience.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P37_S3	In order to optimize the key online business drivers, we continually perform usability testing and are constantly optimizing our website using a variety of sophisticated third party testing tools.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P37_S4	Finally, we measure our online interaction with customers, along with broader website performance, via web analytics platforms and tools.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P38_S0	Sales and Counseling A majority of our direct business sales occur on our website.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P38_S1	The remaining sales are by telephone, and our call center processes all of them.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P38_S2	Our weight loss program is also sold through QVC, a television home shopping network and, in 2012, we introduced a new in-store retail line.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P38_S3	As of December 31, 2012, we employed approximately 68 weight loss counselors and 159 sales agents.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P38_S4	Staffing levels for counselors and sales agents are largely a function of the volume of revenue and orders.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S0	Sales agents are responsible for in-bound sales calls and will initiate out-bound sales calls to our leads and other targeted potential customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S1	Additionally, certain sales agents assist in retaining customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S2	Counselors initiate some out-bound sales calls but primarily focus on in-bound calls and email.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S3	Counselors also handle online web conversations from new visitors and appointments with existing customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S4	Sales agents are paid primarily on commission while counselors receive an hourly wage.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S5	We seek to hire counselors with backgrounds in psychology, sociology, nutrition, dietetics or other health-related fields and with suitable temperaments to speak with our customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S6	Counselors are trained in our program, our Internet chat service, email, motivational techniques and customer service problem solving.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S7	Sales agents are well-versed in explaining our program and working with our customers to determine the program that would best fit their needs in helping them reach their weight loss goals.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S8	Customer Service As of December 31, 2012, we employed approximately 77 customer service representatives.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S9	Customer service representatives are trained to handle in-bound calls and emails from customers who have questions or problems with an order after the sale transaction is completed.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S10	Typical customer inquiries relate to the arrival date of the customer s order shipment, reporting of missing or damaged items and credits and exchanges.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P39_S11	For email inquiries, we have a software system that scans the customer s email message for key words and automatically supplies the representative with a form response that is reviewed, edited and sent back to the customer.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P40_S0	Customer service representatives are paid an hourly wage.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P41_S0	Fulfillment An integrated order receipt, billing, picking, shipping and delivery tracking system comprised of proprietary and third party components is utilized for our orders.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P41_S1	This system integrates the front end, or website customer interface, with order processing and shipping, and allows customers to access shippers order tracking numbers online.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P41_S2	Our computer-assisted picking system allows for virtually paperless order picking in all warehouse facilities.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P41_S3	In 2012, we expanded our capabilities to support the distribution of products to multiple retailers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P41_S4	We utilize an integrated network of distribution facilities through an existing arrangement with our outside fulfillment provider.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S0	Over the past several years, these initiatives resulted in realized cost improvements, enhanced vendor productivity and warehouse efficiencies and helped increase our perfect order index which is a key metric supporting customer satisfaction and quality.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S1	In addition, these initiatives resulted in improved inventory management and allowed us to reduce our overall warehouse footprint.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S2	We currently utilize five outsourced distribution facilities located in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania, Allentown, Pennsylvania, Edwardsville, Illinois and two in Sparks, Nevada.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S3	As of December 31, 2012, all fulfillment was being handled by one outsourced provider.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S4	We have a service agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, which provides for storage, handling of frozen and ready-to-go foods and other services, including pricing and minimum space commitments.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P42_S5	The current contract expires on April 30, 2015, but may be terminated sooner upon 180 days written notice.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P43_S0	We believe that other outside fulfillment providers could be utilized if needed and we continually evaluate the need for secondary fulfillment services.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P43_S1	We continue to partner with our fulfillment provider to reduce the warehouse order turn-around time for processing and shipping orders.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P43_S2	In 2012, approximately 99% of all direct customer initial orders were shipped within three business days of the date the order was received.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P43_S3	In addition, we can deliver to approximately 99% of the domestic population within five business days using standard ground transportation.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P44_S0	Direct customers are not charged for their orders until the ordered product is shipped.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P44_S1	We do not charge customers for shipping and handling on Auto-Delivery food orders provided customers take receipt of their second order.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P44_S2	If a customer cancels before receipt of a second order, the customer will be charged for shipping and the difference in pricing for an Auto-Delivery order versus a non Auto-Delivery order.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S0	All of our foods and supplements are currently outsourced from more than 30 manufacturers or vendors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S1	We have entered into supply agreements with some of these food vendors.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S2	The majority of these agreements provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, as well as exclusivity in the production of certain products, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S3	One agreement also provides for certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S4	All of these contracts may be terminated by us upon written notice, generally between 30 and 180 days.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S5	We anticipate meeting all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S6	In 2012, approximately 17% and 13%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S7	We have a supply arrangement with one of these vendors that requires us to make certain minimum purchases.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S8	In 2011, these vendors supplied approximately 16% and 15%, respectively, of inventory purchases and in 2010, approximately 17% and 18%, respectively, of inventory purchases.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S9	Additionally, we were dependent on one frozen food supplier for less than 20% of our food costs in 2011.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S10	We had a supply agreement with this supplier that expired in November 2011, and we have found other frozen food supply options to replace this supplier.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P45_S11	The amount provided from this supplier in 2010 was negligible.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our product development team uses a number of sources customer feedback, market trends, nutrition science, and breakthroughs in food technology to create new ideas for our program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P46_S1	New foods are created to enhance the variety of our current offerings or to support the efforts of creating a new program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P46_S2	Typically, concepts are formulated in the test kitchen to meet our stringent demands for nutrition and stability.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P46_S3	We then contract with food manufacturers who further develop viable new products based on our specifications.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P46_S4	Regardless of a given food item s pathway through development, that food is evaluated for nutrition, compliance with our program, taste (using testing panels), and cost considerations.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P47_S0	The number of stock keeping units, or SKUs, we introduce each year varies depending on whether we are introducing a new program or simply updating an existing one.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our Customers We offer weight loss programs designed for women, men, seniors as well as people with type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P48_S1	Based on our customer data, our typical customer is female, approximately 50 years of age and weighs approximately 187 pounds.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P48_S2	We believe that, on average, our customers want to lose approximately 43 pounds over a period of time.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P48_S3	Based on our customer surveys, we believe our typical customers tend to stay on our program for 11 to 12 weeks, lose 1.0 to 2.0 pounds per week and have tried other popular diet programs.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P48_S4	We believe that these surveys indicate a willingness to refer our program to others and that our customers value the following Nutrisystem program attributes:
1096376_13_ITEM1_P49_S0	they do not feel hungry while on the program.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S0	Our ecommerce and community websites, both of which are based primarily on third party software customized to meet our business needs, are each hosted in a top tier, co-location facility.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S1	These facilities provide redundant network connections, physical and fire security and diesel generated power back up for the equipment upon which our websites rely and are intended to provide an uninterruptible power supply.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S2	Our servers and our network are monitored 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S3	We use a variety of security techniques to protect our confidential customer data.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S4	When our customers place an order or access their account information, we secure that transaction by using some of the best available encryption technologies, including secure sockets layer, or SSL.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S5	Our customer data is protected against unauthorized access by security measures and we engage a variety of industry leading technology providers including VeriSign, CyberSource and SecureWorks to further ensure the security of our credit card transactions and the safety of our customers personal information.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P50_S6	We own numerous domestic and international trademarks and other proprietary rights that are important to our business.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P51_S0	Depending upon the jurisdiction, trademarks are valid as long as they are used in the regular course of trade and/or their registrations are properly maintained.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P52_S0	We believe the protection of our trademarks, copyrights, patents, domain names, trade dress, and trade secrets is important to our success.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P52_S1	We aggressively protect our intellectual property rights by relying on a combination of watch services and trademark, copyright, patent, trade dress and trade secret laws, and through the domain name dispute resolution system.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P53_S0	As of December 31, 2012, we had approximately 398 administrative, sales, counseling and customer service personnel, 21 employees dedicated to fulfillment and 47 employees in marketing.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P53_S1	None of our employees are represented by a labor union, and we consider relations with our employees to be good.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P54_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is strongest in the first calendar quarter and lowest in the fourth quarter.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P55_S0	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven primarily by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet at certain times of the year and the placement of our advertising is based on the price and availability of certain media at such times.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S0	Available Information All periodic and current reports, registration statements, code of conduct and other material that we are required to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), including our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the 1934 Act Reports ), are available free of charge through our investor relations page at www.nutrisystem.com .
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S1	Such documents are available as soon as reasonably practicable after electronic filing of the material with the SEC.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S2	Our Internet website and the information contained therein or connected thereto are not intended to be incorporated into this Annual Report.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S3	The public may also read and copy any materials filed by the Company with the SEC at the SEC s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, NE, Washington, DC 20549.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S4	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P56_S5	The SEC maintains an Internet site, www.sec.gov , which contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file such information electronically with the SEC.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P57_S0	Executive Officers of the Company The Company s current executive officers and their respective ages and positions are as follows:
1096376_13_ITEM1_P58_S0	Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer Dawn M. Zier has served as our President and Chief Executive Officer and as a member of our Board since November 2012.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P58_S1	Before joining us, Ms. Zier served as the President of International at RDA Holding Co., the holding company and parent of The Reader s Digest Association, Inc., a global media and direct marketing company (the Reader s Digest Association ), since April 2011, as an Executive Vice President of the Reader s Digest Association since February 2011 and as President, Europe of the Reader s Digest Association since October 2009.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P58_S2	Prior to serving in these roles, Ms. Zier served as the President of Global Consumer Marketing for the Reader s Digest Association from June 2008 to October 2009 and as the President and Chief Executive Officer of Direct Holdings U.S. Corp., a marketer of audio and video products and at such time a subsidiary of the Reader s Digest Association, from June 2009 to October 2009.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S0	From August 2005 to June 2008, Ms. Zier served as the President of North American Consumer Marketing for the Reader s Digest Association.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S1	David D. Clark has served as our Chief Financial Officer since November 2007 and in July 2008, the Board promoted Mr. Clark from the position of Senior Vice President, which he had held since November 2007, to Executive Vice President.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S2	Prior to joining us, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of Claymont Steel Holdings, Inc., a manufacturer of steel plate, from November 2006 through October 2007.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S3	Prior to that, Mr. Clark was Chief Financial Officer of SunCom Wireless Holdings, a publicly traded provider of digital wireless communications services, from its founding in 1997 through February 2006 and held the additional position of Executive Vice President from 2000 through February 2006 and Senior Vice President from 1997 through 2000.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S4	On February 6, 2013, Mr. Clark tendered his resignation effective on or about April 1, 2013.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P59_S5	Keira Krausz has served as our Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer since February 11, 2013.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P60_S0	Time, Inc. from 2005 to 2012.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P60_S1	Following the sale of QSP, Inc. in 2012, Ms. Krausz became head of new business development for Animated Storyboards, a global independent provider of television test spots to the advertising industry.
1096376_13_ITEM1_P61_S0	Ms. Krausz started her career at Reader s Digest Association in 1992, and held a number of progressively-responsible positions in product management, marketing, and business management, ultimately ascending to Vice President, Marketing and General Manager, of Reader s Digest Association s Books Music Business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P0_S0	consider carefully the following risks and uncertainties when reading this Annual Report.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the events described below actually occurs, the Company s business, financial condition and operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P0_S2	You should understand that it is not possible to predict or identify all such risks and uncertainties.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Consequently, you should not consider the following to be a complete discussion of all potential risks or uncertainties.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Risks Related to Our Business Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures and our ability to select effective markets and media in which to advertise.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our marketing expenditures were $111.1 million, $110.9 million and $145.9 million in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Our future growth and profitability will depend in large part upon the effectiveness and efficiency of our marketing expenditures, including our ability to:
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	convert consumer inquiries into actual orders.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our planned marketing expenditures may not result in increased revenue or generate sufficient levels of brand name and program awareness.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S2	We may not be able to manage our marketing expenditures on a cost-effective basis whereby our customer acquisition costs may exceed the contribution profit generated from each additional customer.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Our sales may be adversely impacted by the health and stability of the general economy.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, such as a recession or prolonged economic slowdown, may reduce the demand for our products and otherwise adversely affect our sales.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S5	For example, economic forces, including general economic conditions, demographic trends, consumer confidence in the economy, changes in disposable consumer income and/or reductions in discretionary spending, may cause consumers to defer purchases of our program which could adversely affect our revenue, gross margins, and/or our overall financial condition and operating results.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S6	We rely on third parties to provide us with adequate food supply, freight and fulfillment, Internet, networking and call center services, the loss of any of which could cause our revenue, earnings or reputation to suffer.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S7	We rely solely on third party manufacturers to supply all of the food and other products we sell.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S8	In 2012, approximately 17% and 13%, respectively, of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P2_S9	If we are unable to obtain sufficient quantity, quality and variety of food and other products in a timely and low-cost manner from our manufacturers, we will be unable to fulfill our customers orders in a timely manner, which may cause us to lose revenue and market share or incur higher costs, as well as damage the value of the Nutrisystem brand.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	In 2012, more than 90% of our orders were shipped by one third party provider and 100% of our order fulfillment was handled by one third party provider.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Should these providers be unable to service our needs for even a short duration, our revenue and business could be harmed.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Additionally, the cost and time associated with replacing these providers on short notice would add to our costs.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Any replacement fulfillment provider would also require startup time, which could cause us to lose sales and market share.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Internet, Networking and Call Center .
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Our business also depends on a number of third parties for Internet access, networking and call center services, and we have limited control over these third parties.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Should our network connections go down, our ability to fulfill orders would be delayed.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Further, if our website or call center become unavailable for a noticeable period of time due to Internet or communication failures, our business could be adversely affected, including harm to our brand and loss of sales.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Therefore, we are dependent on maintaining good relationships with these third parties.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The services we require from these parties may be disrupted by a number of factors associated with their businesses, including the following:
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S0	with respect to our food suppliers, shortages of ingredients or United States Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) or United States Food and Drug Administration ( FDA ) compliance issues.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We may be subject to claims that our personnel are unqualified to provide proper weight loss advice.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Some of our counselors for our weight management program do not have extensive training or certification in nutrition, diet or health fields and have only undergone the training they receive from us.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S3	We may be subject to claims from our customers alleging that our personnel lack the qualifications necessary to provide proper advice regarding weight loss and related topics.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S4	We may also be subject to claims that our personnel have provided inappropriate advice or have inappropriately referred or failed to refer customers to health care providers for matters other than weight loss.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S5	Such claims could result in lawsuits, damage to our reputation and divert management s attention from our business, which would adversely affect our business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S6	We may be subject to health or advertising related claims from our customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S7	Our weight loss program does not include medical treatment or medical advice, and we do not engage physicians or nurses to monitor the progress of our customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S8	Many people who are overweight suffer from other physical conditions, and our target consumers could be considered a high-risk population.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S9	A customer who experiences health problems could allege or bring a lawsuit against us on the basis that those problems were caused or worsened by participating in our weight management program.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S10	For example, our predecessor businesses suffered substantial losses due to health-related claims and related publicity.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S11	Further, customers who allege that they were deceived by any statements that we made in advertising or labeling could bring a lawsuit against us under consumer protection laws.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S12	Currently, we are neither subject to any such allegations nor have we been named in any such litigation.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S13	If we were subject to any such claims, while we would defend ourselves against such claims, we may ultimately be unsuccessful in our defense.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S14	Also, defending ourselves against such claims, regardless of their merit and ultimate outcome, would likely be lengthy and costly, and adversely affect our results of operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P5_S15	Further, our general liability insurance may not cover claims of these types.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The weight management industry is highly competitive.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If any of our competitors or a new entrant into the market with significant resources pursues a weight management program similar to ours, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Competition is intense in the weight management industry and we must remain competitive in the areas of program efficacy, price, taste, customer service and brand recognition.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Our competitors include companies selling pharmaceutical products and weight loss programs, as well as a wide variety of diet foods and meal replacement bars and shakes, appetite suppressants and nutritional supplements.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Some of our competitors are significantly larger than we are and have substantially greater resources.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Our business could be adversely affected if someone with significant resources decided to imitate our weight management program.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S6	For example, if a major supplier of pre-packaged foods decided to enter this market and made a substantial investment of resources in advertising and training diet counselors, our business could be significantly affected.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P6_S7	Any increased competition from new entrants into our industry or any increased success by existing competition could result in reductions in our sales or prices, or both, which could have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We are dependent on certain third party agreements for a percentage of revenue.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We have contractual agreements with certain third party retailers.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Under the agreements, these third parties control when and how often our products and services are offered and we are not guaranteed any minimum level of sales or transactions.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Additionally, some agreements contain exclusive rights in specified locations to promote our products during the contract term and for a specified period thereafter.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S4	If any third party elects not to renew their agreement or reduces the promotion of our products, our revenues will suffer.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P7_S5	Additionally, in certain instances, we could be prohibited from selling our products through competitors of these third parties for a specified time after the termination of the agreements.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S0	New weight loss products or services may put us at a competitive disadvantage.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S1	On an ongoing basis, many existing and potential providers of weight loss solutions, including many pharmaceutical firms with significantly greater financial and operating resources than we have, are developing new products and services.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S2	The creation of a weight loss solution, such as a drug therapy, that is perceived to be safe, effective and easier than a portion-controlled meal plan would put us at a disadvantage in the marketplace and our results of operations could be negatively affected.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S3	We may be subject to litigation from our competitors.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Our competitors may pursue litigation against us based on our advertising or other marketing practices regardless of its merit and chances of success, especially if we engage in competitive advertising, which includes advertising that directly or indirectly mentions a competitor or a competitor s weight loss program in comparison to our program.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S5	While we would defend ourselves against any such claims, our defense may ultimately be unsuccessful.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P8_S6	Also, defending against such claims, regardless of their merit and ultimate outcome, may be lengthy and costly, strain our resources and divert management s attention from their core responsibilities, which would have a negative impact on our business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our business is subject to online security risks, including security breaches and identity theft.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Unauthorized users who penetrate our information security could misappropriate proprietary or customer information or data or cause interruptions to the product offerings on our website.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P9_S2	As a result, it may become necessary to expend significant additional amounts of capital and resources to protect against, or to alleviate, problems caused by unauthorized users.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P9_S3	These expenditures, however, may not prove to be a timely remedy against unauthorized users who are able to penetrate our information security.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P9_S4	In addition to purposeful security breaches, the inadvertent transmission of computer viruses could adversely affect our computer systems and, in turn, harm our business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	A significant number of states require that customers be notified if a security breach results in the disclosure of their personal financial account or other information.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Additional states and governmental entities are considering such notice laws.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P10_S2	In addition, other public disclosure laws may require that material security breaches be reported.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P10_S3	If we experience a security breach and such notice or public disclosure is required in the future, our reputation and our business may be harmed.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	In the ordinary course of our business, we collect and utilize proprietary and customer information and data.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Privacy concerns among prospective and existing customers regarding our use of such information or data collected on our website or through our services and products, such as weight management information, financial data, email addresses and home addresses, could keep them from using our website or purchasing our services or products.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S2	We currently face certain legal obligations regarding the manner in which we treat such information and data.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Businesses have been criticized by privacy groups and governmental bodies for their use and handling of such information and data.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Currently, a significant number of our customers authorize us to bill their credit cards directly for fees charged by us.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S5	We rely on third party software products to secure our credit card transactions.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S6	Although we have developed systems and processes that are designed to protect consumer information and prevent fraudulent payment transactions and other security breaches, failure to prevent or mitigate such fraud or breaches or changes in industry standards or regulations may adversely affect our business and operating results.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S7	We may experience fluctuations in our operating results which may cause our stock price to be volatile.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S8	We have experienced and expect to continue to experience fluctuations in our quarterly results of operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S9	Our business is seasonal, with revenues generally stronger in the first quarter and weaker in the fourth quarter.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S10	The market price of our common stock is subject to fluctuations in response to our operating results, general trends in the weight loss industry, announcements by our competitors, our ability to meet or exceed securities analysts expectations, recommendations by securities analysts, the condition of the financial markets and other factors.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S11	These fluctuations, as well as general economic and market conditions, may adversely affect the market price of our common stock and cause it to fluctuate significantly.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S12	Future acquisitions and the pursuit of new business opportunities present risks, and we may be unable to achieve the financial and strategic goals of any acquisition or new business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S13	A component of our growth strategy may be to acquire existing businesses or pursue other business opportunities in the market for weight management and fitness products and services.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P11_S14	Even if we succeed in acquiring or building such businesses, we will face a number of risks and uncertainties, including:
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S0	the risk that the anticipated benefits of any acquisition or of the commencement of any new business may not be realized, in which event we will not be able to achieve any return on our investment in that new business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Consummating these transactions could also result in the incurrence of additional debt and related interest expense, as well as unforeseen contingent liabilities, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S2	We may also issue additional equity in connection with these transactions, which would dilute our existing stockholders.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S3	If we do not continue to receive referrals from existing customers, our customer acquisition cost may increase.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S4	We rely on word-of-mouth advertising for a portion of our new customers.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P12_S5	If our brand suffers or the number of customers acquired through referrals drops due to other circumstances, our costs associated with acquiring new customers and generating revenue will increase, which will, in turn, have an adverse affect on our profitability.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We use third-party marketing vendors to promote our products.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S1	If the spokespersons affiliated with the third-party marketing vendors suffer adverse publicity, our revenue could be adversely affected.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Our marketing strategy depends in part on celebrity spokespersons, as well as customer spokespersons, to promote our weight management program.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S3	Any of these spokespersons may become the subject of adverse news reports, negative publicity or otherwise be alienated from a segment of our customer base, whether weight loss related or not.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S4	If so, such events may reduce the effectiveness of his or her endorsement and, in turn, adversely affect our revenue and results of operations.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S5	Third parties may infringe on our brand, trademarks and other intellectual property rights, which may have an adverse impact on our business.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S6	We currently rely on a combination of trademark and other intellectual property laws and confidentiality procedures to establish and protect our proprietary rights, including our brand.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S7	If we fail to successfully enforce our intellectual property rights, the value of our brand, services and products could be diminished and our business may suffer.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S8	Our precautions may not prevent misappropriation of our intellectual property.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S9	Any legal action that we may bring to protect our brand and other intellectual property could be unsuccessful and expensive and could divert management s attention from other business concerns.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S10	In addition, legal standards relating to the validity, enforceability and scope of protection of intellectual property, especially in Internet-related businesses, are uncertain and evolving.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S11	We cannot assure you that these evolving legal standards will sufficiently protect our intellectual property rights in the future.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S12	We may in the future be subject to intellectual property rights claims.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S13	Third parties may in the future make claims against us alleging infringement of their intellectual property rights.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S14	Any intellectual property claims, regardless of merit, could be time-consuming and expensive to litigate or settle and could significantly divert management s attention from other business concerns.
1096376_13_ITEM1A_P13_S15	In addition, if we were unable to successfully defend against such claims, we may have to pay damages, stop selling the service or product or stop using the software, technology or content found to be in violation of a third party s rights, seek a license for the infringing service, product, software, technology or content or develop alternative non-infringing services, products, software, technology or content.
