1096376_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected consolidated financial data presented below has been derived from our Consolidated Financial Statements for each of the periods indicated.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P0_S1	The data set forth below is qualified by reference to and should be read in conjunction with Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements included as Items 7 and 8, respectively, in this Annual Report.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	In 2013, a charge of $5,000 was recorded to settle certain disputes that had arisen with a supplier over a legacy contract.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	In 2013, we recorded $2,357 for severance, including $696 of non-cash expense related to the acceleration of previously awarded equity-based awards.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	During 2012, we recorded $5,724 of severance in general and administrative expense, including $3,293 of non-cash expense related to the acceleration of previously awarded equity-based awards, for our former President and Chief Executive Officer s cessation of employment.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P3_S1	Additionally, we recorded an impairment charge of $2,100 related to advances paid to a frozen food supplier as the supplier was in default with its bank lender and negotiating a work out plan and a charge of $1,980 to vacate a facility.
1096376_16_ITEM6_P3_S2	We also recorded a charge of $2,476 to restructure certain third party marketing vendor contracts and a charge of $1,079 to write off unamortized debt issuance costs.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the financial information included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Background We provide weight management products and services, including nutritionally balanced weight loss programs, multi-day kits available at select retail locations and digital tools to support weight loss.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	The weight loss programs are designed for women and men.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	Additionally, our Nutrisystem D program is designed specifically to help people with Type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight and manage their diabetes.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S3	Our programs are based on more than 40 years of nutrition research.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S4	Our food is created to be nutritious, delicious and portioned for weight loss and management.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S5	Our pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel, through QVC, a television shopping network and select retailers.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S6	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P1_S7	For 2015, 2014 and 2013, the direct channel accounted for 90%, 91% and 92%, respectively, of revenue compared to 8%, 7% and 5%, respectively, for retail and 2%, 2% and 3%, respectively, for QVC.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	We incur significant marketing expenditures to support our brand as we continue to advertise across various media channels.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	New media channels are tested on a continual basis and we consider our media mix to be diverse.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	We market our weight management system through television, print, direct mail, Internet, public relations and social media.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	We review and analyze a number of key operating and financial metrics to manage our business, including the number of new customers, revenue per customer, total revenue, marketing per new customer, operating margins and reactivation revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P2_S4	Our mix of revenue for the direct channel can be divided into three categories.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	First, new customer revenue is all revenue within a quarter from customers joining within that quarter.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	New customer revenue is the main driver of revenue growth.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	Second, on-program revenue is all revenue from customers who joined in previous quarters but who are still within their first nine months on the program.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P3_S3	Third, reactivation revenue is all revenue generated from customers who are more than nine months from their initial purchase.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our ecommerce, direct-to-consumer business model provides flexibility which allows us to manage marketing spend according to customer demand.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	We believe this flexibility is especially valuable as it allows us to react to changing market conditions relatively quickly.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	Additionally, we are continuously looking to make investments to improve lifetime customer economics, length of stay and overall customer satisfaction.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S3	We are able to test new commercials, offers and website configurations to allow us to be more responsive to customer needs and attempt to drive conversion.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S4	We offer a customizable four-week program.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S5	In December 2015, we announced the launch of our Turbo10 program, a clinically tested program that could deliver up to a 10-pound weight loss and a reduction of five inches overall in the first month of dieting.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S6	Previously, we offered our Fast 5+ kit, a one-week starter kit that could help customers lose five pounds plus one inch off their waist in their first week of dieting.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S7	Customers are given a meal plan, access to trackers and tools via NuMi, educational digital content and exercise suggestions and are also encouraged to check in periodically with a Nutrisystem counselor as their needs change in response to weight loss.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S8	Additionally, our multi-day weight loss kits are available at select retailers and represent a significant departure from our traditional four-week program.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S9	The retail channel provides us with great brand exposure, offering consumers who may not be aware of our program an opportunity to sample Nutrisystem at an attractive price point.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S10	Also, we continue to offer our program at Costco through the use of the prepaid program cards and gift cards.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S11	We are actively developing our retail product pipeline and have multiple kits and single items available for purchase.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S12	We believe these new product and program innovations are resonating well with our customers.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S13	We provide an increasing diverse array of weight loss solutions for our customers through an effective and expanding portfolio of products.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S14	Our customers now have greater flexibility in choosing between ready-to-go and frozen options, with no restrictions.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S15	We had an effective acquisition marketing campaign with increased pricing and reduced promotional incentives which drove increases in customer activations, average selling price, length of stay and gross margins in 2015 as compared to 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S16	Revenue for 2015 increased 15% from 2014 to $462.6 million.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S17	We have continued to attract more customers to our brand at our targeted marketing efficiency through the use of expanded media channels.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S18	Our revenue growth was attributable primarily to increases in new customers, on-program revenue, retail revenue and reactivation revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S19	QVC revenue also increased in 2015 as compared to 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P4_S20	Reactivation revenue increased due to higher volumes building off of recent increases in customer counts and marketing efforts to former customers.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	Retail revenue growth was primarily from expanded product offerings and product placement.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	On December 17, 2015, we acquired the SBD brand for a cash payment of $15.0 million.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	The acquisition will provide consumers with additional quality choices and enable us to capture an even more significant share of the commercial weight loss ma rket as we further leverage our expertise in product development, marketing, ecommerce, supply chain logistics, and retail.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 2 of the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	Management develops, and changes periodically, these estimates and assumptions based on historical experience and on various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Management considers the following accounting estimates to be the most critical in preparing our consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	These critical accounting estimates are discussed with our audit committee quarterly.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	We review the reserves for customer returns at each reporting period and adjust them to reflect data available at that time.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S3	To estimate reserves for returns, we consider actual return rates in preceding periods and changes in product offerings or marketing methods that might impact returns going forward.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S4	To the extent the estimate of returns changes, we will adjust the reserve, which will impact the amount of revenue recognized in the period of the adjustment.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S5	The provision for estimated returns for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 was $13.2 million, $12.7 million and $10.8 million, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P8_S6	The reserve for estimated returns incurred but not received and processed was $870,000 and $762,000 at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, and has been included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	We continually assess the quantities of inventory on hand to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	We estimate the reserve for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on our forecasted demand and/or our ability to sell the products, introduction of new products, future production requirements and changes in our customers behavior.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $1.3 million and $460,000 at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P9_S3	The increase in the reserve was due to the change over to the 2016 product and packaging redesign and increased inventories.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and the respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	Deferred tax assets are evaluated for future realization and reduced by a valuation allowance to the extent we believe a portion will not be realized.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	We consider many factors when assessing the likelihood of future realization of our deferred tax assets, including our recent earnings and expectations of future taxable income and other relevant factors.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S3	At December 31, 2014, we had a valuation allowance of $800,000 recorded against our deferred tax asset generated for charitable contributions.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2015, we reduced the valuation allowance due to the expiration of certain charitable contribution carryovers.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P10_S5	At December 31, 2015, there is no valuation allowance.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	We estimate the annual effective income tax rate at the beginning of each year and revise the estimate at each reporting period based on a number of factors including operating results, level of tax exempt interest income, charitable contributions and sales by state, among other items.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Results of Operations Revenue and expenses consist of the following components: Revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	Food sales include sales of food, supplements, shipping and handling charges billed to customers and sales credits and adjustments, including product returns.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	Revenue from the retail programs is also net of any trade allowances, reclamation reserves or broker commissions.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S4	No revenue is recorded for food products provided at no charge as part of promotions.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S5	Cost of revenue consists primarily of the cost of the products sold, including compensation related to fulfillment, the costs of outside fulfillment, incoming and outgoing shipping costs, charge card fees and packing material.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S6	Cost of products sold includes products provided at no charge as part of promotions and the non-food materials provided with customer orders.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S7	Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses, including share-based payment arrangements, for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P12_S8	Internet advertising expense is recorded based on either the rate of delivery of a guaranteed number of impressions over the advertising contract term or on a cost per customer acquired, depending upon the terms.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the advertising and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	The capitalized c osts are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred or the first time the advertising takes place.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	General and administrative expense consists of compensation for administrative, information technology, counselors, customer service and sales personnel, share-based payment arrangements for related employees, facility expenses, website development costs, professional service fees and other general corporate expenses.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P13_S4	Interest expense, net consists of interest expense and unused line fees on our revolving credit facility net of interest income earned on cash balances and short term investments.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	We are subject to corporate level income taxes and record income taxes based on an effective income tax rate for the year.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Overview of the Direct Channel In 2015, 2014 and 2013, the direct channel represented 90%, 91% and 92%, respectively, of our revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	Revenue through the direct channel was $415.8 million in 2015 compared to $365.1 million in 2014 and $327.8 million in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	Revenue is generated primarily through customer starts, reactivation of former customers and the customer ordering behavior, including length of time on our program and the diet program selection.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P15_S3	The revenue increase in 2015 was attributable primarily to an increase in new customers, on-program revenue and reactivation revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P15_S4	Additionally, we had a higher average selling price in 2015 as compared 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	Critical to increasing customer starts is our ability to deploy marketing dollars while maintaining marketing effectiveness.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	Factors influencing our marketing effectiveness include the quality of the advertisements, promotional activity by our competitors, as well as the price and availability of appropriate media.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Revenue increased to $462.6 million in 2015 from $403.1 million in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase in revenue is primarily attributable to an increase in new customers, on-program revenue, retail revenue and reactivation revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S2	Additionally, we had a higher average selling price in 2015 as compared to 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S3	In 2015, direct revenue accounted for 90% of revenue compared to 8% for retail and 2% for QVC.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S4	In 2014, direct revenue accounted for 91% of revenue compared to 7% for retail and 2% for QVC.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S5	Cost of revenue increased to $224.6 million in 2015 from $199.1 million in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P17_S6	Gross margin as a percent of revenue increased to 51.5% in 2015 from 50.6% in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	increases and the discontinuation of the promotion al offer of a free week of food.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	These increases were partially offset by increased produc t costs due to the package redesign and a higher mix of lower margin products .
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	Marketing expense increased to $124.2 million in 2015 from $107.7 million in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S3	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue increased to 26.8% in 2015 from 26.7% in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S4	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2015 promoted the direct business.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S5	The increase in marketing expense was attributable to increased spending for media ($15.3 million) primarily for short form television media and Internet advertising, public relations ($751,000), marketing consulting ($643,000) and marketing compensation and benefits ($402,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S6	These increases were slightly offset by decreased television production ($765,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S7	In total, media spending was $104.6 million in 2015 and $89.3 million in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S8	General and administrative expense increased to $64.7 million in 2015 from $59.2 million in 2014 and as a percent of revenue decreased to 14.0% in 2015 from 14.7% in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S9	The increase in spending was attributable to transaction costs ($2.5 million) associated with the acquisition of the SBD brand in December 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S10	Additionally, there was increased spending for program and product innovation ($1.8 million) and higher compensation and benefits ($845,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S11	Depreciation and amortization expense increased to $9.2 million in 2015 from $7.8 million in 2014 due to increased capital expenditures for our website and digital tools.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S12	Interest expense, net, was $169,000 in 2015 compared to $142,000 in 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S13	In 2015, we recorded income tax expense of $13.7 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 34.4%, as compared to $9.8 million in 2014 with an effective tax rate of 33.6%.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P18_S14	The change in the effective income tax rate was due to the write-off of certain deferred tax assets and liabilities offset by increased levels of food donations.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Revenue increased to $403.1 million in 2014 from $358.1 million in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	The increase in revenue was attributable primarily to an increase in new customers, retail and on-program revenue that was slightly offset by decreased reactivation and QVC revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S2	Additionally, we had a higher average selling price in 2014 as compared to 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S3	In 2014, direct revenue accounted for 91% of revenue compared to 7% for retail and 2% for QVC.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S4	In 2013, direct revenue accounted for 92% of revenue compared to 5% for retail and 3% for QVC.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S5	Cost of revenue increased to $199.1 million in 2014 from $184.2 million in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P19_S6	Gross margin as a percent of revenue increased to 50.6% in 2014 from 48.6% in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	increases partially offset by an increase in certain promotional items.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	Additionally, 2013 was neg atively impacted by a $5.0 million charge recorded to settle certain disputes that had arisen with a supplier over a legacy contract.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S2	Marketing expense increased to $107.7 million in 2014 from $95.8 million in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S3	Marketing expense as a percent of revenue was 26.7% in both 2014 and 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S4	Substantially all of the marketing spending in 2014 promoted the direct business.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S5	The increase in marketing expense was attributable to increased spending for media ($11.9 million) and public relations ($368,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S6	Slightly offsetting these increases was a decrease in marketing consulting ($352,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S7	In total, media spending was $89.3 million in 2014 and $77.4 million in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S8	General and administrative expense increased to $59.2 million in 2014 from $58.2 million in 2013 and as a percent of revenue decreased to 14.7% in 2014 from 16.3% in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S9	The increased spending was due to higher compensation and benefits ($1.3 million) reflecting increased call center commissions and labor costs for key initiatives and increased spending in miscellaneous taxes ($262,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S10	These increases were partially offset by decreased professional, outside and computer services expenses ($390,000), decreased new packaging expense ($274,000).
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S11	Depreciation and amortization expense decreased to $7.8 million in 2014 from $8.9 million in 2013 as certain fixed assets for our website and assets purchased when we relocated our corporate headquarters reached the end of their useful lives.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S12	Interest expense, net, was $142,000 in 2014 compared to $89,000 in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S13	In 2014, we recorded income tax expense of $9.8 million, which reflects an effective tax rate of 33.6%, as compared to $3.5 million in 2013 with an effective tax rate of 32.3%.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P20_S14	The change in the effective income tax rate was due to changes in executive compensation, decreased levels of food donations and the reduction in tax reserves during 2013 due to the lapse of the statute of limitations which offset a charge to record a valuation allowance for charitable contributions recorded in 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	Contractual Obligations and Commercial Commitments As of December 31, 2015, our principal commitments consisted of obligations under supply agreements with food vendors, an agreement with our outside fulfillment provider, agreements with our internet and networking providers, operating leases and employment contracts.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	Although we have no material commitments for capital expenditures, we anticipate continuing requirements for capital expenditures.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	Following is a summary of our contractual obligations.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	We have entered into supply agreements with several food vendors, some of which may provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, exclusivity in the production of certain products, as well as certain rebates to us if certain volume thresholds are exceeded, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	Purchase obligations may vary depending on product mix.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S1	We anticipate that we will meet all annual purchase obligations.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S2	We have no off-balance sheet financing arrangements.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S3	At December 31, 2015, we had working capital of $19.2 million, a decrease of $5.6 million from the $24.8 million working capital balance at December 31, 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S4	Cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2015 were $6.2 million, a decrease of $6.4 million from the balance of $12.6 million at December 31, 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S5	In addition, we had $9.3 million and $16.6 million invested in short term investments at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P24_S6	The decrease in cash, cash equivalents and short term investments was related primarily to the acquisition of SBD for a cash payment of $15.0 million in December 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Our principal sources of liquidity during 2015 were cash flows from operations.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	On November 6, 2015, we entered into a $50.0 million unsecured revolving credit facility with a lender.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	The credit facility provi des for interest on borrowings at either a base rate or the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate, in each case plus an applicable margin and is also subject to an unused fee payable quarterly.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S2	The credit facility contains financial and other covenants, including a minimum consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio , if there are outstanding borrowings , and limitations on, among other things, liens, indebtedness, certain acquisitions, consolidations and sales of assets.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S3	The credit facility can be drawn upon through N ovember 6, 2020, at which time all amounts must be repaid.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S4	This credit facility amended and restated the previous credit agreement dated as of November 8, 2012, which matured on November 6, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P26_S5	There were no borrowings outstanding at December 31, 2015 an d 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	In 2015, we generated cash flow of $31.2 million from operating activities, a decrease of $1.6 million from 2014.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	The decrease in cash flow from operations was primarily attributable to net changes in operating assets and liabilities, including changes in income taxes, an increase in inventories due to increased demand and the package redesign and an increase in receivables due to increased retail revenue.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	These decreases in cash flow were offset by an increase in net income.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	In 2015, net cash used in investing activities was $20.8 million primarily from the cash payment of $15.0 million for the acquisition of SBD and capital additions of $13.0 million offset by the net proceeds from short term investments of $7.2 million.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P27_S4	We are continuing to invest in our ecommerce and web platform and facilities to incorporate new product initiatives and growth opportunities.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	In 2015, net cash used in financing activities was $16.8 million primarily for the payment of dividends partially offset by increased proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	Our Board of Directors declared quarterly dividends of $0.175 per share, which were paid on March 23, 2015, May 21, 2015, August 20, 2015 and November 19, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	Subsequent to December 31, 2015, our Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share payable on March 17, 2016 to stockholders of record as of March 7, 2016.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P28_S3	Although we intend to continue to pay regular quarterly dividends, the declaration and payment of future dividends are discretionary and will be subject to quarterly determination by our Board of Directors following its review of our financial performance.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P28_S4	We believe that our available capital resources are sufficient to fund our working capital requirements, capital expenditures, income tax obligations and dividends for the foreseeable future.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	Typically in the weight loss industry, revenue is greatest in the first calendar quarter and lowest in the fourth calendar quarter.
1096376_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	We believe our business experiences seasonality, driven primarily by the predisposition of dieters to initiate a diet at certain times of the year and the placement of our advertising, which is based on the price and availability of certain media at such times.
1096376_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We believe that we are not subject to any material risks arising from changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity prices or other market changes that affect market risk instruments.
1096376_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Our cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2015 of $6.2 million were maintained in bank and money market funds.
1096376_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Additionally, we invested $9.3 million in short term investments, which are classified as available-for-sale securities and are reported at fair value in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	As such, a change in interest rates of 1 percentage point would not have a material impact on our operating results and cash flows.
1096376_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The information required by this Item is set forth on pages 32 through 51 hereto.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Disclosure Controls and Procedures The SEC defines the term disclosure controls and procedures to mean a company s controls and other procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Financial Officer, as of the end of the period covered by this report, our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer have concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures at the end of the period covered by this report were eff ective to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is (i) recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified in the Commission s rules and forms, and (ii) acc umulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding disclosure.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over the Company s financial reporting.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of the Company s financial reporting and the preparation of consolidated financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that: (i) pertain to maintaining records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparation of the Company s financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and that the receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made in accordance with management and board of director authorization; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance that unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on its financial statements would be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P3_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P4_S0	There was no change in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Management evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Based upon that evaluation, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P6_S0	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm, KPMG LLP, has audited the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Their report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting appears on page 28.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Nutrisystem, Inc.: We have audited Nutrisystem, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S1	Nutrisystem, Inc.'s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P7_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S4	In our opinion, Nutrisystem, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1096376_16_ITEM9A_P8_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015, and our report dated February 26, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S0	Report of Independent Regist ered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Nutrisystem, Inc.:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S1	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company) as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S2	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S4	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1096376_16_ITEM15_P1_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P2_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Nutrisystem, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P2_S4	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Nutrisystem, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report dated February 26, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P3_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P4_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P5_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P6_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P7_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P8_S0	Nature of the Business Nutrisystem, Inc. (the Company or Nutrisystem ) is a provider of weight management products and services, including nutritionally balanced weight loss programs, multi-day kits available at select retail locations and digital tools to support weight loss.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P8_S1	The weight loss programs are designed for women and men.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P8_S2	Additionally, the Nutrisystem D program is designed specifically to help people with Type 2 diabetes who want to lose weight and manage their diabetes.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P9_S0	The Nutrisystem programs are based on over 40 years of nutrition research.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P10_S0	The Company s pre-packaged foods are sold directly to weight loss program participants primarily through the Internet and telephone (including the redemption of prepaid program cards), referred to as the direct channel, through QVC, a television shopping network, and select retailers.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P10_S1	Approximately 99% of revenue for each of the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 was generated in the United States.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P11_S0	Presentation of Financial Statements The Company s consolidated financial statements include 100% of the assets and liabilities of Nutrisystem, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P11_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P12_S0	Cash Equivalents and Short Term Investments Cash equivalents include only securities having a maturity of three months or less at the time of purchase.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P12_S1	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, demand accounts and money market funds comprised all of the Company s cash and cash equivalents.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P13_S0	Short term investments consist of investments in government and agency securities and corporate debt securities with original maturities of greater than three months at the time of purchase.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P13_S1	The Company classifies these investments as available-for-sale securities.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P13_S2	These investments are reported at fair value with the related unrealized gains and losses included in accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income, a component of stockholders equity, net of related tax effects.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P14_S0	The Company evaluates its investments for other-than-temporary impairment by reviewing factors such as the length of time and extent to which fair value has been below cost basis and the Company s ability and intent to hold the investment for a period of time which may be sufficient for anticipated recovery of the market value.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P14_S1	There were no other-than-temporary impairments in 2015, 2014 or 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S0	Inventories Inventories consist principally of packaged food held in outside fulfillment locations.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S1	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market, with cost determined using the first-in, first-out method.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S2	Quantities of inventory on hand are continually assessed to identify excess or obsolete inventory and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S3	The reserve is estimated for excess and obsolete inventory based primarily on forecasted demand and/or the Company s ability to sell the products, introduction of new products, future production requirements and changes in customers behavior.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S4	The reserve for excess and obsolete inventory was $1,253 and $460 at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P15_S5	Fixed Assets Fixed assets are stated at cost.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P16_S0	Depreciation expense is calculated using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which are generally two to seven years.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P17_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the lesser of the estimated useful life of the asset or the related lease term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P17_S1	Expenditures for repairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred, while major renewals and improvements are capitalized.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P18_S0	Included in fixed assets is the capitalized cost of internal-use software and website development incurred during the application development stage.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P18_S1	Capitalized costs are amortiz ed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the asset, which is generally two to five years.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P19_S0	Costs incurred related to planning or maintenance of internal-use software and website development are charged to expense as incurred.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P19_S1	The net book value of capitalized software was $ 15,022 and $13,162 at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P20_S0	Intangible Assets Intangible assets consist of a trade name from the acquisition of the South Beach Diet ( SBD ) brand in December 2015 and domain names (see Note 6).
1096376_16_ITEM15_P20_S1	The trade name is presented at cost, net of accumulated amortization, and is amortized on a straight-line basis over its estimated useful life.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P20_S2	The domain names have indefinite lives and are not being amortized but are reviewed for impairment.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P21_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company continually evaluates whether events or circumstances have occurred that would indicate that the remaining estimated useful lives of long-lived assets may warrant revision or that the remaining balance may not be recoverable.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P21_S1	Long-lived assets are evaluated for indicators of impairment.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P21_S2	When factors indicate that long-lived assets should be evaluated for possible impairment, an estimate of the related undiscounted cash flows over the remaining life of the long-lived assets is used to measure recoverability.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P21_S3	If any impairment is indicated, measurement of the impairment will be based on the difference between the carrying value and fair value of the asset, generally determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows associated with the use of the asset.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P22_S0	As of December 31, 2015, management believes that no reductions to the remaining useful lives or write-downs of long-lived assets are required.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue from direct to consumer product sales is recognized when the earnings process is complete, which is upon transfer of title to the product.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S1	Recognition of revenue upon shipment meets the revenue recognition criteria in that persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the selling price is fixed or determinable and collection is reasonably assured.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S2	The Company also sells prepaid program cards to wholesalers and retailers.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S3	Revenue from these cards is recognized after the card is redeemed online at the Company s website or via telephone by the customer and the product is shipped to the customer.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S4	Revenue from the retail programs is recognized when the product is received at the seller s location.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P23_S5	Deferred revenue consists primarily of unredeemed prepaid gift cards and unshipped food.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P24_S0	When a customer orders the frozen program, two separate shipments are delivered.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P24_S1	One contains Nutrisystem s standard shelf-stable food and the second contains the frozen foods.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P24_S2	Both shipments qualify as separate units of accounting and the fair value is based on estimated selling prices of both units.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S0	Direct to consumer customers may return unopened shelf-stable products within 30 days of purchase in order to receive a refund or credit.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S1	Frozen products are non-returnable and they are non-refundable unless the order is canceled within 14 days of delivery.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S2	Estimated returns are accrued at the time the sale is recognized and actual returns are tracked monthly.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S3	The Company reviews its history of actual versus estimated returns to ensure reserves are appropriate.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S4	Revenue from product sales includes amounts billed for shipping and handling and is presented net of estimated returns and billed sales tax.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S5	Revenue from the retail programs is also net of any trade allowances, reclamation reserves or broker commissions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S6	Revenue from shipping and handling charges was $2,561, $2,013 and $2,000 in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P25_S7	Shipping-related costs are included in cost of revenue in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P26_S0	Dependence on Suppliers In 2015, approximately 19% and 17% of inventory purchases were from two suppliers.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company has a supply arrangement with one of these suppliers that requires the Company to make minimum purchases.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P26_S2	In 2014, these suppliers provided approximately 14% and 17% of inventory purchases and in 2013, approximately 12% and 14% of inventory purchases (see Note 8).
1096376_16_ITEM15_P27_S0	In 2013, a charge of $5,000 was recorded to settle certain disputes that had arisen with a supplier over a legacy contract.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P27_S1	This charge is included in cost of revenue in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P28_S0	The Company outsources 100% of its fulfillment operations to a third-party provider and more than 96% of its orders are shipped by one third-party provider.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S0	Supplier Rebates One of the Company s suppliers provides for rebates based on purchasing levels.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S1	The Company accounts for this rebate on an accrual basis as purchases are made at a rebate percentage determined based upon the estimated total purchases from the supplier.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S2	The estimated rebate is recorded as a receivable from the supplier with a corresponding reduction in the carrying value of purchased inventory and is reflected in the consolidated statements of operations when the associated inventory is sold.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S3	The rebate period is June 1 through May 31 of each year.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S4	For the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company reduced cost of revenue by $698, $883 and $1,068 respectively, for these rebates.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S5	At December 31, 2015, no receivable was recorded but at December 31, 2014 $360 was recorded in receivables in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P29_S6	Effective June 1, 2015, the Company entered into a new agreement with the supplier that includes lower initial pricing and higher levels of purchases required to earn rebates resulting in the Company projecting as of December 31, 2015 that no rebate will be earned.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P30_S0	Historically, the actual rebate received from the supplier has closely matched the estimated rebate recorded.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P30_S1	An adjustment is made to the estimate upon determination of the final rebate.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P31_S0	Marketing Expense Marketing expense includes media, advertising production, marketing and promotional expenses and payroll-related expenses, including share-based payment arrangements, for personnel engaged in these activities.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P31_S1	Media expense was $104,621, $89,304 and $77,396 in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P32_S0	Direct-mail advertising costs are capitalized if the primary purpose was to elicit sales to customers who could be shown to have responded specifically to the direct mailing and results in probable future economic benefits.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P32_S1	The capitalized costs are amortized to expense over the period during which the future benefits are expected to be received.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P32_S2	Typically, this period falls within 40 days of the initial direct mailing.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P32_S3	All other advertising costs are charged to expense as incurred or the first time the advertising takes place.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P32_S4	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, $3,311 and $1,958, respectively, of costs have been prepaid for future advertisements and promotions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P33_S0	Lease Related Expenses Certain of the Company s lease contracts contain rent holidays, various escalation clauses, or landlord/tenant incentives.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P33_S1	The Company records rental costs, including costs related to fixed rent escalation clauses and rent holidays, on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P34_S0	Lease allowances utilized for space improvement are recorded as leasehold improvement assets and amortized over the shorter of the economic useful life of the asset or the lease term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P34_S1	Tenant lease incentive allowances received are recorded as deferred rent and amortized as reductions to rent expense over the lease term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P34_S2	Included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets is $2,266 of a tenant improvement allowance at December 31, 2015, of which $345 is included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities and $1,921 in non-current liabilities.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P34_S3	At December 31, 2014, the tenant improvement allowance was $2,611, of which $345 was included in other accrued expenses and current liabilities and $2,266 in non-current liabilities.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P35_S0	Income Taxes Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and the respective tax bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P35_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P35_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in the consolidated statements of operations in the period that includes the enactment date.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P36_S0	In assessing the ability to realize deferred tax assets, the Company considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P36_S1	A tax benefit from an uncertain tax position may be recognized only if it is more likely than not that the position is sustainable, based on its technical merits.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P36_S2	The tax benefit of a qualifying position is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized upon settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P36_S3	The liability for unrecognized tax benefits is classified as noncurrent unless the liability is expected to be settled in cash within 12 months of the reporting date.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P36_S4	The Company records accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of interest expense, net.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P37_S0	The Company is managed and operated as one business.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P37_S1	The entire business is managed by a single management team that reports to the chief executive officer.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P37_S2	Revenue consists primarily of food sales.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P38_S0	Earnings Per Share The Company uses the two-class method to calculate earnings per share ( EPS ) as the unvested restricted stock issued under the Company s equity incentive plans are participating shares with nonforfeitable rights to dividends.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P39_S0	Under the two-class method, earnings per common share are computed by dividing the sum of distributed earnings to common stockholders and undistributed earnings allocated to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P39_S1	In applying the two-class method, undistributed earnings are allocated to both common shares and participating securities based on the number of weighted average shares outstanding during the period.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P39_S2	Undistributed losses are not allocated to unvested restricted stock as the restricted stockholders are not obligated to share in the losses.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P40_S0	The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted EPS:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P41_S0	In 2015, 2014 and 2013, common stock equivalents representing 229, 377 and 786 shares of common stock, respectively, were excluded from weighted average shares outstanding for diluted income per common share purposes because the effect would be anti-dilutive or the minimum performance requirements have not yet been met.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P42_S0	The cost of all share-based awards to employees and non-employees, including grants of stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units, is recognized in the financial statements based on the fair value of the awards at grant date.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P43_S0	The fair value of stock option awards is determined using the Black-Scholes valuation model on the date of grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P43_S1	The fair value of restricted stock and performance-based restricted stock unit awards is equal to the market price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P43_S2	The fair value of share-based awards is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, net of estimated forfeitures.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P43_S3	The Company relies primarily upon historical experience to estimate expected forfeitures and recognizes compensation expense on a straight-line basis from the date of grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P44_S0	The Company issues new shares upon exercise of stock options, granting of restricted stock or vesting of restricted stock units.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P44_S1	Cash Flow Information The Company made payments for income taxes of $13,508, $7,118 and $2,842 in 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P44_S2	Interest payments in 2015, 2014 and 2013 were $182, $168 and $116, respectively.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P44_S3	During 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company had non-cash capital additions of $670, $483 and $42, respectively, of unpaid invoices in accounts payable and other accrued expenses and current liabilities.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S0	No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers, ( ASU 2014-09 ).
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S1	ASU 2014-09 outlines a new, single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S2	This new revenue recognition model provides a five-step analysis in determining when and how revenue is recognized.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S3	The new model will require an entity to recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects what it expects in exchange for the goods or services.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S4	It also requires more detailed disclosures to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P45_S5	This guidance is effective for annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2017, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period and should be applied retrospectively to each prior reporting period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect of initially applying the ASU recognized at the date of initial application.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P46_S0	Company is currently assessing the impact that adopting this new accounting standard will have on the consolidated financial statements and footnote disclosures.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P47_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-05, Customer s Accounting for Fees Paid in a Cloud Computing Arrangement, to provide guidance to customers about whether a cloud computing arrangement includes a software license.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P47_S1	If a cloud computing arrangement includes a software license, then the customer should account for the software license element of the arrangement consistent with the acquisition of other software licenses.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P47_S2	If a cloud computing arrangement does not include a software license, the customer should account for the arrangement as a service contract.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P47_S3	The new standard is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015, and interim periods within those annual periods.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P47_S4	The Company is currently assessing the impact that adopting this new accounting standard will have on its consolidated financial statements and footnote disclosures.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P48_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P49_S0	An entity using an inventory method other than last-in, first out or the retail inventory method should measure inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P49_S1	The new guidance clarifies that net realizable value is the estimated selling prices in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal and transportation.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P49_S2	This guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P49_S3	The Company is currently assessing the impact that adopting this new accounting standard will have on its consolidated financial statements and footnote disclosures.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P50_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes, which eliminates the current requirement to present deferred tax assets and liabilities as current and noncurrent amounts in a classified statement of financial position.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P50_S1	Instead, entities will be required to classify all deferred tax assets and liabilities as noncurrent in a statement of financial position.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P50_S2	This standard is effective for financial statements issued for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P50_S3	The Company does not expect this new accounting standard to have a material impact of its consolidated financial statements and footnote disclosures.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P51_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and operating expenses during the reporting period.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P51_S1	Actual results could differ from these estimates.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P53_S0	At December 31, 2014, cash, cash equivalents and short term investments consisted of the following:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P54_S0	A three-tier fair value hierarchy has been established by the FASB to prioritize the inputs used in measuring fair value.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P55_S0	Level 1 Valuations based on quoted prices for identical assets and liabilities in active markets.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P55_S1	Level 2 Valuations based on observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active, or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P55_S2	Level 3 Valuations based on unobservable inputs reflecting the Company s own assumptions, consistent with reasonably available assumptions made by other market participants.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P56_S0	The fair values of the Company s Level 1 instruments are based on quoted prices in active exchange markets for identical assets.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P56_S1	The Company had no Level 2 or 3 instruments at December 31, 2015 and 2014.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P60_S0	6. INTANGIBLE ASSETS On December 17, 2015, the Company acquired the SBD brand for a cash payment of $15,000.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P60_S1	The acquisition was financed with existing cash.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P61_S0	The Company will begin developing South Beach Diet meal programs, products, and services as a distinct brand with the intent to launch in both the direct-to-consumer and reta il channels in 2017.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P61_S1	The acquisition will provide consumers with additional quality choices and enable the Company to capture an even more significant share of the commercial weight loss market as it further leverages its expertise in product development, marketing, ec ommerce, supply chain logistics and retail.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P62_S0	The preliminary allocation of the purchase price is to the SBD trade name and is expected to be amortized on a straight-line basis over a period of 15 years.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P62_S1	The approximate fair value of the trade name is based on preliminary estimates and assumptions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P63_S0	The fair value measurement method used to measure the assets acquired utilizes a number of significant unobservable inputs or Level 3 assumptions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P63_S1	These assumptions include, among others, projections of the acquired businesses future operating results, the implied fair value of assets using an income approach by preparing a discounted cash flow analysis and other subjective assumptions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P63_S2	These preliminary estimates and assumptions could change during the purchase price measurement period as the Company finalizes the valuation of the asset acquired.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P64_S0	No amortization expense was recorded for 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P64_S1	Estimated amortization expense for identifiable intangible assets for the next five years is expected to be as follows:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P65_S0	The acquisition was accounted for under the acquisition method of accounting.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P65_S1	During 2015, SBD did not contribute to the operations of the Company as the product offering will be developed over the next year.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P65_S2	The Company incurred $2,498 in transaction costs associated with the acquisition of SBD, which have been charged to expense in 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P66_S0	Additionally, the Company had $84 of domain names acquired in previous years with indefinite lives that are not being amortized.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P67_S0	On November 6, 2015, the Company entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement that provides for a $50,000 unsecured revolving credit facility (the Credit Facility ) with a lender.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P67_S1	The Credit Facility can be drawn upon through November 6, 2020, at which time all amounts must be repaid.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P67_S2	There were no borrowings outstanding at December 31, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P67_S3	The Credit Facility amended and restated the previous credit agreement dated as of November 8, 2012, which matured on November 6, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P67_S4	There were no borrowings outstanding at December 31, 2014 under the previous credit agreement.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	The Credit Facility provides for interest at either a base rate or a LIBOR rate, in each case plus an applicable margin.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	The base rate will be the highest of (i) the Administrative Agent s prime rate, (ii) 0.50% above the Federal Funds Rate and (iii) the LIBOR rate for deposits in dollars for a one-month interest period as determined three business days prior to such date, plus 1.50%.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S2	The LIBOR rate is equal to the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate for the relevant term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S3	The applicable margin is subject to adjustment based on the Company s consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio and ranges from 0.00-0.50% per year for base rate loans and from 1.25-1.75% per year for LIBOR rate loans.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S4	The Company will also pay an unused line fee.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S5	The unused line fee is 0.25% of the total available credit.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S6	The Company incurred no interest expense during 2015, 2014 and 2013.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S7	During 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company incurred $118, $135 and $140 in an unused line fee, respectively, under the Credit Facility and prior financing arrangements.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P68_S8	Interest payments and unused line fees are classified within interest expense, net in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	The Credit Facility contains financial and other covenants including a minimum consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio, if there are outstanding borrowings and limitations on, among other things, liens, indebtedness, certain acquisitions, consolidations and sales of assets.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P69_S1	As of December 31, 2015, the Company was in compliance with all covenants contained in the Credit Facility.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P69_S2	At December 31, 2015, the Company had $23 of unamortized debt issuance costs associated with the Credit Facility that are being amortized over its remaining term.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P70_S0	The Company leases its corporate headquarters and certain equipment.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P70_S1	These leases generally have initial terms of one to 12 years and have renewal options for additional periods.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P71_S0	Lease obligations, with initial or remaining terms of one or more years, consist of the following at December 31, 2015:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P72_S0	Total rent expense for 2015, 2014 and 2013 was $2,304, $2,237 and $2,261, respectively.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P73_S1	In the opinion of management, after consultation with legal counsel, the outcomes of such matters are not anticipated to have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in future years.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P74_S1	These agreements may provide for annual pricing, annual purchase obligations, exclusivity in the production of certain products, as well as rebates if certain volume thresholds are exceeded, with terms of five years or less.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P74_S2	The Company has total purchase obligations of $43,582 as of December 31, 2015.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P74_S3	The Company anticipates it will meet all annual purchase obligations outstanding at December 31, 2015.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P79_S0	A reconciliation of the statutory federal income tax rate to the Company s effective tax rate is as follows:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P80_S0	The change in the effective tax rate from 2014 to 2015 was due to the write-off of certain deferred tax assets and liabilities offset by increased levels of food donations.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P80_S1	The change in the effective tax rate from 2013 to 2014 was due to the changes in executive compensation, decreased levels of food donations and the reduction in tax reserves due to the lapse of the statute of limitations which offset a charge to record a valuation allowance for charitable contributions carryforwards that might not be realized due to the short carryforward period for this temporary difference.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P81_S0	The significant items comprising the Company s deferred income tax assets and liabilities are as follows:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P82_S0	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company had net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $28,696 and $29,474 , respectively, for state tax purposes.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P82_S1	For state tax purposes, there is a limitation on the amount of net operating loss carryforwards that can be utilized in a given year to offset state taxable income.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P82_S2	Net operating losses will begin to expire in 2025.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P83_S0	In 2013, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of $800 against its deferred tax asset generated for charitable contributions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P83_S1	The Company recorded the valuation allowance to reduce the deferred tax asset to an amount it expects is more likely than not to be realized due to the short carryforward period for this temporary difference.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P83_S2	In 2015, the Company wrote off the valuation allowance as certain charitable contribution carryovers expired.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P84_S0	Based on the projected level of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the remaining net deferred tax assets.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S0	Equity Incentive Plans The Company has three equity incentive plans: the 1999 Equity Incentive Plan, the 2000 Equity Incentive Plan and the Amended and Restated 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan (collectively, the Equity Incentive Plans ).
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S1	The Amended and Restated 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan is currently the only plan under which new awards may be granted.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S2	Under that plan, a variety of equity instruments can be granted to key employees and directors including incentive and nonqualified stock options to purchase shares of the Company s common stock, restricted stock, restricted stock units or shares of common stock.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S3	The 1999 Equity Incentive Plan, the 2000 Equity Incentive Plan and the Amended and Restated 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan authorize up to 1,000, 5,600 and 5,400 shares of common stock, respectively, for issuance.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S4	At December 31, 2015, the Amended and Restated 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan had 1,476 shares available for grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S5	Under each of the plans, the Board of Directors determines the term of each award, but no award can be exercisable more than 10 years from the date the award is granted.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S6	The stock options issued under the Equity Incentive Plans generally expire between seven and 10 years from the grant date.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S7	The Board also determines the vesting provisions of all awards and the exercise price per share of stock options issued under the plans, which is the fair market value at date of grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P89_S8	Awards issued to employees generally vest over terms ranging from two to four years.

1096376_16_ITEM15_P95_S0	Expense for restricted stock is amortized ratably over the vesting period.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P95_S1	The following table summarizes the restricted stock activity for 2013, 2014 and 2015:
1096376_16_ITEM15_P96_S0	Additionally, the Company grants performance-based stock units.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P96_S1	The performance-based units have performance conditions and service-based vesting conditions.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P96_S2	Each vesting tranche is treated as an individual award and the compensation expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period for each tranche.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P96_S3	The requisite service period is a combination of the performance period and the subsequent vesting period based on continued service.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P96_S4	The level of achievement of such goals may cause the actual amount of units that ultimately vest to range from 0% to 200% of the original units granted.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P97_S0	The Company recognizes expense ratably over the vesting period for performance-based restricted stock units when it is probable that the performance criteria specified will be achieved.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P98_S0	The fair value is equal to the market price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P98_S1	The following table summarizes the restricted stock unit activity:

1096376_16_ITEM15_P102_S1	Under the provisions of the Plan, substantially all employees meeting minimum age and service requirements are entitled to contribute on a before and after-tax basis a certain percentage of their compensation.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P102_S2	The Company matched 100% of employees first 3% contribution and 50% of the employees next 2% contribution.
1096376_16_ITEM15_P102_S3	Employees vest immediately in their contributions and the Company s contribution.
